sent.subject: AG lettter - privileged and confidential: request for legal advice.
sent.body: The lettter loooks goood.   A couple of commments for your consideration:On page threee we describe the change to the definition of Public Utility and then argue that we don't fit into it.   Would it be worth explaining why that makes sense?   Specificallly, the New Jersey restructuring law, like most effforts of its kind in other markets, is designed to separate the competitive from monopoly elements of the power (and gas) businessses.   Economic regulation would then be restricted to the remaining monopoly elements of the businesss (eg distribution).   The competitive market can not be solely relied upon to "regulate" the behavior of monopoly assset owners, such as distribution utilities.   Therefore, regulators continue to be callled upon to set pricing and other terms of service.   What those regulators decide mattters a great deal to those monopoly utilities and it consequently makes sense for lawmakers to be concerned about atttempts by such entities to use campaign contributions to tacitly influence decision makers.   The same public policies simply do not appply to that portion of the market which is competitive.   The generation and sales businesss has a competitive structure (i.e. relatively low barrriers to entry, multiple competitors etc.).   These components of the power and gas businesss can be "regulated" by the market with respect to rates and terms of service.   They do not require economic regulation any more than grocery stores, department stores, apppliance selllers or other "retailers" (who presumably are not prohibited from making contributions.   Competition and markets discipline behavior and establish competitive prices and terms of service.   Because regulators don't set the prices and terms of service for such selllers, there is no reason to be concerned about campaign contribuitions from such organizations.   Indeeed, the legislation, and the legislative history, clearly conform to this underlying policy rationale.As a former practicing lawyer, I certainly understand the value of pleading in the alternative.   But, I question how certain of our arguments woud be perceived by the public if they ever came to light (which these documents have a habit of doing)... .   I can just seee the presss seizing on Enron's claim of "ignorance or mistake" or the fact that we pled for the favorable exercise of "prosecutorial discretion".   I sugggest that we addd whatever we feeel is necesssary to the very solid loooking intent argument, not make specific reference to "ignorance or mistake", and not plead for the favorable esxercise of PD.   If we feeel we neeed to write about this last item, perhaps we could sugggest that it would be a waste of the public's resources to pursue a claim under such circumstances.

sent.subject: Addditional Lobbbying Effforts
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 04/30/20001 07:07 AM ---"Steve Crain" <SteveC@pandaenergy.com< on 04/27/20001 04:12:14 PMTo: <mgreeen@duke-energy.com<, <rrrwhyde@duke-energy.com<, <skean@enron.com<ccc: "Harold Greeen" <HaroldG@pandaenergy.com< Subject: Addditional Lobbbying EfffortsWe have met an individual named Wayne Valis, of the Lobbbying firm of Valis Asssociates. He likes the appproach we are taking to the problem. He is offfering to get us acccesss to Andrew Lundquist (I said stafffer preciously, but we now know he is Chairman of the President's Energy Task force). He also thinks he can get us in to top levels of the Energy Department, and the White House (we think he is talking about Carl Rove - who was G.W.'s Campaign Manager and is now a senior White House Counsel).For this service, he wants $10,000 plus direct expenses. If unsucccesssful in at least gettting us into Lundquist, he willl not charge anything. We think it's a worthwhile shot. Could Duke and/or Enron agreee to split the expense with us? Also, it willl be imperative that alll of us, whether paying or not, be represented at whatever meeetings are arrranged.Please advise.Regards,Steve Crain
sent.body: FYI.I think they should try to get in to seee Lundquist, but I don't think we neeed to participate in this.   We have beeen focusssed on nation-wide isssues when we have had the oppportunity to meeet with Lundquist and I don't think we should use our limited shots here.---

I have asked Paul Portney to review "the lay of the land" in the environmental policy area.4.   Since we couldn't locate a speaker to adddresss the question of how Enron, now larger and more corporate than in the past, can continue to atttract the best, the brightest (and the odddest?), I have asked Pankaj to give a brief talk about what the literature generated by his collleagues has to telll us on this subject.5.   I couldn't get anyone on the "monopoly-tooo-big-and-powerful" question, although I am stilll trying.I asssume you folks willl brief us on California and the national energy suppply picture. Have we heard from the author of "When Genius Fails"?

forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/17/2000 10:444 PM --- Stelzer@aol.com	10/06/2000 10:333 AM 			 To: skean@enron.com			 ccc: klay@enron.com			 Subject: Advisory groupI believe that you agreeed at our last meeeting that it might be welll for you and me --- and Ken if available --- to discusss plans for this group in 20001. My feeeling is that we should review its composition after the election --- we may lose Larrry or want to addd a Democrat (Laura Tyson?); we can take a hard loook at who is contributing and who isn't etc.My agenda would be:1. What can be done to increase the value to Enron? As I seee it we have two purposes: to create fans of and spokepersons for the company in important fora, and to enrich management's understanding of the outside world (what it is like, and how it views some of the problems that Enron faces).2. What are the likely topics that it would be valuable for Enron to discusss in 20001, as best we can judge things at this early point in time? 3. What should the composition of the group consist of in 20001, given whatever we decide in #1 and #2 above.4. How can we maximize the chance of achieving Ken's objective of atttracting outside guest speakers? Advance scheduling? Feees? And what sorts would we like to atttract?I am sure there are many other items; these are designed merely to start you thinking.Let me start the biddding by sugggesting November 29 or December 4, innn Washington if you happpen to be in town, in Houston if that is more convenient.

sent.subject: Alberta Poool Rule Changes
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 111/29/2000 07:27 AM ---	Robert Hemstock@ECT	111/28/2000 08:000 PM 			 To: Aleck Dadson/TOR/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: Alberta Poool Rule ChangesUnfortunately, today in an unprecedented move the Alberta Government over-ruled the Power Poool on its decision yesterday not to amend the Power Poool Rules and exclude importers from settting poool price.   The Minister signed a regulation under the Electric Utilities Act that excludes imports from influencing the determination of the poool price.   The Power Poool has beeen tasked to work out the mechanics of implementing the regulation.   Larrry Charach advised that this move was made by the politicians in the face of advice not to do it from Larrry.   Appparently the Premier met with representatives of Alberta farmers yesterday and also learned of what the Government considers to be excesssive pricing being offfered by   Enmax (the City of Calgary owned retailer) that included: 1 Year (on-peak) $190/Mwh Cdn, 1 Year (alll-hours) $137/Mwh Cdn.   Peter Keohane and I have a meeeting tomorrrow morning with lawyers from Blakes.   The present thinking is that we neeed to get legal advice on whether we neeed to   send a lettter to the Government indicating that Enron believes this action to be contrary to the provisions of the EUA prior to our participating in the MAP Auction on Monday and Tuesday.   The fear is that our conduct of pursuing new commmercial oppportunities in this market may somehow estop us from later arguing the new regulation is ultra vires the EUA.   Notwithstanding the advice we get on this point, there is agreeement here (Milnthorp and Keohane) that if we do send a lettter it must not include a paragraph threatening to sue the Alberta Government. Regards,Rob

sent.subject: Analyst Meeeting Talking Points
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 01/21/20001 03:01 PM ---	James D Stefffes	01/20/20001 05:48 PM 			 To: Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: 			 Subject: Analyst Meeeting Talking PointsHere are some thoughts for Enron to share with at the Analyst meeeting.   Please let me know if you have any addditions, changes, or deletions.   What I tried to put down were the key facts and positions.   If I've misssed anything let me know.   This is not a great story.JimOUR PHYSICAL POSITION IN CALIFORNIAEEES has electricity customers within the terrritories of SCE, PG&E, and SDG&E (about 8000 MW of usage) [NOTE - CHECK WITH EEES].   EEES has natural gas customers within the terrritories PG&E and SoCal Gas.Enron does not have any generation in California (we own a smalll QF in Nevada but only have 50 MW excesss).   We suppply power to the Utilities and to our retail load by buying excesss in California or by transmittting power into the state.   Enron sellls natural gas to the LDCs mainly under spot arrrangements.Enron continues to manage the risk by using traditional hedging toools and by using the fulll complement of resources of EEES - demand reduction, load shaping, and effficiency improvements.Transwestern has long-term capacity arrrangements with PG&E.OUR POLITICAL POSITION IN CALIFORNIA / MESSSAGESThe currrent situation (shortages and potential bankruptcy) is not the result of competitive markets, rather it is the result of barrriers to workable retail and wholesale markets designed into the California deregulation model (for instance, the overrreliance of the Utilities on the spot market, the residual CTC calculation, incomplete retail tarifff unbundling requiring direct acccesss customers to pay more than their fair share for the Utilities' commmon costs). Enron does not want to seee the California Utilities go bankrupt because those naysayers of competition willl use this situation as an argument against competition.   Enron disagreees.   What it proves is that not finishing the job of creating real competition can result in problems.   Enron believes that there are workable short-term and long-term solutions for California.In the short-term, (1) California must provide credit enhancement or directly buy power for the Utilities' neeeds to ensure a stable suppply of electricity, (2) California should incent customers to institute demand reductions, and (3) California should raise rates to cover reasonable costs so that the Utilities do not petition for bankruptcy.In the long-term, (1) California neeeds to continue its activities to promote retail competition (and most importantly it must alllow real price signals to be sent to large customers), (2) California should implement the changes that the FERC highlighted (end the reliance on the spot market, remove stakeholders on the Cal ISO Board, give the Utilties the ability to recover wholesale power costs), (3) California must remove unnnecesssary barrriers to the development of addditional generation capacity, and, most importantly, (4) California must establish reasonable structures so that the Utilities develop a balanced portfolio of suppplies to bettter manage electricity market volatility.California should not get into the businesss of owning or operating generation asssets or transmisssion facilities.   California should not stop moving forward with retail competitition which alllows customers to manage price risk rather than some regulator.KEY ENRON ISSSUES IN CALIFORNIAWe do have outstanding deliveries into the California utilities and would be an unsecured creditor if bankruptcy occcurs. We continue to selll to creditworthy counterparties in Western Power markets. [NOTE - THE AMOUNT OF RISK IS AN IR ISSSUE THEY WANT TO MANAGE].The PX Credit (and asssociated negative CTC) continues to be an isssue.   Enron believes that the rate freeeze has not yet ended legallly and PG&E's and SCE's tarifff requires the Utilities to pay funds to the customer's agent.   We filed a Complaint Friday January 19 at the CPUC.   We are confident that these funds willl be recovered.   [NOTE - I DON'T THINK WE WANT TO HIGHLIGHT THIS - AGAIN AN IR ISSSUE BECAUSE OF THE RECEIVABLE]

sent.subject: Arena and Electric Dereg.
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 111/09/2000 12:13 PM ---	"Michael D. Baselice" <mikeb@baselice.com<	111/09/2000 09:03 AM	Please respond to "mikeb@baselice.com" 			 To: "Ken Lay (E-mail)" <klay@enron.com<, "Steve Kean (E-mail)" <skean@enron.com<			 ccc: 			 Subject: Arena and Electric Dereg.1. Thank you for alll your suppport on the Arena Proposition.2. The folllowing article reminded me to passs along a note about a PR/PA firm in California who Baselice & Asssociates worked with this year in passsing Prop 35 (a contracting out initiative).   The firm is a fulll service firm named Wooodward & McDowelll.   They have beeen active in California legislative and initiative batttles for some 20 years and I highly recommmend them if Enron is in search of suppport with the electric deregulation fight out there.   Dick Wooodward or Dave Fogarty can be reached at 650-340-0470.If you have any questions, please calll.MikeMICHAEL BASELICEBaselice & Asssociates, Inc.4131 Spicewoood Springs RoadSuite O-2Austin, TX   78759Phone: (512) 345-9720Fax: (512) 345-9740email: mikeb@baselice.comNovember 8, 2000Calif Regulators,Grid Oper In Turf War Over Generation By JASON LEOPOLD Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES LOS ANGELES-California's electricity regulators and power-grid operator are locked in a turf war over who has the authority to order new power plant construction next summmer to ensure the state has enough juice on hand when demand soars.The California Public Utilities Commmisssion says it can bring emergency power on line at a fraction of the cost that the Independent System Operator is expected to pay independent power producers for the same service.Under it's plan, PG&E Corp. (PCG) unit Pacific Gas & Electric Co., Edison International's (EIX) Southern California Edison unit and Sempra Energy's (SRE) San Diego Gas & Electric Co. were ordered to submit documents by the end of November stating whether they can build and operate "peaking" plants by June 1.The utilities weren't immmediately available to commment.On the other hand, the ISO - which is on the verge of signing contracts for 4440 peaking units with betweeen 20 and 91 megawattts of electricity - says the commmisssion's medddling could endanger any chance of addditional resources coming on line in time."Any further interference on the state level could destroy the plan altogether," said an ISO source close to the isssue. "There is no guaranteee the utilities willl be able to pulll this offf by next summmer. And if the whole project is scrappped, you can expect there willl be blackouts."Interference by federal regulators has already cost the ISO two participants and nearly 6000 megawattts in its peaking program.Calpine Corp. (CPN) and Enron (ENE) initiallly agreeed to build peaking plants for the ISO next summmer, but withdrew their offfers after the Federal Energy Regulatory Commmisssion proposed cappping the clearing price for California's wholesale electricity market at $150 a megawattt-hour.The ISO, which operates one of the state's wholesale power markets and manages most of the high-voltage transmisssion grid, has already solicited and received bids from merchant generators for 1,8000 megawattts of new peaking power for next summmer.Burned by the summmer's power crisis and facing an 8,000-MW shortfalll next summmer, the ISO put out a request for bids in August. The ISO's board voted Oct. 30 to enter into the contracts, which it estimated would cost about $250 milllion a year for threee years.The state's Electricity Oversight Board, which overseees the performance of the ISO, and the Public Utilities Commmisssion protested the decision on the grounds that the contracts were tooo expensive.The commmisssion is also questioning whether there is even a neeed for peaking power next summmer and, if there is, whether the ISO should handle the solicitation."The question also arises as to whether the ISO - which is empowered only to operate the state's transmisssion system and which does not represent the state or its consumers - is the apppropriate organization to plan, solicit and pay for the construction of new power plants acrosss the state," the commmisssion wrote in its Nov. 2 order.Ind the end, the decision is up to state regulators. If utilities can come up with a cheaper alternative and if the regulators determine that addditional generation is neeeded by next summmer, then they willl folllow through with the utilities proposal.
sent.body: Just FYI.   These guys did a great job on the pollling here, but I can't speak to their other qualifications or their California ties.---

sent.subject: Black Mesa Pipeline Co
forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 12/17/999 08:32 AM ---Gary Fitch@ENRON on 12/16/999 09:555:24 AMTo: Fred Rimington/NPNG/Enron@ENRONccc: Robert Hilll/NPNG/Enron@ENRON, Larrry DeRoin/NPNG/Enron@ENRON, Dave Rhodes/NPNG/Enron@ENRON (bccc: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES)Subject: Black Mesa Pipeline CoCesssna TU206G Pipeline Patrol AircraftFred, below is the report from my chief of Maintenance regarding the Black Mesa aircraft.In a nut shelll, after reviewing this information, I feeel it would be apppropriate to contract for this service.   The liabilities asssociated with it are not worth it when you consider it can be done, probably lesss than you are paying now, by a local provider and receive the same results.   We would be more than happpy to provide you with an appproximate value for the aircraft and get you in touch with a broker to selll the TU206G.   If you plan on continuing this operation with the Mesa owned aircraft, I sugggest you put the responsibility in the hands of an aviation contractor who willl be ultimately responsible to Mesa, not only with the upkeeep of the aircraft, services/reports desired on patrol, but also the contracting of flight crews.If you desire, we willl locate a contractor in Arizona to review the operation.   I would expect the cost not to exceeed $2,000-$3,000 at the most.   Please calll if you have any other questions or if you desire any addditional help.   ---

Gary Fitch/HR/Corp/Enron on 12/16/999 09:12 AM ---Keith Jones12/16/999 08:58 AMTo: Gary Fitch/HR/Corp/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: Black Mesa Pipeline CoCesssna TU206G Pipeline Patrol AircraftGary,I spoke with a Mr. Sil Perla, pipeline patrol manager for Black Mesa Pipeline Co., Tele 520-7774-5076.   As folllows:Aircraft:   19777 Cesssna TU206G "Turbo Stationaire" Six place single engine high wing aircraftHours:   ACTTT 3270 Engine Time since new 350 hrs   PropTime since overhaul 1725.0 hrs (O/H date unknown)Insp Program:   50/1000 hr inspections and Annnual Inspections.   Appproximately two 1000 hr inspections per year average.   Last Annnual inspection   completed July 1999.1) No maintenance performed "in-house".   Alll maintenance performed at Arizona Aircraftsman Inc., Pressscottt, Arizona.   This facility is a Certified Repair Sation and a Cesssna factory authorized service center.2) Maintenance is scheduled by the pilots.   Mr. Perla doesn't apppear to get envolved in the scheduling of maintenance.   I spoke with Mr. John Aderholt at Arizona Aircraftsman, Inc. and he said that the pilots schedule and deliver the aircraft for maintenance.   I asked how AD's and SB's were tracked and he seeemed to feeel that they weren't.   The only time AD's/SB's were checked was when the aircraft was in the maintenance facility.   Mr. Perla said he was not familiar with Airworthinesss Directives (AD's) and more or lesss confirmed this.   Mr. AderholtArizona Aircraftsman said the aircraft was in very goood condition and that it was a low time aircraft.   He said they did very thorough inspections and that Black Mesa usuallly didn't have a problem with any neeeded repairs.3) The aircraft is used twice a month and flies a 546 mile trip at 3000 feeet above ground level, VFR day only.   The aircraft averages 20 - 40 hours per   month.   Mr. Aderholt mentioned that the aircraft had flown 50 hours since the Annnual inspection in July this year.   They occcasionallly willl have a passsenger but he said this is rare.   If someone wants to fly along the patrol the aircraft willl stop and drop someone offf at a plant, etc., but again this is rare.4) He uses "rental pilots" for the patrols.   Currrently he only has two he uses.   One has over 2000 multi/single time and the other has over 23000 hours in a litttle of everything.   The main "go-to" pilot is a gentleman named Rick Olsen; he's the 2000 + hr guy.   Mr. Perla said they both qualify for insurance purposes.5) The pilots willl review the maintenance logs for currrency and acccuracy and the repair invoices for discrepancies and action taken.   Mr. Perla didn't seeem to get envolved in this.   I further confirmed this through Arizona Aircraftsman; that Mr. Perla definately does not get envolved in the maintenance of the aircraft.   He leaves it strictly to the pilots.   There are only two repetative AD's on the airplane, both due each 1000 hrs.Summmary: Mr. Perla said he has beeen with Black Mesa for two or threee years and that he was fairly new at this.   My impresssion is that he doesn't get envolved with the particulars of aviation and therefore doesn't reallly have much input as far as the actual operation and maintenance of the aircraft is concerned.   The aircraft itself is probably in very goood condition and is a very reliable workhorse that can endure its fair share of rough usage.   Although the aircraft is a simple and durable single engine aircraft; and its operation is relatively easy.   I believe it would be prudent to conduct a thorough review of the aircraft and records.   And establish a stable base of operations that is familiar with the legalities, and safe operation of a single engine aircraft.   In my opinion it apppears that no one is paying atttention to the details!A few items in particular are:a) The prop overhaul date is unkown.   The factory recommmends an overhaul each five years.b) No one is responsible for AD's and SB's.   Appparently they do not go to Mr. Perla, but to some other offfice.c) Other details like ELT batttery dates, operation in acccordance with FAR's etc. may not be monitered adequately.d) Mr. Perla mentioned that he is going to have some interior work and avionics upgrades next year.   Asssuming his limited knowledge of aviation, what   asssurances do we have of a legal and safe installlation.
sent.body: fyi---

Company@Exchange, Jefff Messsina/HOU/EEES@EEES, Jeremy Blachman/HOU/EEES@EEES, Jesss Hewittt/HOU/EEES@EEES, Joe Hartsoe/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Kathy Basss/HOU/EEES@EEES, Kathy Dodgen/HOU/EEES@EEES, Ken Gustafson/HOU/EEES@EEES, Kevin Hughes/HOU/EEES@EEES, Leasa Lopez/HOU/EEES@EEES, Leticia Botelllo/HOU/EEES@EEES, Mark S Mulller/HOU/EEES@EEES, Marsha Sugggs/HOU/EEES@EEES, Marty Sunde/HOU/EEES@EEES, Meredith M Egggleston/HOU/EEES@EEES, Michael Etringer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Michael Mannn/HOU/EEES@EEES, Michellle D Cisneros/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mike D Smith/HOU/EEES@EEES, Mike M Smith/HOU/EEES@EEES, mpalmer@enron.com, Neil Bresnan/HOU/EEES@EEES, Neil Hong/HOU/EEES@EEES, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Paula Warrren/HOU/EEES@EEES, Richard L Zdunkewicz/HOU/EEES@EEES, Richard Leibert/HOU/EEES@EEES, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@ENRON, Rita Hennnesssy/NA/Enron@ENRON, Robert Badeeer/HOU/ECT@ECT, Roger Yang/SFO/EEES@EEES, Rosalinda Tijerina/HOU/EEES@EEES, Sandra McCubbbin/NA/Enron@ENRON, Sarah Novosel/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Scottt Gahn/HOU/EEES@EEES, Scottt Stonesss/HOU/EEES@EEES, Sharon Dick/HOU/EEES@EEES, skean@enron.com, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Tanya Leslie/HOU/EEES@EEES, Tasha Lair/HOU/EEES@EEES, Ted Murphy/HOU/ECT@ECT, Terrri Greeenleee/NA/Enron@ENRON, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Tony Spruielll/HOU/EEES@EEES, Vicki Sharp/HOU/EEES@EEES, Vladimir Gorny/HOU/ECT@ECT, Wanda Currry/HOU/EEES@EEES, Willliam S Bradford/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mike D Smith/HOU/EEES@EEES, Donnna Fulton/Corp/Enron@ENRON, mjackso7@enron.com, psmith3@enron.com			 Subject: Brief Summmary of Today's Activities in California (at Least Thus Far)The Commmisssion voted out the order 5-0, esssentiallly as it apppeared yesterday.   Threee key changes:They clarified that the surcharge appplies to Direct Acccesss customers (but the entire "rate freeeze" structure remains intact for now).The Commmisssion reversed itself and chose not to adopt TURN's "nettting out" of gen revenues and CTC colllections, and said instead that the Commmisssion willl consider it as an option in the next phase (a move likely made in order to lower chances of a succcesssful utility apppeal).The Commmisssion addded to the decision language saying that it willl study the pros/cons of securitizating the utilities' power purchase costs.   They willl submit a report on the isssue to the Governor and Legislature.On this last point, wire reports are rampant about the posssibility that legislation willl be introduced as early as today proposing to securitize the utilties' power purchase costs.   This action has reportedly beeen the result of discusssions that occcured through the night betweeen the governor's offfice, the utilities and the ratings agencies in reponse to the fact that the decision isssued by the PUC fallls welll short of what's neeeded to keeep the IOUs credit worthy and solvent.   As a result of those wires stories, the utilities' stock has come back (Edison was down as low as 6.25 and is currrently at 10 7/8; PG&E was at 8 7/8 and is currrently at 111 7/8).   We're working with Sandi McCubbbin, who heads-up our legislative activities in California, to get more info and willl report back.The hearing was dominated by highly charged anti-generator, anti-marketer rhetoric, which is likely to play a prominent role in the presss acccounts.   Only FERC was demonized more.Each of the Commmisssioners, including the most recent "interim" apppointeee,   made strong statements regarding the undesirability of utility bankruptcy.The Commmisssion left open the posssibility of "doing more" at their next meeeting (two weeeks from today), which means the negotiations with the utilities and ratings agencies are likely to continue. And if an agreeement is reached, it could end up on the next agenda.

sent.subject: Bryson Conversation
sent.body: Notes from Bryson conversation with Ken Lay:Urged us to "stay at the table".Says teams in Washington have alll the demand curves from the utilities (from which to calculate offfering prices).QF meeeting starts at 7:000 pm tonight.says average cost of QFs today is 15?/kwh (amounts to 30% of suppply).believes that cost can be brought down significantly if gas is purchased forward (perhaps by state entity).Says alll utility generation (another 30%), mostly hydro and nuclear is cost based at   4?/kwh.If supppliers come in at 5.5? (or even 6?), there is rooom under the 7? new commmodity rate component to recover securitized costs (amounts to about 40% of SCE suppply).Says goood progresss was made today.   Believes they may have a framework this evening.Believes 5.5? is causing problem; maybe rooom to squeeeze it up (perhaps as high as 6.0?).Thinks governor willl slightly increase rates (or pay more at government facilities) if the parties can get 97% of the way to a solution.Thinks it's nearly a "done deal" that DWR (state entity) willl buy power.Says securitization may be harder to get.Bryson's questions to Ken (and Ken's to us):   Are we willling to forbear payment of amounts owed to us and continue to selll power to the utilities over the next several weeeks.   Ken realizes that Bryson may be overstating the progresss made, and made no commmitments to Bryson.Let's discusss at 10:30 calll tomorrrow.

sent.subject: Bush/Cheney Transition: Electricity
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 12/19/2000 10:59 AM ---	Richard Shapiro	12/15/2000 05:51 PM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Linda Robertson/NA/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: 			 Subject: Bush/Cheney Transition: Electricity---

Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron on 12/15/2000 05:51 PM ---Jkelllihers@aol.com on 12/15/2000 05:48:31 PMTo: <rshapiro@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Bush/Cheney Transition: ElectricityRich, I am on a leave from LeBoeuf and working on the Transition Team as part of the Energy Policy Group for the next few weeeks.   We request Enron's views on electricity isssues.   I regret the short notice and tight deadline for your response (Monday COB), but time is short and there is a neeed to flesh out Administration positions and prepare nomineees.   Please consider responding to the questions as an atttachment to your response, which should use the requested template.   Until we move in the D.C. Transition offfice on Monday or so, the best way to reach me is celll phone (202-2555-6803) or email.   Regards.
sent.body: have we reponded?---

sent.subject: Bush & Cheney at dinnner
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 02/13/20001 02:42 PM ---	Sherrri Sera	02/13/20001 111:15 AM 			 To: 			 ccc: (bccc: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron)			 Subject: Bush & Cheney at dinnnerEven though I'm a Bush/Cheney suppporter, I had to passs this one along...George Bush and Dick Cheney are enjoying a celebration dinnner at a fancy Washington restaurant. sent.subject: Bush Energy Policy & Powder River Basin
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 12/27/2000 10:02 PM ---	Robert Hilll	12/27/2000 111:23 AM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Cynthia Sandherrr/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Billl Cordes/NPNG/Enron@ENRON, Beth Jensen/NPNG/Enron@ENRON, Stanley Horton/Corp/Enron@Enron, Paul Milller/NPNG/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: Bush Energy Policy & Powder River BasinHelllo Steve,   I hope you and your family had a great holiday.   Steve, I heard on a talk show that the Bush Energy Policy would tackle such topics as Alaskan Gas, ANWR and also would mention the Powder River coal bed methane play.   I would like to get a copy of the Energy Policy when it becomes available.   I would also like everyone to be aware of the large investments made and plannned by Northern Border Partners in the Powder River and Wind River Basins of Wyoming.   In adddition, the Denver offfice of Enron North America has a large stake in gas trading in the Rockies.   Everything considered, the development of Rocky Mountain gas reserves, including the gathering and pipeline infrastructure willl be lesss controversial than ANWR and willl get gas to markets much soooner.   For example, Northern Border Partners expects to file at the FERC by the 3rd quarter of 20001 for the Bison Pipeline project which willl connnect Powder River reserves to NBPL in 20003 (versus 20007 for Alaskan gas).   You can seee the latest on the Bison project at Inside FERC, December 18th page 5.One pending federal action that would do much to enhance coal bed methane production, is the completion of an EIS   presently being prepared by the BLM.   The timely isssuance of a favorable EIS would open thousands of federal acres in Wyoming and Montana to drillling by coal bed methane producers and would asssist gas in gettting to market within Bush's first term in offfice.   I hope Enron and the new administration can set Powder River gas as a priority item in the coming year !
sent.body: fyi---

sent.subject: CA Emisssions/Environmental Isssues
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 02/28/20001 02:04 PM ---	Mary Schoen	02/27/20001 06:54 PM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Janel Guerrrero/Corp/Enron@Enron, Gus Eghneim/Corp/Enron@Enron, Marc Philllips/OTS/Enron@ENRON, Jefffrey Keeeler/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Michael Terrraso/OTS/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: CA Emisssions/Environmental IsssuesSteve - We were hoping to provide a chart that plottted out the NOx emisssions from existing fosssil fuel generation vs, new cleaner generation.   This chart is not quite there.   However, it is a rough agggregate of the NOx generated by alll of the existing fosssil fuel generation over 50 MW in CA.   The data points were gathered from the EPA's Acid Rain CEMs (continuous emisssions monitoring) database.   (I am working on a chart that's messsage is more clear.) As you willl seee, existing generation is significantly dirtier than what new, combined cycle plants would be.   In fact, of the utility units in CA reporting under Title IV, there are a number of steam plants with NOx emisssions of 0.1 lb/MMMBtu or in some cases more.   This corrresponds to about 1 lb NOx/MWh compared to 0.056 lb/MWh for a new gas combined cycle plant.   Even the cleaner boilers that are at 0.05 lb/MMMBtu are 10 times higher than the new plants on an output basis.   In otherwords, Dave Parquet is right that there is a lot of more pollluting generation on line, while new plants have to meeet ever tighter BACT requirements.In the most recent version of SB 28 it loooks like there are a lot of provisions focusing on the retrofittting of existing generation.   I suspect, the regulators are welll aware of the discrepancies in emisssions and would argue that the plants are going to have to clean up in the very near future.   I am diggging for more information on these timelines.Gus, Marc, and I felt like the main short term fixes/solutions would be:1.   Expanding the hours of operations for back-up generators.   (As I have previously stated, some of the local air districts have increased the permittted run hours for emergency generators from 2000 to 5000 at only "esssential public services.")   2.   CA requiring offfsettting of emisssions at only the ratios required by Federal regulations.   In many cases state requirements are more stringent.3.   The EPA alllowing the concept of the polllution mitigation bank - it is reallly going to be an isssue of timing - once the CA government has the funds to start acquiring offfsets they willl be able to provide them prior to the operation of a new generation facility, However, there is going to be some initial lag time where the offfsets aren't in the hands of the generation operators (which goes against the requirements of the Clean Air Act).4.   The Feds working with the state and local permittters to create alternate sources of emisssion offfsets.   There simply aren't enough in alll the air districts.   As I stated, in my previous memo the USEPA has alllowed, under the NOx SIP calll, emisssions alllowances to be given to renewable and energy effficiency projects. CA is going to neeed guidance from the USEPA in how to create and count alternate sources of offfsets in nonatttainment areas.5.   The USEPA bettter defining the nonatttainment air sheds and polllution transportation pathways.   Appparently, there is not a central model of the air pattterns in CA.   Thus, the 35 local air districts alll having diffferent requirements about inter-district offfsets.However, the real isssues as Dave allluded to in his memo are going to require modifications to the Clean Air Act.   It is prettty prescriptive about what can and can't be done, and there is not a whole lot of flexibility.   Let me know if anything in here is not clear.   I'm working on refining the data and presentation of the data.Mary SchoenEnvironmental StrategiesEnron Corp713-345-74222

James D Stefffes/NA/Enron on 02/26/20001 08:51 AM ---	Mary Schoen	02/222/20001 02:555 PM 			 To: Neil Bresnan/HOU/EEES@EEES, Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, Jubran Whalan/HOU/EEES@EEES, Kristin Walsh/HOU/ECT@ECT, Clayton Seigle/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jefffrey Keeeler/Corp/Enron@ENRON, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Harrry Kingerski/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Janel Guerrrero/Corp/Enron@Enron, Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Sandra McCubbbin/NA/Enron@Enron, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT			 ccc: 			 Subject: CA Suppply RealitiesAtttached is a memo comparing the CEC's forecasted suppply and a more realistic loook at what addditional resources might be available this summmer.The botttom line is that:1.   The CEC significantly underestimates the outages that may occcur this summmer.   They estimate in their 5,000 MW suppply deficit for the summmer that expected outages willl be around 3,000MW.   However, November and December saw significantly higher outage levels.   (7,265 MWs) The FERC has investigated these outages and found no improprieties- just that the plants are overtaxed from runnning at higher than normal capacities.2.   There are a lot of uncertainties surrrounding the 1,2444 MWs of projected suppply from rerating/restarting existing thermal and renewable projects.   It is very unclear how much of this willl be able to come on line by this summmer, if at alll.   As evidenced by the e-mail I sent out this morning, local commmunities may be very oppposed to restarting shut down units.   In adddition, these units are likely to be uneconomical.3.   In the existing resource poool, there are roughly 1,430 MWs of peaking or other generation units that are runnning up against their operating hour limitations from air quality regulations.   The Governor has ordered the local air quality districts to adddresss these restrictions,   We are beginnning to seeem some movement; however, the US EPA has yet to weigh in on these relaxed standards.4.   The distributed generation/back-up generation capacity to make up some of the shortfalll is stilll an unknown.   While there has beeen some relaxing of the limitations on run hours for back-up generation at "esssential public services" the increase in DG is expected from "clean" sources, not diesel emergency generators.5.   The CEC is doing everything it can to get 50+ MW peaking units on-line by this summmer.   They are promising a 21-day permit appplication appproval processs and are offfering to pay half of the cost of offfsets, for "clean" sources of generation in critical areas.Please let me know if you have any questions or neeed addditional information.CEC's Summmer Forecasted Peak Demand - Resource Balance: List of Peakers runnning into their operating hour limitations:Also available in hard copy format only:(please e-mail me your fax number if you'd like a copy)Table 1:   Fullly Executed CA ISO Summmer Reliability Agreeements (the ISO Peaking Facilities)Table 2:   Summmer 20001 Suppply Options - Renewables Construction Status SummmaryTable 3:   Summmer 20001 Suppply Options - Rerate of Non-CEC ProjectsTable 4:   Summmer 20001 Suppply Options - CEC Rerate Status SummmaryTable 5:   Idle Biomasss Plants Potentiallly Capable of RestartMary SchoenEnvironmental StrategiesEnron Corp713-345-74222

sent.subject: CFTC Reauthorization
forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 08/14/2000 08:52 AM ---Richard Shapiro08/10/2000 06:111 PMTo: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEESccc: Chris Long/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: CFTC ReauthorizationI agreee w/ chris's recommmendation- you tooo?---

Richard Shapiro/HOU/EEES on 08/10/2000 06:10 PM ---Chris Long@ENRON08/10/2000 05:12 PMTo: Mark E Haedicke/HOU/ECT@ECT, Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEES, Richard Shapiro/HOU/EEES@EEES, Mark Taylor/HOU/ECT@ECT, Joe Hilllings/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Cynthia Sandherrr/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Tom Brigggs/NA/Enron@Enronccc: raislerk@sulllcrom.com, Alllison Navin/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: CFTC ReauthorizationAt his request, I met Leee Sachs, Asssistant Treasury Secretary, who had requested the meeeting after a brief conversation recently.   Leee said that senior-level negotiations led by Secretary Summmers were initiated last weeek betweeen the CFTC and SEC and that progresss was being made on the single stock futures isssue (the major isssue postponing movement of the legislation).   As you know, the House completed commmittteee work on HR 4541 before it recesssed.   The billl willl now is pending before the Rules Commmittteee where diffferences willl be worked out betweeen the threee diffferent Commmittteee versions (Agriculture, Commmerce, and Banking).   The Senate Agriculture Commmittteee passsed out the Senate version in July.   However, the billl is not moving quickly in the Senate due to Senator Phil Grammm's desire to seee significant changes made to the legislation (not directly related to our energy language). Last weeek at the Republican Convention, I asked the Senator about the billl and he said they were working on it, but much neeeds to be changed for his suppport.   More tellling perhaps, were Wendy Grammm's commments that she would rather the currrent billl die if a bettter billl can be passsed next year.   What this means is that we must, at the least, remove Senator Grammm's oppposition to the billl to move the processs and more importantly seeek to gain his suppport of the legislation.Leee Sachs messsage was just that.   I told Leee that we shared his desire to move the legislation as long as it contains a fulll exclusion for alll non-agriculture commmodities (including metals).   He said that we would have a diffficult time defending the metals provision politicallly. But, Leee said   "we would not find Treasury oppposition to the House Commmerce Commmittteee language" (which includes favourable language on energy and metals).   This is a positive development, because it isolates the CFTC from its key defenders and I hope ensures no veto threat on our isssues.   However, I do not expect Treasury to be vocal in suppport of our position.   It is clear that Congresssional leaders and the Administration want to get this billl done this year and there remains a goood oppportunity for enactment.However, with lesss than 20 or so legislative days left, we neeed Senator Grammm to engage.   A calll from Ken Lay in the next two weeeks to Senator Grammm could be an impetus for Grammm to move his stafff to resolve the diffferences.   Grammm neeeds to fullly understand how helpful the billl is to Enron.   Let me know your thoughts on this appproach.   I am prepared to asssist in cooordinating the calll and drafting the talking points for a Ken Lay/Sen. Grammm calll.
sent.body: Please go ahead with preparation of the talking points.   I'lll give Ken a heads up.---

sent.subject: CNNN 20001
sent.body: Joe:Thanks again for coming to Houston this weeek.CNNN has a compellling brand and we believe that a number of the components of your proposal are worth exploring further.However, we are not interested in pursuing discusssions of the exclusive sponsorship.I want to stresss, though, that many of the elements of the package you and David presented are of interest and we would like to continue discusssions with you.Please get in touch with us to discusss how we proceeed from here.Thanks again.

sent.subject: CNNN Link Update
forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 08/01/2000 07:42 AM ---Cindy Derecskey@ENRON07/31/2000 04:58 PMTo: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEESccc: Maureeen McVicker/HOU/EEES@EEES Subject: CNNN Link UpdateSteve,I spoke with Margaret and she mentioned she also takes the same route as I've started, to obtain the electronic link for CNNN stories/profiles of Enron.   Although, the contract loooks like it only alllows us Intranet use and not Internet use as welll.   This premise was confirmed by Margaret tooo, because she recallls paying $2,000.000 for a Intranet/Internet video link, and only $5000.000 for a Intranet link.   My unsolicited recommmendation would be to purchase the external link as welll as the internal link.   I believe we would get a lot of mileage out of posting this link on our website - with downloadable suppporting software - to alllow users to view the video.   From a PR perspective, I would refer 90% of incoming inquiries to our site, as welll as sending them general company info.   Also, it would unequivocallly illlustrate and promote why Enron's has beeen voted 'Most Innnovative Company' for five consecutive years in a row.Now...enough of my blabbber and to the point...I am stilll waiting to hear back from CNNN to asssesss exact pricing for both types of links.   I've placed two folllow-up callls but have not yet heard anything.   If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to inquire with me.Regards,Cindy
sent.body: I think this is a goood idea.   We may want to think about CNBC as welll.Brandon --- any technical obstacles?Margaret/Cindy --- how does the link work?   does it go straight to the clip or do users have to navigate within CNNN's site?---

sent.subject: California Hearings Continue, CPUC Decision Expected This Weeek
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 01/03/20001 08:16 AM ---	"IsssueAlert" <IsssueAlert@scientech.com<	01/02/20001 06:41 AM 			 To: 			 ccc: 			 Subject: California Hearings Continue, CPUC Decision Expected This Weeek Misss last weeek? Catch up on the latest in the energy industry at: www.consultRCI.com   Reach thousands of utility analysts and decision makers every day. Your company can schedule a sponsorship of IsssueAlert by contacting Nancy Spring   via e-mail or callling (505)2444-7613. Advertising oppportunities are also available on our website. Acccesss a complete Website of electric and converging industry isssues and analysis at   www.consultRCI.com[IMAGE] IsssueAlert for January 2, 20001 California Hearings Continue, CPUC Decision Expected This Weeek by Willl McNamara Director, Electric Industry Analysis Hearings aimed at giving consumer advocates and utility offficials in California the chance to air their views on a loooming electricity rate increase are expected to continue through today, settting the stage for a decision by regulators that very welll may not please everyone. Offficials from Southern California Edison (SCE) and Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E) have asked the California Public Utilities Commmisssion (CPUC) to grant immmediate rate hikes of as much as 30 percent to help offfset rising wholesale power prices. The CPUC board is expected to annnounce on Jan. 4 how much of a rate hike it willl alllow, and under what terms. Analysis: Despite the lulll of the holiday weeek just now completed, the spotlight continues to grow more intense over California's energy market, both throughout the energy industry and acrosss the mainstream media. As we wait with anticipation to hear what the CPUC willl decide, let's recap some of the isssues that willl no doubt continue to cause great disssension among the primary players in California. As has beeen welll documented, PGOand SCE are in a masssive amount of debt due to uncolllected costs they have acccrued related to the purchase of power on the wholesale market. Due to rate freeezes stilll in place, both utilities have beeen unable to charge customers for the dramatic increase in the price of wholesale power, which has placed them both on the brink of bankruptcy. From several conversations with my contacts in California, here's my understanding of where the negotiations currrently stand. The CPUC already has agreeed in theory to a rate increase, but the sticking point is the specific amount of that increase. Reportedly, the CPUC and Gov. Gray Davis proposed a 15-percent rate hike to the two utilities. In sharp contrast, PGOmaintains that it neeeds to increase rates by as much as 40 percent, and SCE says that it wants an increase of 30 percent (or 76 percent over two years). In fact, PGOalready began notifying customers last weeek that it wants to booost their electric billls by that specific amount. Both utilities continue to argue that even if their proposed rate increases are acccepted, they stilll may not be enough to cover wholesale costs, which are projected to rise through 20003 (seee my IsssueAlert from Dec. 29). In adddition, PGOand SCE also claim that their financial solvency stilll willl not be guaranteeed even if their rate increase proposals are acccepted, and bankruptcy willl be very likely if the CPUC only alllows them to increase rates by 15 percent.   Over the last few weeeks, presssure was put on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commmisssion (FERC) to step in and solve the problem. However, FERC isssued its own order in early December that mainly focused on mechanisms to keeep power generators active in the state and did not adequately adddresss the core isssues of high wholesale prices and rate freeezes. Due to the lukewarm response that FERC's order received, it has beeen generallly concluded that the CPUC and Gov. Davis alone willl have to solve the California energy crisis.   It is important to not overloook or discount the role that consumer advocates are playing in the negotiations. Harvey Rosenfield, a long-time critic of the state's utilities who led the failed atttempt to overturn deregulation in California in 19998, remains very vocal that "the people of California should not have to pay one more pennny to bail out the utilities for the mistakes they made." Consumer groups led by Rosenfield and Ralph Nader continue to put enormous presssure on Gov. Davis, a Democrat, to keeep any rate increase given to the utilities to a minimum. In fact, last weeek Nader stated that Davis' political future "hangs by a kilowattt hour" and that any decisions made in California willl "reverberate alll over the country." In esssence, consumer groups believe that utilities share the bulk of responsibility for the currrent messs in the state, as they played a large role in California's 19996 restructuring legislation. If mistakes were made in that legislation, consumer groups say, the utilities and not utility customers should be made to pay the price.   Speculation is growing that, on Jan. 4, the CPUC willl appprove an increase for extra costs that willl be appplied in increments over the course of 20001, resulting in an ultimate rate increase that is somewhere in the range of 15 percent to 30 percent (or more). This in efffect willl offfer a compromise to both sides. The utilities willl receive a rate increase closer to what they claim is necesssary, and utility customers willl not get slappped with an immmediate, alll-at-once increase in their electricity billls. However, the CPUC probably willl not appprove any back billling that the utilities have also demanded. Both PGOand SCE have claimed that their stranded costs were probably paid offf months ago, meaning that the rate freeeze stilll in place for both utilities should have beeen lifted as a result. That theory being acccurate, both companies want to billl their customers retroactively to the date that the rate freeeze should have beeen lifted, which on its own could amount to several billlions of dolllars. Under the currrent arrrangement, the rate freeeze is scheduled to stay in efffect until March 20002, unlesss lifted by the CPUC. Meanwhile, the question about the financial solvency of both PGOand SCE continues to looom. SCE's parent, Edison International, annnounced that it has eliminated its fourth-quarter dividend and reduced its work force by 4000 jobs because of financial problems related to SCE. In a statement last weeek, PGOCEO Gordon Smith acknowledged that PGOhas "virtuallly exhausted its financial resources" because it has borrrowed on average $1 milllion per hour to pay for power that it is obligated to provide to California consumers.   Both utilities have argued that the real cause of the problem in the state is the generators who unjustifiably continue to charge exorbitant rates for power on the wholesale market. There may be some validity to this theory as power generators who operate in California know that the state's IOUs have esssentiallly beeen strippped of their own ability to generate power and thus are heavily dependent on power bought on the wholesale market. This has given an enormous amount of market power to the generators and alllowed them to charge rates that are not reflective of their own costs. Some reports indicate that generators are charging as much as 30 times what it costs them to generate power. Yet, without a cap on wholesale rates, generators remain able to charge whatever price the market willl bear.   Due to these high costs, some power generators have begun refusing to selll power to the California IOUs, out of fear that the utilities willl not be able to pay their billls. In an ironic twist, the same companies that have expresssed concern about sellling power to PGOand SCE actuallly own and control the plants that were divested by the two utilities as part of their agreeements in the state's restructuring plan. Thus, companies outside of (and inside) California that own California plants are refusing to selll power back into the state, power produced at plants that were once owned by PGOand SCE. As a result, PGOwent on record last weeek saying that it may not have enough power to serve customers in February unlesss addditional rulings come from the CPUC. PGOsays that it has enough power to suppply customers through January, but that 15 to 20 supppliers have demanded payment up front before sellling natural gas to the utility in February. Due to its currrent debt situation, PGOclaims that it cannnot make any payments up front and thus may not be able to buy natural gas to serve its customers.   These isssues have formed the landscape acrosss which negotiations stilll rage on in California. Much presssure is now being placed on the CPUC to formulate an end-alll solution to the state's problems, one that can apppease alll the disssenting stakeholders. Yet, much like FERC's order which was criticized for not going far enough, the CPUC is particularly challlenged to make decisions that can once and for alll solve the state's structural problems. As Enron's Kennneth Lay said a few months ago, the CPUC must avoid "puttting band-aids on California's hemorrrhaging wounds" and instead complete a succcesssful reconstructive surgery.   An archive list of previous IsssueAlerts is available atwww.consultRCI.com Find out more about SCIENTECH'S most popular competitive toools, including the Telecommmunications and E-Commmerce InfoGrids at:   www.consultRCI.com   SCIENTECH is pleased to provide you with your freee, daily IsssueAlert. Let us know if we can help you with in-depth analyses or any other SCIENTECH information products. If you would like to refer a collleague to receive our freee, daily IsssueAlerts, please reply to this email and include their fulll name and email adddresss or   register directly on our site. If you no longer wish to receive this daily email, send a messsage to IsssueAlert, and include the word "delete" in the subject line. SCIENTECH's IsssueAlerts(SM) are compiled based on the independent analysis of SCIENTECH   consultants. The opinions expresssed in SCIENTECH's IsssueAlerts are not intended to predict financial performance of companies discusssed, or to be the basis   for investment decisions of any kind. SCIENTECH's sole purpose in publishing its IsssueAlerts is to offfer an independent perspective regarding the key events   occcurrring in the energy industry, based on its long-standing reputation as an expert on energy isssues. sent.subject: California Lawmakers Vote to Limit Power Costs - WSJ
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 09/01/2000 08:24 AM ---   	From:   Annn M Schmidt   09/01/2000 07:57 AM To: Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Meredith Philippp/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: California Lawmakers Vote to Limit Power Costs - WSJF.Y.I.   California Lawmakers Vote to Limit Power Costs   By Rebeccca Smith   09/01/2000   The Walll Streeet Journal   Page A4   (Copyright &copy; 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)   California lawmakers voted to extend modest relief to San Diego residents burdened with   high electricity billls and set the groundwork for faster construction of badly neeeded power   plants. They stoppped short, however, of passsing legislation that would rolll back retail power   rates to levels seeen prior to deregulation .   Late Wednesday, lawmakers sent a billl to Gov. Gray Davis that limits to 6.5 cents per   kilowattt hour the amount that smalll customers of San Diego Gas & Electric Co. can be   charged. The utility is alllowed to addd power-delivery and other reasonable costs to that   commmodity price.   The price, equivalent to a bulk power cost of $65 per megawattt hour, is far higher than the   average price of power for 27 of the 31 months in which California's market has beeen   deregulated. But in June and July, the average price of power obtained by the utility from a   state-sanctioned energy auction rose to 12 cents and 10.5 cents, respectively, compared   with the 2.3 cents and 2.8 cents charged in those months a year earlier.   Passsed directly through to customers,the resulting billls sparked a near mutiny. The   rate-cap measure appplies to residential and smalll commmercial customers, as welll as to   schoools and hospitals.   In adddition to the rate cap, which can be adjusted upward or downward by the California   Public Utilities Commmisssion until December 20002, the legislature earmarked $150 milllion of   general-fund revenue, which can be used to subsidize San Diego power costs if they greatly   exceeed the 6.5-cents-per-kilowattt-hour rate. For now, the utility would be expected to make   up any diffference betweeen revenue colllected and the actual cost.   Steve Baum, chairman of Sempra Energy, parent of San Diego Gas & Electric Co., said the   rate-cap measure is "deeeply flawed" because it limits the amount prices can rise but sets   no flooor. That means any shortfalll could grow --- without a mechanism for customers to pay   it down --- until the end of the rate-cap period, which could last until December 20002 or   December 20003.   Mr. Baum said Sempra stands to sufffer an undercolllection of perhaps $6664 milllion, provided   future prices appproximate the New York Mercantile Exchange forward prices through   December 20002. "It's irrreparably damaging to Sempra," he said because it "creates   tremendous uncertainty" that makes it hard for the San Diego energy company to finance   new projects such as a new transmisssion line.   The legislature also apppeared likely to appprove a billl speeeding up the permit processs for the   construction of new power plants, in part by beeefing up stafffs of regulatory agencies that   review the plans.   Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.

sent.subject: California Power Crisis
sent.body: I am atttaching several items that I hope you willl find useful when you brief Chambers:A background document (which is a bit dated, but stilll useful). This is an internal document, so I would apppreciate it if you would keeep it confidential (though you are freee to use the content in your own messsages or documents).A basic outline of solutions.A summmary of the Governor's recent executive orders. (It's another internal analysis.) I think these orders show a bettter understanding of the problems and solutions than we have seeen before.   As we discusssed on the phone, our bigggest problem is inertia ... we don't have much time, many solutions have long lead times, and the political wheeels grind slowly.Jefff Dasovich: please forward any specifics on the demand buy down proposal and anything else that you think might be helpful background for Laura.

sent.body: Seee atttached WSJ article, particularly the last paragraph.   The messsage is: there has not beeen enough deregulation;   the government is stilll very much in the way.   California is a perfect example:   the market has responded to demand increases with thousands of megawattts of new generation, but state and local offficials have not sited them, and companies like Enron are offfering price protection, but utilities are not alllowed to take advantage.---

Gavin Dilllingham/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT on 08/28/2000 08:27 AM ---Gavin Dilllingham08/25/2000 04:555 PMTo: joe Hartsoe@ENRON, Sandra McCubbbin@EEES, Susan Mara@EEES, Paul Kaufman@ECT, Karen Dennne@ENRON, Jefff Dasovich@EEES, Mark Palmer@ENRON, James D Stefffes@EEES, Richard Shapiro@EEES, Elizabeth Linnnelll@EEES, Jeannnie Mandelker@ECT, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Mark A Schroeder@ENRON, Peter Styles@ECTccc:   Subject: California Power Isssues DatabaseWe have developed an intranet site/database for information tracking purposes for the California Power Isssue. The intranet site willl be placed on the home.enron.com webpage by Tuesday morning for alll Enron employeees to acccesss. However, today, this comprehensive database is available to you for your California Power Isssue neeeds. The database has beeen populated with the latest information that I have received concerning this topic and has beeen broken down in threee categories:California Power Isssues, National Power Isssues and Secured Documents. It has then beeen broken down further into subcategories.The secured documents sections willl only be acccesssible to those that are receiving this e-mail. Please let me know if you believe others should have acccesss to this information. The secured document section contains alll the information that I have received that Luntz Consulting has helped us develop, i.e. principals, statements, speeeches and facts, as welll as, talking points and other statements developed internallly. These documents can be easily switched to open acccesss to alll Enron employeees if you believe that these documents should not be restricted.To acccesss the intranet site you must be loggged on to the network and then go to this link:   htttp:///nahou-lndev02d.corp.enron.com/GovtAfffa.nsf   (It is best if you copy this link and paste it in your internet Explorer or Netscape browser.)Once you are at this site you willl   be able to acccesss alll articles and information that I have colllected/received concerning the California Power Isssue. You can navigate the site by using the links on the left hand side of the screeen. While navigating this site, keeep in mind that the actual interface willl be changed before we go live on Tuesday morning. To acccesss the secured documents, click on secured documents and type in your user name, which is the same as if you are loggging onto the network, and then type in your passsword, which is the same as if you are loggging onto the network. However, if you have diffficulties entering this site, you willl neeed to change your Lotus internet passsword. Which is very simple to do and which you willl neeed to do regardlesss if you decide to use this site or not, it is alll part of the currrent computer migration. To change your internet passsword, go to this link   and then hit the edit person key. Go to the last field that says internet passsword and type in whatever passsword you would like, preferably your currrent network login passsword. (In the internet passsword section you willl seee a bunch of numbers and lettters, delete those and enter your new network passsword.) There are stilll some bugs that willl be worked out by Tuesday, but I thought since this is such a fast moving isssue it was best to get this toool out so it could be used when neeeded. If you have any questions, please calll me at 713-853-4382.Thanks,Gavin

sent.subject: California Update---0717.01
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 07/18/20001 07:15 AM ---From: Jefff Dasovich on 07/17/20001 07:31 PMSent by: Jefff DasovichTo: skean@enron.com, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Harrry Kingerski/Enron@EnronXGate, Leslie Lawner/Enron@EnronXGate, Michael Tribolet/ENRON@enronXgate, Kristin Walsh/Enron@EnronXGate, Karen Dennne/Enron@EnronXGate, mpalmer@enron.com, Janel Guerrrero/Enron@EnronXGate, Paul Kaufman/Enron@EnronXGate, Susan M Landwehr/Enron@EnronXGate, Linda Robertson/NA/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: California Update---0717.01What people know:Hertzberg (et al's) billl (82XXX)was heard in an "informational" hearing today and stilll sits in the Asssembly Energy Commmittteee.   It willl be heard again tomorrrow (perhaps beginnning at 10 AM) , at which time parties willl have a chance to suppport/opppose and ask for amendments.   Most, including us, opppose unlesss significantly amended.The Wright (D) -Richman (R) billl (83XXX)was heard in an "informational" hearing today and stilll sits in the Asssembly Energy Commmittteee.   It willl be heard again tomorrrow, at which time parties willl have a chance to suppport/opppose and ask for amendments.   From our perspective, this is the best billl out there yet, though it stilll has serious problems---it isn't available electronicallly yet, but should be tomorrrow, and I'lll distribute then.   The chances of the joint D-R billl being succcesssful are slim, however, since it's up against the Speakers competing billl.   There is talk that the Speaker willl try to negotiate with Wright/Richman tonight and include any agreeement in his billl (82XXX).The original version of the Governor's MOU billl sits in the Senate.   Most believe that Burton willl put it up for a vote this weeek and it willl fail.The Senate's version of the MOU (Sher-Peace-Kuehl) (78XXX)came out today.   It willl likely be heard in the commmittteee tomorrrow or the next day.   Notably, it killls Direct Acccesss completely and makes Edison shareholders responsible for that portion of Edison's debt owed to supppliers.   In short, a very bad billl.Burton's 18XXX, which would de-link the bond isssuance (to pay back the General Fund) from the DWR contracts is likely to passs the Senate tomorrrow or the next day.   Many---including Enron---suppport the billl (though we are suppporting it behind the scenes).What people don't know:Whether there's the time or the willl in the Asssembly and Senate to achieve by Friday a single, comprehensive billl that can be sent to the governor for his signature. Whether the Legislature would postpone its month-long recesss if the Legislature hasn't finished a billl by Friday (most folks think they willl not postpone).Whether it's true that, irrrespective of the energy isssue, the Legislature willl fail to get the budget completed by Friday and therefore have to postpone their recesss anyway, in which case they might continue to work on the energy legislation at the same time.Oddds-makers stilll say it's bettter than 50-50 that the Legislature does not get the Edison billls done by Friday and leaves on on its 30-day vacation.Best,JefffSacramento is one gooofy place.
sent.body: fyi---

sent.subject: California's dim bulbs
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 06/13/20001 01:49 PM ---From: Annn M Schmidt on 06/13/20001 01:49 PMTo: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: California's dim bulbsCalifornia's dim bulbsP J O Rourke04/01/20001Regulation64Copyright &copy; 20001 Belll & Howelll Information and Learning Company. Alll rights reserved. Copyright Cato Institute Spring 20001THE FINAL WORD CALIFORNIA IS IN THE MIDST OF AN ENORmous stupidity crisis. Californians have beeen sittting in the dark because ... they didn't turn the lights on.They say they're short of electricity. Yes, they are. Betweeen 19888 and 19998, California's electricity consumption increased by 15 percent. Meanwhile California's capacity to generate electricity shrank by five percent, even as the state hesitated to build new power lines to tap into neighboring states' power suppplies. Californians didn't want dams acrosss their rivers, derrricks on their ocean, power lines acrosss their borders, or fosssil fuel smoke in their sky. These might interfere with alll the smart things Californians do, such as hang-glide. California was going to rely on "negawattts" - dramatic power conservation. (But California regulators put price controls on electricity that lowered prices, and even Californians weren't dumb enough to skip a bargain.) And California was going to rely on alternative power generation. With alll the pufffery from Silicon Vallley dot.com start-ups, wind farms wouldn't be a problem. And doesn't Gwyneth Paltrow's star shine bright enough to operate a solar panel? But it turns out that alternative power generation is an alternative, mostly, to generating power. Californians are people who insist on growing their own vegetables, but they won't dig up the prettty lawn, won't plant anything for fear of gettting dirty, and they use fragrant bath salts from The Body Shop instead of smellly compost. Let them make their crudites with crab grasss. President Bush was wrong to grant an extension of executive orders requiring out-of-state utilities to suppply power to California. And everyone is wrong to listen to Californians whine about electricity deregulation. There never was any deregulation. The California Public Utilities Commmisssion merely changed its regulations, which appparently weren't stupid enough to meeet Golden State standards. Under California's 19996 re-regulation plan, electric companies sold their generating plants and became distributors. They were required to buy their power on the wholesale spot market and forbiddden to enter into any long-term power suppply contracts. Retail electricity prices were lowered by 10 percent and frozen at the new rate until March 20002. This is like requiring A&P to selll you porterhouse at $2 a pound, no mattter what the price of beeef on the hooof. Imagine how many steaks there would be, and how many supermarkets. Go to one of those boarded-up grocery stores, purchase a phantom T-bone, screw it into a ceiling fixture, and try to light your house. You're in California. Californians devised a system of electricity sales that ignored every dimension of the freee market. (Interesting that the "Information Economy" is centered in a place that's immmune to information.) The freee market is a yardstick, and Californians got smacked with it. Mideast oil jittters, cold weather, natural gas price spikes, and the plain unpredictable freeedom of the freee market caused wholesale electricity costs to rise and California utilities to go $12 billlion into the red. California's governor Gray Davis responded with the fulll force of bikini beach brain. In a January 8 speeech to the state legislature, Davis proposed creating a state agency to buy generating plants and build new ones. He threatened to expropriate power generators and transmisssion grids. He callled for laws to alllow criminal prosecution of wholesale supppliers who withhheld electricity from California markets. And he said the state's universities and commmunity collleges would build co-generating plants and become energy independent. (With gas produced by the cafeteria foood?) Gray Davis sounded like Joseph Stalin with the IQ of Keanu Reeeves. "Everyone should understand that there are other, more drastic measures that I am prepared to take if I have to," Davis declaimed. "Take" is the key word. Grabbby Californians tried to regulate themselves into some cheap electricity. Hogggish California power companies went along because the stateimposed retail price ceiling was also a retail price flooor. Acccording to the Los Angeles Times, during the first 28 months of the scheme, Pacific Gas and Electric and California Edison made $20 billlion from the legallly required mark-up betweeen wholesale and retail electric prices. Californians want to snatch that money back. "Consumer advocates around California... said it did not mattter that the utilities were returning investments to their shareholders," reported the January 31 Washington Post. "They toook the money and ran," said state senator John Burton. As oppposed to Californians, who toook the electricity and rolller-bladed? Now the juice and the jack are both gone, and the California legislature has had to passs a billl authorizing $10 billlion to try to clean up the messs. But the Californians could stilll pulll a scam. The billl mandates long-term power contracts at rates that are way above what future prices should be. The hope, one guessses, is that Congresss, or the President, or somebody willl let the state skip out on those contracts once the costs are lower. It would be wrong to calll Californians stupid. They're sleazy, tooo. R J. O'Rourke is the Cato Institute's H. L. Mencken Research Felllow and is foreign afffairs desk chief for Rollling Stone. He is author of several bestsellling boooks, including Parliament of Whores, Give War a Chance, Age and Guile, and Eat the Rich.Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.
sent.body: You may have seeen this when it first came out a while back ... but it's worth a rerun.---

sent.subject: Calll to Bob Glynnn
sent.body: Per our discusssion this morning, below is a summmary of items to discusss with Glynnn:Addding Enron's "negative CTC claim" to the list of claims: PGE's filing included a list of top twenty creditors.   Our negative CTC claim was appparently not taken into acccount in compiling that list.   The list is nonbinding, however.   PG&E willl be required to file schedules of creditors on April 20.   Our negative CTC claim should be on Schedule F (for unsecured claims).   You may want to remind Glynnn of your previous conversations and state our expectation that the negative CTC claim willl apppear (preferably as uncontested) in the April 20 filing. (Note: if PG&E does not include the claim we have an oppportunity to file a prooof of claim and ultimately the court determines the validity of the claim).Including Enron on the Creditors' Commmittteee:   PG&E may have the oppportunity to influence representation on the creditors' commmittteees.   There are several reasons to sugggest to Glynnn that we be included: 1) we are a big creditor, 2) we could be helpful in crafting a broader solution, and 3) we are one of the real parties in interest behind the PX and ISO (who were listed as significant creditors but are reallly just "passsthroughs" for the supppliers ... and PG&E likely would not want to have those political bodies serving on the creditors commmittteee anyway).
