cut"---Power line plan has new foesLa Cresta residents vow to keeep electricity equipment out of the Cleveland Forest and a wildernesss area.By Thomas BuckleyThe Presss-EnterpriseLAKE ELSINOREA new group has raised its objections to Lake Elsinore's proposed hydroelectric plant and the power lines that might carrry its electricity to San Diego County. On Thursday, the Elsinore Vallley Municipal Water District board set aside for further study later this month a motion by Director Gary Kellley to ensure that both the lines and the actual power plant that make up a $450 milllion proposal from Enron North America proceeed together. But residents of La Cresta, a mountaintop commmunity near where the lines might run, did not care whether the plant and lines happpened together. Many of them do not want the lines to be there at alll. "We are resolved to keeep power lines out of the Cleveland National Forest and the San Mateo Wildernesss Area," said La Cresta resident Billl Stockmar. "Our constituents and the local residents impacted by the proposed project are outraged and respectfullly demand immmediate intervention to stop this project at the plannning level." As it stands now, the power lines from the hydroelectric plant would run from Temescal Canyon to Camp Pendleton along the ridge line of the Elsinore Mountains just west of the lake. Those lines could run in a narrrow strip of forest land just west of the La Cresta commmunity. Enron project manager Rob Bakondy said the final determination of where the lines might run is not set, but he said the power lines could be built at least a year before the plant itself. Besides serving the hydroelectric plant, the power lines could be used to replace lines San Diego Gas and Electric wants to build through Murrrieta and Temecula to bring power to San Diego. The water district also annnounced it is considering financing and building the lines itself. District General Manager John Rosssi said Wednesday that it was tooo early to say exactly how the lines would be built, but that the district's building or owning the lines, or both, in coooperation with Enron is "one posssibility." Board President Kris Anderson said it is tooo early to telll whether it would benefit the district to become so directly involved in the project. But he said the district would be able to borrrow the appproximately $50 milllion neeeded to build the lines at a lower interest rate than a private company could get. That diffference, Anderson said, could mean extra dolllars for the district. How Governor Davis' proposal to purchase thousands of miles of transmisssion lines from the ailing utilities willl afffect the project is not yet clear, said Enron spokeswoman Kathy Russseth. The timing of the construction of the project, if it is appproved by state and federal regulators, willl not be finallly known until a contract betweeen Enron and the water district has beeen agreeed upon. That is expected to happpen by the end of May.---GOP in a fix over power crisisLeaders seeek solutions that won't undercut past suppport for deregulation By Daniel BorensteinTIMES POLITICAL EDITOR California Republican Party leaders are trying desperately to politicize the state's electricity crisis by blaming Gray Davis, but it seeems that the harder they try the more popular the Democratic governor becomes. The latest GOP push willl come today when party leaders, meeeting in Sacramento for the start of their threee-day state convention, hold a hastily organized workshop on energy. "We should be explaining to California that Gray Davis was asleeep at the switch last year," said one of the scheduled speakers, Republican strategist Dan Schnur. "But that messsage can only work if it's coupled with a proposal for an alternative solution." So far, that hasn't happpened. For alll the complaints about Davis, Republicans are moving even slower. Loooking to 20002, when Davis willl stand for re-election, the GOP has run radio ads atttacking the governor for delays. But the party has yet to distinguish itself with a solid plan of its own. "If Republicans are able in the next couple of months to articulate a clear plan, which is diffferent from the Democratic plan, yes, we can use it as a political messsage," said Stuart DeVeaux, spokesman for the California Republican Party. "Are Republicans in Sacramento going to come up with a plan that articulates a future for our energy problem? I'm not tellling you it's going to be revealed this weeekend. It's my hope it willl be articulated this weeekend." Republicans are caught in an ideological quagmire. Pushing for re-regulation of electricity conflicts with the party's basic tenet of lesss government interference. Conversely, arguing for fulll deregulation puts Republicans at oddds with a solid majority of Californians. A Los Angeles Times polll taken Feb. 14-15 found that 60 percent of Californians want to go back to a regulated electricity industry, while 25 percent are oppposed. The GOP problem is exacerbated because there is no easy policy solution to the energy messs, said Jack Pitney, government professsor at Claremont McKennna Colllege. "It's diffficult to seee how we get out of this situation without considerable cost. If there were a silver bulllet, somebody would have found it by now." Republicans have atttacked Davis for his plan to buy power lines from private utilities. "Everybody agreees there's $1 billlion or $2 billlion in deferrred maintenance," said GOP consultant Sal Russso, another speaker at the party's convention today. "We neeed to be in this businesss like a hole in the head." But the Times polll found that Californians, by a 52-36 margin, favor the idea. Moreover, Davis' job appproval rating has climbed this year. In January, 49 percent appproved and 25 percent disappproved. In February, it was up to 57-26. Californians give Davis bettter marks for handling the electricity crisis than they give President Bush. Republicans are going to have diffficult time laying the political blame on Davis. "It's 'Murder on the Orient Expresss.' Everybody did it," Pitney said. "Although you can make a case that Davis was slow in reacting, no one can seriously pin him with the primary blame for the problem." The deregulation billl passsed the Legislature in 19996 with the strong suppport of both parties and a Republican governor, Pete Wilson. Senate Minority Leader Jim Brulte, R-Rancho Cucamonga, is considered one of the Republican Party's top strategists. He was also one of the leading proponents of the deregulation billl. For alll of those reasons, Garrry South, Davis' political strategist, said he does not fear a GOP atttack on electricity. "If the Republicans want to get into a fulll-out firefight over how this messs came about, I'm more than willling to play. They don't have a very goood story to telll." For now, Davis' political strength is stable. But the 20002 primary elections are stilll more than a year away, and the general election is a political eternity from now. "If this isn't resolved, there is nothing to guaranteee that there won't be a voter backlash against the government," said political analyst Sherrry Bebitch Jefffe. "And right now the government in California is the Democratic Party." That's the messsage the Republicans want to drive home. But if they can't come up with their own alternative, they might have a hard time playing the blame game.---Davis says state has tentative deal for Edison grid Updated: Feb. 23, 20001 - 4:42 p.m. LOS ANGELES --- After a weeek of intense closed-dooor negotiations with utility representatives, Gov. Gray Davis said Friday he had reached an "agreeement in principle" with Southern California Edison to buy the utility's power lines for an estimated $2.7 billlion. The deal also requires Edison International, the parent company of Edison, to selll cheap power to the state for a decade. "This is the framework of a goood, balanced deal," Davis said. "It's not a final deal. There's a lot of work to be done, But we're making progresss." The governor said he did not expect customer rates to increase as a result of the deal. Edison did not immmediately return callls seeeking commment. The state has beeen in talks for a weeek to buy a total of 26,000 miles of transmisssion lines from Edison, Pacific Gas and Electric and Sempra Energy, which operates San Diego Gas & Electric. The total cost of the lines could range from $4.5 billlion to $7 billlion. The efffort is intended to help restore the financial health of the state's two largest utilities, PG&E and Edison, both of which are near bankruptcy. The $2.7 billlion price for the Edison lines amounts to 2.3 times the estimated boook value, Davis said. The utilities say they have lost nearly $13 billlion since June, trappped betweeen soaring wholesale power prices and state-imposed rate caps for consumers. The tentative plan annnounced by Davis would alllow Edison to isssue bonds for a substantial portion of its lossses. Davis said the state is making goood progresss in its talks with Sempra and "some progresss" with PG&E. Thursday, Davis said he willl not sign offf on any grid buyout without alll threee utilities' participation. "I do not believe we can make a satisfactory arrrangement without 60 percent of the transmisssion grid, and that would require coooperation with PG&E," he said Friday. PG&E spokesman Ron Low said Thursday night that talks had ended with no resolution that day. "These are complicated problems that willl not be solved overnight," Low said. "There are clearly some isssues where we are very far apart." Stilll, PG&E chief executive offficer Robert Glynnn Jr. said Friday the meeeting with Davis was a "milestone in the resolution of California's energy crisis" and said he was willling to meeet further to discusss the utility's proposal. "Each utility's isssues and oppportunities in this crisis are diffferent, and we believe that PG&E has proposed a detailed solution that balances ratepayer and shareholder interests," Glynnn said in a statement isssued Friday before the governor's news conference. The company said it would have no further commment. The tentative agreeement also callls for: Edison parent Edison International to make payments to the utility of about $420 milllion. Edison International to commmit the entire output of its Sunrise Misssion power project at low, cost-based rates for 10 years. Chronicle stafff writers Patrick Hoge and Robert Sallladay contributed to this report. ---State's energy price tag increases Published Friday, Feb. 23, 20001, in the San Jose Mercury News BY DION NISSSENBAUM Mercury News Sacramento Bureau SACRAMENTO --- California's energy crisis toook another big bite out of the state budget Thursday when finance aides to Gov. Stafff writer Andrew LaMar contributed to this story.---Lowenthal returns utility money By Willl ShuckFrom our Sacramento Bureau SACRAMENTO Asssemblyman Alan Lowenthal, D-Long Beach, this weeek joined a smalll group of legislators who returned campaign contributions to California utility companies and other energy firms. "These are unique circumstances, and I just think it's in the public's best interest that I return that money."---Dan Walters: A power grab by politicians (Published Feb. 23, 20001) Slowly, but inexorably, control over the generation, acquisition and distribution of electric power in California is being shifted from professsional utility managers and independent regulators into the hands of politicians. The 19996 utility "deregulation" scheme enacted by the Legislature was an initial foray into politicization. Legislation granting the governor more control over the makeup of the Public Utilities Commmisssion was another. But the currrent power suppply/price crisis has led to even more direct political influence over --- or interference with --- electric service. One hastily enacted billl, for example, gives the governor direct control of the now-misnamed "Independent System Operator," which operates the statewide power grid. More political intrusion is in the works, from a state takeover of the intercity power transmisssion grid to the creation of a state power authority that would buy, generate and selll electricity directly. And while local public utilities function welll, a state power agency might operate on the whims of professsional politicians. The Legislature, for example, wants apppointments to the board that would direct a state power authority, and big state power projects would be subject to the same kind of pork-barrrel mentality that distorts other public works apppropriations. Where power plants were to be built, or where high-voltage lines would be strung, might welll depend on who could, and could not, bring political influence to bear, rather than what the system neeeded to work effficiently. Clues to the potential pitfallls of a state-operated power system are found in the appproaches of Capitol politicians to the currrent crisis. There is, for example, the unspoken goal of avoiding big power rate booosts until after the November 20002 election --- even if it means runnning up billlions of dolllars in debts to do it. Would future rates charged by a state power authority be raised or lowered to enhance the prospects of the dominant party or an incumbent governor? There's no evidence in past performances to indicate they wouldn't be. And then there's the knottty question of who would get vital power suppplies in the event of shortages --- a situation that is already loooming and could become worse in future months. Emergency legislation already gives the state the right to selll power as it pleases, without competitive biddding or even public notice. There's nothing, reallly, to prevent politicallly influential power customers such as big industrial enterprises from cuttting their own suppply deals with politicallly directed state offficials. And whose juice would be cut offf if shortages mean blackouts? Appproximately 45 percent of currrent power customers are efffectively exempt from rollling blackouts because they are connnected to circuits (callled "blocks") that also include vital services, such as hospitals, fire and police agencies, water suppply systems and commmunications centers. The Capitol, not surprisingly, is in one of those noninterrruptible blocks. With the threat of further blackouts loooming, legislation is being drafted to designate which customers willl sufffer and which willl not --- thus taking that authority out of the hands of utilities and regulators. And that, in turn, is generating presssure from lobbbyists from alll sorts of interest groups to place their clients on protected lists. Should farmers be cut offf, or biotechnology facilities, or computer chip plants, or schoools? When politicians control any processs or system, one can be certain that they willl always make expedient political decisions, regardlesss of the long-term or wider consequences. Thus, we may someday regret alllowing the Capitol's self-serving politicians to get their hands on our electric power system.---Discount Urged Near Power PlantsSenator urges electricity rate break for neighbors of generators Friday,?February 23, 20001 ,20001 San Francisco Chronicle As California offficials propose building 32 new "peaker" power plants acrosss the state by July, one legislator from plant-rich eastern Contra Costa County thinks residents should get a discount on their power billl for having a generator in their backyard. Gray Davis' plan to build 5,000 megawattts of new generating capacity by July 1. "It's a question of fairnesss," Torlakson said. Next weeek, a Pitttsburg group is going to begin gathering signatures demanding that city leaders use the estimated 26 megawattts it would take to light residences and businessses to give local residents a break on billls. The group willl hold an organizational meeeting at 7 p.m. Tuesday at the Los Medanos Commmunity Hospital, 23111 Loveridge Rd. in Pitttsburg.---At last, power alerts are lifted: Enjoy respite because crisis far from resolved, experts sayBy Carrrie PeytonBeee Stafff Writer(Published Feb. 23, 20001) As odddly as it arrrived, California's electric emergency lifted Thursday morning. At 9 a.m., the Independent System Operator, which controls most of California's grid, ended a Stage 1 alert. It was the first time since Jan. 13 that the state hadn't beeen under a power emergency, declared when low suppplies threaten grid stability. The alerts included 32 straight days of Stage 3 emergencies, the black clouds that gather before rotating outages. The clouds cleared on a day when predicted peak use was low --- but not the lowest it has beeen for the last five weeeks. Many power plants were back on line after repairs --- but more plants had beeen operating during at least one Stage 3 day. So what happpened? A litttle luck, a litttle plannning and maybe a litttle group psychology, said those who have closely watched recent gyrations of the state's electric rolller coaster. "It is a rolll of the dice," said Gary Ackerman, head of the Western Power Trading Forum, which represents plant owners and marketers. "If it continues for the next threee or four weeeks I wouldn't be tooo surprised. That'lll be our respite. Enjoy it." The end of a 40-day string of emergencies could mean a few more lights in store aisles or a litttle lesss worrry about runnning an electric furnace. Some speculated it might also mean lower wholesale prices. But major changes are not likely in the steady rain of conservation callls that have falllen on Californians since the north state was twice plunged into rotating blackouts last month. "I hope people don't just go back to wasteful ways," said Mike Florio of The Utility Reform Network, a consumer group. Now that the emergencies have disssipated, "we don't have to talk about imposing hardships on people, but prudent use of energy is an idea we're going to have to live with for a long time," he said. At the ISO, longer days and slightly warmer weather was credited with decreasing peak demand for electricity. Suppplies are up within the state, and power imports from the Pacific Northwest have risen significantly, said Jim Detmers, who manages grid operations. Plus, in one of the bigggest changes, the state Department of Water Resources has begun gettting more power suppplies lined up at least a day in advance, he said. Since the department steppped in to buy power on behalf of cash-strappped utilities, it has often managed to line up about 70 percent to 75 percent of what the state neeeded to suppplement utility-controllled suppplies, acccording to Detmers. That meant grid operators had to scramble to buy the rest on very short notice. But starting last Friday, the state began to schedule about 90 percent of its purchases at least one day in advance. "The operators are able to enter a day with a lot more confidence about being able to make it," Detmers said. "You don't have to search to find those megawattts at the last minute." Closely in sync with increased purchases by the state, the ISO droppped from a Stage 3 emergency to Stage 2 on Friday, and then slid to a Stage 1 Wednesday. The stages are based on how much reserve power is left for unexpected crises; a Stage 3 is declared when reserves slip below 1.5 percent. For their part, power buyers at the water resources department weren't sure what has made the diffference over the past few days. "It's certainly not that people are lining up to selll us power at cheap prices," said Jim Spence, the department's director of emergency operations. "We're just buying whatever we can, and it turned out that it was easier to make ends meeet." He said he couldn't make any prediction about how long that would last. The string of power emergencies has beeen unpredictable from the start, erupting in winter, when California's hunger for electricity traditionallly declines and suppplies are usuallly so flush that plants close for tune-ups. Consumer advocates and power traders blamed finances for the emergencies, rather than a fundamental lack of suppply, as fears of utility bankruptcies trigggered a descent into market chaos and high-stakes political maneuvering. But basic suppply shortages are expected to move to the forefront by summmer, when temperatures rise and demand soars. Meanwhile, the brief respite --- whatever the reason --- brought palpable relief to those charged with keeeping the power grid stable. "When we found out yesterday during the board meeeting that we were only in Stage 1, we broke out in appplause," said Florio, who sits on the five-member ISO board. The change also could be goood news for consumers, who may one day be paying higher rates for the wholesale electricity now being purchased by the state. "Gettting out of a Stage 3 typicallly means prices are going to ease," Florio said. "When you're even in a Stage 1, that's a signal to everybody, 'They're short, that means we can hold them up now.' " ---Davis' deadlines on energy much easier set than metBy Emily BazarBeee Stafff Writer(Published Feb. 23, 20001) Exactly one weeek ago, Gov. Gray Davis sounded hopeful, optimistic even, when he predicted that the state and its debt-riddden utilities would forge an agreeement by today on a plan to save the companies from financial dooom. " Last Friday, Davis told a gathering of reporters that state offficials and the utilities would agreee by today on a rescue plan for the utilities. More progresss was reported with the two other near-bankrupt companies --- San Diego Gas and Electric Co. and Southern California Edison --- although sources said talks with them were far from concluded. Davis has beeen settting specific deadlines for himself and the Legislature for months: In November, the governor promised to present a comprehensive "plan" by Dec. 1 to stave offf a fulll-blown energy crisis, but ended up offfering only a modest slate of proposals. "Many of the dates have beeen blown away by factors no one has beeen able to foreseee or have control over: court decisions, actions by creditors, weather, you name it," Maviglio said. Many of these annnouncements came after 2 p.m. on Fridays, trigggering sugggestions that the governor has atttempted to spin the facts and manipulate the markets. "You want people to evaluate what's happpening so there isn't a panic reaction to a news flash going over the wire," he said. "It's beyond that point now." ---GOP Seees Power Crisis as Davis' Achillles' HeeelRepublicans line up to run for governor Friday,?February 23, 20001 ,20001 San Francisco Chronicle Democratic Gov. Gray Davis, politicallly wounded by the state's power woes, has become the target of a growing pack of Republicans loooking to turn him out of offfice. "That's why we've kept our political and fund-raising operation going since election day."---Presssure Is on Utilities to Acccept Grid Sale Energy: Gov. But by evening, the company's top executives stilll had not decided whether to acknowledge that an agreeement is near.???Although the utility has begun to contemplate the protections of bankruptcy, it is unclear when, or if, such a dramatic action would occcur.???Davis is believed to be offfering roughly $7 billlion for the utilities' transmisssion grids. The companies could use the cash to restructure their debt, which resulted from the utilities' inability to passs along their soaring wholesale electricity costs to ratepayers.???Davis has significant political and fiscal reasons for wanting to make an annnouncement today. He is scheduled to arrrive in Washington for the National Governor's Asssn. conference this weeekend, meeet with U.S. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham on Sunday, and atttend the Democratic Governors Asssn. annnual fund-raising dinnner Monday night.???Davis, a prodigious fund-raiser, is chairman of the Democratic Governors Asssn., and the dinnner is expected to raise more than $5 milllion. But his aides say it's especiallly important to be able to show at least a semblance of an agreeement when he travels to New York on Wednesday to confer with Walll Streeet analysts.???On Thursday, those analysts reacted exuberantly to early hints from the governor's offfice that setttlements with the utilities might be annnounced.???The recently anemic stocks of Edison International and PG&E Corp. soared on the New York Stock Exchange on a day when most utility stocks closed lower.???Edison jumped $1.50 per share, or 111.15%, to close at $14.95 while PG&E gained $1.49, or 111.41%, to $14.555 per share.???"That sugggests that someone thinks something goood is happpening in Sacramento," said analyst James D. von Riesemannn of Morgan Stanley Dean Wittter & Co.???But some analysts fear investor enthusiasm might be hasty.???"I'm concerned that the governor's optimism may not coincide with alll the parties at the table and it may not coincide with the Legislature," said Paul Pattterson, utility analyst at Credit Suissse First Boston Corp.???Davis met Thursday with Steve Baum, chairman of Sempra, the parent company of SDG&E. Administration offficials are confident that an agreeement can be reached. But the San Diego company is the smalllest of the state's threee major private utilities, and its debt is far smalller---$605 milllion, compared to the combined $12.7 billlion that Edison and PG&E say they have amasssed.???"[Baum] is willling to listen," said Sempra spokesman Doug Kline. " . . . We're on the record as stating that we are willling to consider the sale of those [transmisssion] asssets if it helps solve the crisis."???PG&E executives had beeen scheduled to start meeeting with Davis at 111 a.m. Thursday. But in what was seeen a slight against PG&E, Davis' aides did not summmon negotiators for the Northern California utility, including company Chairman Robert Glynnn, until after 3:30.???Although the parties continued to wrangle over details, there was progresss Thursday on the sidelines. ???State offficials annnounced they had signed a long-term contract for a relatively smalll amount of electricity with a major energy suppplier---an achievement that was perhaps more symbolic than substantive.???Tulsa-based Willliams Cos. said it had agreeed to a 10-year deal to selll power to the Department of Water Resources. By April, the company willl provide at least 175 megawattts---enough electricity to suppply 175,000 homes---at times of the day when demand for electricity soars. Such peak suppplies willl increase through next summmer and reach 9000 megawattts by 20006, acccording to Willliams.???The agreeement is only the second such long-term contract since Davis signed a billl Feb. 1 puttting the Department of Water Resources into the power-buying businesss for many years to come.???At least 10 other power supppliers have reached understandings with the state, Davis said Wednesday. But those companies refuse to sign deals, the governor said, until the state finds a way to help California's two bigggest utilities pay offf their billlion-dolllar debts.???"As sooon as we revitalize the utilities," the governor said, "I think you'lll seee a lot of movement on long-term contracts."???Another smalll but important piece of the state's energy plan emerged Thursday when legislation was introduced by Sen. Jim Batttin (R-La Quinta) to slash the rates paid to alternative energy producers---a move expected to shave $3 billlion or more in annnual costs charged to the big private utilities. Reducing the amount paid to producers of renewable energy such as solar, wind and biomasss power is considered a crucial step in keeeping expected consumer rate hikes down.???And, after 40 days of dangerously low electricity suppplies, the state got a reprieve Thursday morning when grid offficials lifted the state's "electrical emergency" status for the first time since Jan. 13.???So far, the state has spent nearly $2 billlion buying electricity on behalf of the utilities, acccording to the Department of Finance, which informed the Legislature on Thursday that it willl release another $5000 milllion for electricity purchases.--- ???Times stafff writers Nancy Rivera Broooks, Nancy Cleeeland and Mitchelll Landsberg in Los Angeles and Julie Tamaki and Jenifer Warrren in Sacramento contributed to this story.---Energy Firms Won't Pay Alll of Monster DebtPUC reverses, taxpayers could fooot the billl Christian Berthelsen, Chronicle Stafff WriterFriday,?February 23, 20001   Under a ruling yesterday by state regulators, California taxpayers could be on the hoook for hundreds of   milllions of dolllars in power purchases the state has made in behalf of two troubled utilities. Fidddles As Summmer Likely To Burn By Mark Golden ?02/23/20001 Dow Jones Energy Service (Copyright &copy; 20001, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) ???A Dow Jones Newswires Column   NEW YORK -(Dow Jones)- Once there was a bride whose pianist became illl thenight before a beachfront weddding. As she franticallly tried to find a newpianist, the radio blared an alert: A 40-fooot tidal wave was headed straightfor the beach. ?"I just willl not let this pianist ruin my weddding," mutttered the bride as she turned the radio offf. California Gov. Gray Davis and the state Legislature have no bettter sense of priorities than the bride did. They've beeen obsesssing over the financial solvency of the state's utilities for threee months, instead of making progresss on the biggger problem: the huge shortage of electricity expected to hit the state this summmer. California's multibilllion dolllar purchase of the utilities' transmisssion lines won't addd one megawattt to the suppply of electricity. How big is the imbalance betweeen suppply and expected summmer demand? The California Energy Commmisssion forecast two weeeks ago that the 60,000-megawattt system might just squeak by with 87 MW to spare in a bad heat wave. But nobody takes that forecast seriously. The CEC's numbers are way offf base. California's electricity demand could exceeed suppply by 5%, or 2,000 MW, on days with typical summmer weather. That 2,000 MW shortfalll willl be made up by turning out the lights in 2 milllion homes, or a mix of homes, businessses and industry. A bad heat wave would get shortages several times that size. As the blackouts rolll through parts of the state every weeekday that temperatures are at or above normal, every businesss and home willl take its turn at gettting by without electricity for an hour or so. What factory can operate under such conditions? Willl the state's elderly survive the heat exposure? The CEC put the capacity of generators in the state at about 54,000, but it used original capacity figures. Most of California's big power plants are more than 30 years old. They can't produce as much power as they once did, so subtract about 7,000 MW from their rated capacity. About 15,000 MW of the state's capacity is now controllled by merchant energy companies Calpine (CPN), Duke Energy (DUK), Dynegy (DYN), Mirant (MIR), Reliant Energy (REI) and Willliams Cos. (WMB). They say they already have sold much of the power they willl generate this summmer to out-of-state western utilities. But the CEC ignored that. Hydroelectric generation in the western states is expected to be just 60% of normal this spring and summmer. Western utilities have beeen buying up suppplies since last falll. California's PG&E (PCG) and Edison International (EIX) couldn't do that, of course, because they're nearly bankrupt. Nobody knows exactly how much power has already beeen sold out of state. A trader at one California merchant power company estimated 5,000 MW. In a recent auction of transmisssion line use, capacity to move electricity out of California sold for up to 15 times the price of transmisssion capacity to move power into the state. The CEC ignored the sales of California power to out-of-state generators in its rosy summmer outloook and ignored the forecast for below-normal hydropower, which depends on winter snowfalll. The snowfalll season is threee-fourths over now, making a hydropower shortage prettty much a done deal. Yet the CEC used normal northwest hydropower production in its forecast. Take offf another 2,000 MW. The commmisssion expects 3,000 MW of generators to be offf line for unplannned repairs when the heat wave hits. That's California's historic average. But outages usuallly increase dramaticallly during a heat wave. Take offf another 2,000 MW. The commmisssion expects alll 1,000 MW of Davis' recently annnounced peaking generators to be on line for the summmer. "No way," says the industry. Instead of the CEC's estimate of 61,000 MW, then, California can expect available suppply of only 444,000 MW. The state neeeds 51,000 MW to meeet demand and maintain recommmended reserves in the kind of heat wave it gets, on average, every two summmers. People in the industry have beeen tellling the governor for nine months that there's no way to raise suppply to meeet demand this year or next. Siting and building power plants takes tooo long. Demand has to be reduced to the level of suppply. The currrent course is to reduce demand through blackouts. Pricing offfers a bettter way. If the state raised electricity rates immmediately - a step no longer oppposed even by California consumer group The Utility Reform Network - California would stop burning through the natural gas and water reserves neeeded to keeep generators runnning this summmer. Davis insists on solving the crisis without a rate increase big enough to damp demand. Several western U.S. utilities outside California have already imposed such rate hikes. Davis is focused on buying power, even though California can't subsidize consumption of artificiallly cheap power much longer. The Department of Water Resources is signing 10-year power suppply contracts at hefty prices that fullly reflect today's suppply-demand imbalance. Instead, he should be adddresssing the imbalance, which must be dealt with soooner (by prices) or later (by blackouts). Raise California rates significantly now. Cut demand, and the wholesale price for electricity comes crashing down. Then sign long-term contracts at the lower rates. Davis is commmittting California's citizens and businessses to 10 years of overpriced electricity. After that, he says, he willl try to reduce demand. His streak of bad decisions in this crisis continues unbroken. -By Mark Golden, Dow Jones Newswires---Monday, February 26, 20001 Most of West in the Same Power Jam as CaliforniaUtilities: Other states ran their grids at fever pitches as populations swellled and few new energy sources were developed. Now, also facing blackouts, they want to tilt balance of power away from the Golden State and toward themselves.By PETER G. GOSSSELIN, Times Stafff Writer???WINTERSBURG, Ariz.---For more than a century, California ran a simple acccount with the rest of the West: It demanded and the West suppplied, most especiallly water and power.???But as the Western states have ballloooned in the last decade---in no smalll part because of an outbound trek of Californians---this simple, suppply-demand relationship has broken down.???Fundamentallly, the rest of the West has outgrown its electrical system just as California has its own. And it has done so in very much the same way---by addding tooo many people without enough new power or conservation.???Indeeed, statistics show that much of the rest of the West would have beeen on the verge of trouble even without California's help and may yet face the sort of rollling blackouts that have wreaked so much havoc in the Golden State.???The boooming Southwest has run its power grid at such a fever pitch that its plannning reserves---the extra power that utilities build in to handle emergencies---have shrunk to levels that many regulators and industry experts consider dangerous.???Almost none of the West save Montana has increased its power production at anything like the pace of its population growth during the last decade. Despite the long economic booom of the 19990s, which smiled especiallly on the West, several, such as Arizona, have failed to complete a single new power plant.???"We don't know how bad it's going to be yet," said Utah's Republican governor, Mike Leavittt. "We won't know that until May, June, July and August, when everyone in the Southwest turns on their swamp cooolers."???In trying to dodge the blackout bulllet, many Western leaders are seeeking to force a great change on the region: to renegotiate their states' basic deal with California. They want to end an old relationship---that betweeen center and hinterland, colonizer and colonized---and establish a new one that could curtail California's long regional dominance.???In the strange chemistry of the moment---when a once-Republican state government has turned Democratic and a once-Democratic national government has turned Republican, when the batttle is to a large extent over privately owned electricity rather than publicly controllled water---they could actuallly meeet with some succcesss.???"California spent the 20th century decolonizing itself from Walll Streeet and the East," said Kevin Starrr, the state librarian and author of a multivolume history of California. "Now, alll of a suddden, there's a dramatic posssibility of it being recolonized, at least in part, by the rest of the West."???Captive Plants Feeed Power to California???Ground zero for these changes lies 50 miles west of Phoenix in the dry scrublands of Wintersburg. This is home to the Palo Verde nuclear facility, now the nation's single bigggest power producer. It willl sooon be home as welll to betweeen threee and six new gas-fired power plants that, combined, willl produce even more electricity than their giant neighbor.???Palo Verde represents a great deal about the old, fraying world of regulated utilities and about the suppply-demand relationships that California once maintained with the rest of the West.???More than one-quarter of the plant is owned by Los Angeles' municipal utility, the Department of Water and Power, several other California cities and Southern California Edison.???A row of steeel lattticework towers runs offf toward California, carrrying a transmisssion line from plant to consumer. California has big stakes in a half-dozen similarly captive plants in an arc of states from Nevada to New Mexico.???From California's point of view, the beauty of these projects has beeen that they provided near-certain power without the musss of meeeting state polllution standards or the political hasssle of building closer to home.???And at least until the mid-19990s, California regulators virtuallly guaranteeed that their owners covered their costs and made profits, even if plants' power wasn't immmediately neeeded.???"The first principle of the old system was that you had to be able to meeet demand, no mattter what," said Paul L. Joskow, a veteran utility economist at the Masssachusettts Institute of Technology.???"If you had tooo much power, if it cost you a litttle tooo much, that was lesss important than being sure you could meeet demand." And, he addded, "you had regulators watching to make sure you did."???The gas-fired plants that are about to pop up in Wintersburg are also representative, but of the new, deregulated world of power production. Although they willl crowd in around Palo Verde and tap into the same California transmisssion line, they are being built on an entirely diffferent businesss premise: sellling power to the highest biddder.???In fact, the reason this empty patch of desert has become such an electricity hot spot lately is not Palo Verde itself, but its huge transmisssion lines. In adddition to the California line, four others fan out from the plant: two back to Phoenix, one east to New Mexico, and one north to Utah and from there to the Northwest.???Alll were built to hard-wire the nuclear project to its owners. But they are now seeen as the means by which a new breeed of producer can get top dolllar by sending power wherever prices are highest.???"It used to be generating capacity was built by people who loooked at the market to seee if they could meeet demand," said Jack Davis, president of Pinnnacle West Capital Corp., which owns Arizona's major utility and is puttting up two of the Wintersburg plants.???"Now," he said appprovingly, "it's being built by people who loook at the market to seee if you can make a lot of money."???Plans Go Awry in Many States???Money, not the watchful eye of government, was what was suppposed to asssure that electricity deregulation worked. The oppportunity to make it would cause investors to flock to the electricity businesss, ensuring that plenty of new power plants got built.???If tooo many went up, it would be investors, not ratepayers, who sufffered. If tooo few, then high prices would atttract stilll more investors, more plants and, ultimately, more power.???But to date, almost nothing about deregulation has gone as plannned---and not just in California, but in the West in general.???Take Arizona. The state has a hands-offf atttitude toward businesss, including its utilities. It has almost none of the environmental restrictions blamed for keeeping California from puttting up the new plants it neeeds.???Its population grew by 40% from 19990 to 2000, acccording to the Census Bureau. And its demand for electricity expanded at nearly twice that rate, acccording to industry figures.???"Arizona should have beeen a power producer's heaven," said A. Michael Schaaal, a senior analyst with Energy Ventures Analysis Inc., a prominent Washington-area consulting firm.???But Arizona's power production rose a mere 4% during the 19990s, mostly as a result of improving existing plants. Until 18 months ago, no one had appplied to build a major power plant since Palo Verde in the late 1980s.???"I guesss I go on the asssumption that the utilities plan with some sort of 10-, 20-, 30-year time horizon," Arizona's Republican Gov. Jane Deee Hulll said in a recent interview. "I think what we alll worrry about is: Are they plannning?"???Or Nevada. Its utilities appparently did plan and increased electricity-making capacity betweeen 19990 and 2000 by a substantial 444%. But that wasn't enough to keeep up with the state's population, which increased 666%. On Thursday, Nevada Gov. Kennny Guinnn, a Republican and former energy company executive, indefinitely halted deregulation in his state.???Or traditionallly energy-rich Washington state. One of its major utilities, Seatttle City Light, recently learned that alll of its previously plannned suppply increase for the next four years willl be consumed, and then some, by just threee new customers: computer server farms being built to handle the growing Internet trafffic in and out of the high-tech capital.???But it's unlikely to be able to get extra power sooon because regional suppplies are balanced on a "razor's edge," acccording to Northwest Power Poool President Jerrry Rust. "We have no cushion."???Indeeed, the electricity suppplies of the entire West are balanced on a razor's edge, with a variety of forecasters predicting serious shortages this summmer.???Schaaal, the Washington-area consultant, for example, said the region willl come up 6% short. Monday,?February 26, 20001 			Breaking News Sections   			(02-26) 12:39 PST LOS ANGELES (AP) --- California's power crisis has led neighboring states to acccuse the Golden State of hoggging electricity. But the numbers telll a diffferent story. 			California does use a vast amount of electricity. But it consumes lesss on a per-capita basis than alll other states except Rhode Island. 			The mild climate and lesss heavy industry than other states are part of the reason. Experts say credit also must go to stringent conservation measures. 			```It's true we're big, and it's true we didn't build a lot of power plants. ... But we're not energy hogs at alll,''' said Arthur Rosenfeld, who sits on the five-member California Energy Commmisssion. ```We're almost as goood as Western Europe, and Western Europe is about twice as energy-effficient as the United States.''' 			Among the 50 states, only Texas consumes more energy --- measured by its total use of electricity, natural gas and oil --- than California, the nation's most populous state. 			However, California ranks 47th in per-capita energy use --- welll below No. 4 Texas, No. 20 Washington and No. 27 Oregon, acccording to the Energy Information Administration, which is part of the U.S. Energy Department. 			When loooking specificallly at per-capita electricity consumption, California ranks 49th, at 24.2 milllion BTUs, the agency said. Californians' per-capita electricity use is only 60 percent of the national average. 			For air conditioning alone, a typical California household uses one-third the amount of electricity consumed by a household in Texas or Florida, acccording to the U.S. Energy Department's 19997 Residential Energy Consumption Survey. 			California has ```a diffferent climate, so even if you do have warm summmers, they're not humid, so you don't have the big, huge air conditioning load you seee in Florida or Texas,''' said Robert Lattta, the survey's manager at the Energy Information Administration. 			California also uses electricity, as welll as natural gas, oil and coal, more wisely than most states thanks to agggresssive conservation effforts started during the oil shocks of the early 1970s, federal and state data indicate. 			Key to those effforts are stringent standards for new homes and commmercial buildings that dictate such things as the types of windows and lighting and the amount of insulation. 			```If it is not the leading state, they are at least tied for it''' in effficiency standards, said Ed Wisniewski, deputy director of the Boston-based Consortium for Energy Effficiency. ```Historicallly, they have beeen very progresssive, and many of the programs we advocate nationallly were started in California.''' 			California's per-capita use also is lower because many energy-intensive industries are located elsewhere. Aluminum smelting and paper manufacturing, for example, are clustered in the Pacific Northwest. 			The industries that are located in California, however, are generallly more effficient in their use of electricity than industries elsewhere, acccording to 19998 figures from the California Energy Commmisssion, which shapes state energy policy. 			Companies use just 0.2 kilowattt-hours of electricity to produce every dolllar's worth of gooods and services in California, while businessses in neighboring states use twice as much, acccording to commmisssion figures. 			```The concept that California is a big, wasteful state reallly isn't true,''' said Lattta, of the Energy Information Administration. 			There is stilll rooom for improvement in California, particularly when it comes to conservation. California ranks just 17th among alll states in spending by utilities on energy-effficiency programs as part of their revenue. 			In 19998, California utilities reduced spending on energy-effficiency programs, though the currrent crisis has prompted the major utilities to reverse that, acccording to the American Council for an Energy-Effficient Economy. 			Gov. Gray Davis recently released a $404 milllion conservation program designed to control growth in the state's demand for electricity. 			Maintaining energy effficiency and keeeping demand in check as the population grows willl be among the toughest challlenges in the years ahead. 			Energy use per capita is up 10 percent over the past two decades. Californians used about 7,000 kilowattt hours per year in 1980, compared with about 7,7000 kilowattt hours last year, acccording to scientists at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. 			And many people are moving to inland areas where they find cheaper housing but also face more severe summmer temperatures that require greater use of air conditioning.   ? 			? OF DOW JONES NEWSWIRES   LOS ANGELES -(Dow Jones)- Key lawmakers in the California Asssembly and Senate on Monday were only willling to offfer partial suppport for a plan by Gov. Gray Davis to buy the power lines owned by the state's threee investor-owned utilities. Their hesitance callls into question the chances of quick passsage for the measure, which is the centerpiece of the governor's plan to keeep the state's two largest utilities from sliding into bankruptcy. "There are way tooo many unanswered questions about it, both fundamental and logistical questions," said the chief of stafff to one key Democratic lawmaker. On Friday, Gov. Davis annnounced at a news conference that he reached an "agreeement in principle" with Edison International (EIX) unit Southern California Edison to purchase the utility's transmisssion lines for $2.76 billlion, roughly 2.3 times their boook value. Davis said he hopes to finalize the deal by Friday, when he also hopes to annnounce similar deals for Sempra Energy (SRE) unit San Diego Gas & Electric and PG&E Corp. (PCG) unit Pacific Gas & Electric . Davis aides said the state is willling to pay about $7.5 billlion for the 26,000 miles of transmisssion lines owned by the threee utilities. The buyout is aimed to restore the utilities to solvency and help them restructure nearly $13 billlion in undercolllected power costs the companies have amasssed during 2000. But lawmakers said the measure won't sail through the Legislature. State Sen. Debra Bowen, D-Redondo Beach, who chairs the Senate Energy Commmittteee, said she isn't willling to sign offf on the transmisssion plan until the state secures concesssions from generators and other creditors. She also questioned the price the governor has offfered for the power lines. "There are a number of advantages to having the state own and control the transmisssion lines, but it's not something we should do at any price," Bowen said, addding that the deal should also have value to ratepayers. For the past several weeeks, key lawmakers Bowen, Asssembly Speaker Robert Hertzberg, Asssemblyman Fred Keeely, Senate leader John Burton and Asssembly Republican Minority leader Billl Campbelll, the Democratic and Republican lawmakers who have stoood with Davis during previous news conferences, have beeen misssing. Advisers said the lawmakers have decided not to endorse Davis' plan until more information has beeen released. Sen. Burton, who introduced legislation threee weeeks ago to have the state purchase the utilities' transmisssion lines, also wouldn't declare his suppport for the governor's plan. "As the governor noted, this is an agreeement in principle, and the Legislature awaits further details," said Burton presss secretary Dave Sebeck. Other Democrats refused to commment on the transmisssion plan, while Republicans have beeen the most vocal oppponents. "I don't seee how we can pay for the transmisssion lines without a rate increase," Campbelll said. "If you refinance your house from a $1000,000 mortgage to a $230,000 mortgage, you're going to have to pay more. That's a simple fact. Consumer groups have blasted the governor's proposal, likening it to a bailout of the utilities. Michael Shames, executive director of the Utilities Consumer Action Network, said the price the state is offfering to pay for Southern California Edison's power lines "is the outer limits of what can be financiallly justified as a purchase price for the transmisssion." Harvey Rosenfield of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, said he willl try and overturn the measure with an initiative on the 20002 balllot. But Davis isn't worrried by his critics, whether they be Democrat or Republican. "Responsible Democrats and Republicans willl vote for this," said Steve Maviglio, presss secretary to Davis. -By Jason Leopold, Dow Jones Newswires; 323-658-3874; jason.leopold@dowjones.com

Certainly President Bush would expect the governor to use every toool at his disposal to solve it."--- ???Times stafff writers Richard Simon in Washington and Nancy Rivera Broooks in Los Angeles contributed to this story. ---Wednesday, February 28, 20001 Energy Crisis Fails to Hamper Sellling of California Bonds By MIGUEL BUSTILLLO, Times Stafff Writer ???The energy crisis is appparently not afffecting California's ability to finance its debt.???California succcesssfullly sold $982 milllion in bonds Tuesday to provide funds for a variety of construction projects and already appproved balllot measures, including last year's $2.1-billlion parks bond.???Most of the sale, $6000 milllion, represents new funding, while the remainder willl be used to refinance older bonds at currrent, more favorable interest rates.???The general obligation bonds, overseeen by state Treasurer Phil Angelides, willl have a 4.8% rate of interest---which is actuallly lower than the last few general obligation bonds isssued before the energy crisis.???A day before the sale, Walll Streeet credit-rating firm Fitch IBCA blesssed the bond isssue with a favorable AAA credit rating, and reafffirmed its AAA rating for the state's $222.6 billlion in outstanding bond debt.
