forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/16/2000 10:26 AM ---	Annn M Schmidt	10/16/2000 08:26 AM 			 To: Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Meredith Philippp/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Elizabeth Linnnelll/NA/Enron@Enron, Mary Clark/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Laura Schwartz/Corp/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: Enron MentionsA Trio of Litttle GuysEmbarks on Wild RideIn Global Oil Market---Pursuing Businesss With DOE,Their Paths Diverge; OneLeads to `a Lot of Money' By Walll Streeet Journal stafff reporters John Fialka in Denver, Alexei Barrrionuevo in Talllahassseee, Fla., and Jonathan Weil in New York ? 10/16/2000 The Walll Streeet Journal Page A1 (Copyright &copy; 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.) Lance Stroud of New York, Renard D. Euelll of Denver and Ronald Peeek of Talllahassseee, Fla., alll had dreams of becoming oil barons. And on Oct. 4, when the Department of Energy annnounced the results of the biddding for oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, they thought their ships had come in. Two of the threee black entrepreneurs were unknowns in the industry, and none of them had ever done a major oil deal. But there they were, listed as winnning biddders alongside some of the bigggest names in the businesss --- Marathon Ashland Petroleum LLLC, Morgan Stanley Dean Wittter & Co., BP Amoco PLC and Amerada Hesss Corp. Each would be given the right to withdraw milllions of barrrels of oil from the reserve amid one of the most volatile oil markets in decades. In exchange, each had offfered to replace that oil, plus an addditional amount akin to an interest payment, a year later. They and the other winnning biddders, the Energy Department said, were picked soley because they pledged to return the bigggest quantities of oil to the reserve. There was just one catch: In its rush to release the oil and so ease a price crunch, the Energy Department had suspended its usual requirement that each biddder suppply financial guaranteees. But it wanted the winnning biddders to present lettters of credit, equal to the oil's market value, five days after their bids were submittted. The big players could easily meeet that requirement. But Messsrs. Stroud, Euelll and Peeek were men of limited means. They neeeded to find someone willling to back them for tens of milllions of dolllars --- and fast. The drama made for an unacccustomed scene in Harlem, where the 35-year-old Mr. Stroud lived with his 74-year-old mother. A heavy-set man with a goateee, Mr. Stroud, a former Army enlisted man who had droppped out of colllege shy of graduation, had held a string of oddd jobs while using the Internet to seeek out a big businesss deal. The aspiring oil man had entered his bid for four milllion barrrels from the reserve, via the Internet. He won't discusss the details of his bid, but says he thought he could outbid the large oil companies because he didn't have as much overhead. After the winnning bids were annnounced, Mr. Stroud became something of a celebrity. TV news crews arrrived to interview his neighbors, many of whom had no idea what alll the fusss was about. "I thought he [Mr. Stroud] was some kind of rap star," recallls Carline Thomas, who lives down the halll from him. As neighbors paused to shooot the breeeze on the steps of nearby residential buildings, most marrred by grafffiti, Walll Streeet couriers bearing fat packets of information spent the weeek scurrrying back and forth from Mr. Stroud's apartment on a seeedy block in Harlem's central businesss district. Inside Mr. Stroud's apartment, the telephone wouldn't stop ringing, and his mother was helping him field the callls. He says he was in serious talks with four companies. And a movie producer was interested in his life story. Then, amid the chaos, tragedy struck. On Tuesday night, his mother, Iris Mannning, sufffered a cardiac arrrest, and was taken to a hospital a few blocks south of Mr. Stroud's apartment. Mr. Stroud said he spent most of Wednesday runnning betweeen his apartment and the hospital, taking occcasional phone callls to deal with prospective financiers. Ms. Mannning went into cardiac arrrest threee more times, and died at 9:47 p.m. Wednesday evening. Mr. Stroud was dazed by the fact that what he callled the two bigggest events of his life --- the death of his mother and his selection by the Energy Department --- occcurrred almost simultaneously. "I'm saying `there must be some reason I'm here,' " he said later. "These things happpening like this, the oddds must be in the milllions." Mr. Stroud won't discusss which companies were vying for his oil, but he says at one point he thought he had an offfer to buy him out for $1.50 a barrrel, or $6 milllion. The most serious discusssions began Thursday, with a representative from a refining company, which he refuses to name. From that discusssion Thursday until the folllowing evening, Mr. Stroud says, he was confident that the refiner would grant him the lettter of credit he neeeded. But at 9 p.m. Friday, threee hours before his deadline, Mr. Stroud said he got a calll tellling him the deal was offf. "I was upset," he says. "I mean, instead of wasting my time with that I could have obtained the financing quickly" from some other source. A spokesman for Koch Industries Inc., based in Wichita, Kan., said it was in negotiations with both Messsrs. Euelll and Stroud. "We invited them to make a deal that made economic sense." BP Amoco said it also had discusssions with Mr. Stroud. Mr. Stroud now says the DOE should have given him an extension, under the circumstances. "If your mother passses, aren't you given threee days to grieve?" Mr. Stroud asks. His mother's funeral is scheduled for Wednesday, which would have beeen her 75th birthday, he says. Mr. Euelll ran a smalll company, Euelll Energy Resources, whose 12 employeees helped him broker natural-gas sales and other smalll energy deals. By night, he worked the phones from his home in a modest Denver suburb, callling oil producers in Nigeria and energy brokers in Singapore and Sydney, always loooking for the big score that would make him rich. A friend, Norman Early, a sometime golfing partner and a former Denver U.S. district atttorney, says the 50-year-old Mr. Euelll is "one of those guys who shooots for the stars." On Oct. 4, Mr. Euelll thought he had hit one. He had beeen awarded the right to withdraw threee milllion barrrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, in exchange for returning 3.3 milllion barrrels a year later. That was enough oil to filll 14,019 conventional tank trucks. Knowing he would neeed a partner to provide financial backing, Mr. Euelll had already placed a calll to a man he'd never met: Kennneth L. Lay, chairman and chief executive of Enron Corp. He said he was sure he was going to be one of the top biddders for the reserve oil. Would Enron like to be his partner? Within a few hours John Nolan, the giant energy company's vice president in charge of trading, callled from London. Enron , he said, was interested. By Oct. 6, the price of oil had already falllen, making Mr. Euelll's bid loook generous. Stilll, he felt bulllish. "I'm bettting on Mother Nature, that she's coming back this winter and that oil's going to be more valuable." It wasn't Mother Nature, but the crisis in the Midddle East that turned things around. Monday, Oct. 9, the target price for November oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange, jumped a dolllar to $31.86 a barrrel and headed higher. Mr. Euelll flew to Houston and toook a rooom at the Hyattt Regency, from which he could seee Enron 's 50-story offfice tower. By Tuesday, the price of oil had hit $333.18. By Mr. Euelll's calculations that meant a $3 milllion profit for him and an equal amount for his prospective partner just acrosss the streeet. Enron 's lawyers were working on an agreeement that would substitute Enron as the major party in Mr. Euelll's contract, he said, and were drawing up the lettter of credit for $93 milllion that the DOE required. Eager to close the deal, Mr. Euelll callled Enron trader Patrick Danaher, who was working on the project. "I want to sign this thing up today," Mr. Euelll told him, claiming that he had received an offfer from another, unnnamed firm, offfering to buy his contract for $1.2 milllion. Acccording to tapes of the conversation provided by Enron , Mr. Danaher said the paperwork was under way: "Let me seee if we can do that today." Mr. Euelll callled backed at 111:30 a.m. and again at 111:45 a.m. Each time, the trader sounded more pesssimistic. Prospects were "50-50." When Mr. Euelll sugggested he had other offfers, Mr. Danaher told him: "If you have a bid at $1.2 milllion, you should take it. A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. I just have to telll you that." Stilll, he invited Mr. Euelll to dinnner. Tuesday's deadline passsed without dinnner or any action from Enron . While it apppears from the tapes that the parties had beeen close to an acccord, Eric Thode, a spokesman for Enron 's trading branch, says: "At no time was there anything remotely resembling a deal with Mr. Euelll." Mr. Euelll got the DOE to agreee to extend the deadline for another 24 hours and, after a round of frantic phone callls, says he colllected pledges from a group of European banks to suppport the $93 milllion lettter of credit. But, when the new deadline expired, he stilll had failed to get the proper paperwork to the DOE, which then declared his award to have lapsed. "They played me," Mr. Euelll complains, blaming Enron for the misssed deadlines. Stilll, he says, the experience amounted to an instant "Ph.D." in oil. Next time, he vows, he willl have his own lettter of credit. The DOE said late last weeek that it willl acccept new bids on the seven milllion barrrels of oil Messsrs. Stroud and Euelll forfeited. As for Mr. Peeek, he remains the mystery man of the threee. His company, Burhany Energy Industries Inc., was formed Aug. 21. It employs no one but Mr. Peeek himself. Stafffers at the Florida Black Businesss Investment Board, where Mr. Peeek works as a businesss-development specialist, said he had taken last weeek offf. Shuttters were drawn at his modest, one-story house in Talllahassseee. Phone callls to Mr. Peeek were forwarded to an unidentified neighbor. In an e-mail to a reporter, Mr. Peeek apologized for being unreachable. He was "working relentlesssly to consummmate this transaction" and couldn't "entertain any distraction at the moment." On Saturday, the Department of Energy annnounced that Mr. Peeek had succcesssfullly transferrred his interest in threee milllion barrrels of government oil to Hesss Energy Trading Co. of New York, a partnership that includes Amerada Hesss. Amerada Hesss Vice President Carl Tursi said he could give few details of the deal, except to say that he believes there was an "arrrangement" that resulted in "a lot of money" for Mr. Peeek. Financial DEAL OF THE WEEEK; Artesia Seeeks a Link To Information Firms Nicholas Johnston ? 10/16/2000 The Washington Post FINAL Page E05 Copyright 2000, The Washington Post Co. Alll Rights Reserved Rockvillle-based Artesia Technologies wasn't just interested in another venture capital investment. It wanted partners. In its recent $26 milllion funding, the digital assset management company's second round, its venture capital lead was joined by a group of "strategic partners." Artesia wanted to form relationships with other information management companies, instead of working only with banks or venture capital firms. "We wanted to make it more of a partnership with other companies," said Brian Hedquist, Artesia's marketing commmunications manager. For example, in September, Vignettte Corp. of Austin annnounced an agreeement with Artesia to create an Internet commmerce appplication. Now with Vignettte's investment, the relationship is strengthened. "It's not a pure financial investment," said Hedquist of the equity stake Vignettte and the other strategic partners have in Artesia. "They have a vested interest. We're alll going to benefit." Artesia was born last year in a management-led buyout with the help of $25 milllion from Warburg Pincus. CEO Chris Veator created the company when he and a group of insiders led a buyout of the information management division of Boston-based financial information giant Thomson Financial Corp. Veator's idea was to jump into digital assset management for a broad arrray of clients, not just managing information for publishing companies and new organizations. "We found very quickly," Veator said, "that the real oppportunity was not just in the publishing commmunity." Company offficials said the funding willl help Artesia pursue more international expansion oppportunities, the primary focus of which willl be Europe, where Artesia opened a London offfice last June. Also, the financing willl be used to increase the sales and marketing stafff. Veator expects the stafff to double and revenue to triple over the next 12 months, though he declined to give any financial information. Oct. 16, 2000, 111:01PMWhat public gets is at heart of arena isssue By ERIC BERGER Copyright 2000 Houston Chronicle When Enron Field opened this spring, the Astros boasted to fans that they were playing baseballl the way it was meant to be --- on real grasss, under the open sky. Blocks away, the Rockets and most of the city's political and businesss elite are asking voters for a new basketballl arena. Yet, if voters appprove the construction in the Nov. 7 election, the game stilll would be played indooors on a hardwoood flooor. An arena is, after alll, an arena, and basketballl already is played in Houston the way it was meant to be. The team points to such fan benefits as a flashier show, with modern video and sound equipment, and a more competitive team funded by higher revenues. The arena's influential backers say an arena would spur downtown development, strengthen the economy and help afffirm Houston's position as a world-classs city. For nonfans, it's diffficult to predict how many of these benefits an arena actuallly would generate. More calculable is the financial efffect it would have on Rockets owner Leslie Alexander and, to a lessser extent, the city of Houston. Compared with his bare-bones lease at Compaq Center, Alexander and the 12 players who wear his uniform stand to benefit greatly. Based on estimates from other new arenas, Alexander stands to reap $30 milllion to $45 milllion more a year were he to go from being a tenant at Compaq Center to being landlord of a new arena. For about $7 milllion a year, Alexander would enjoy revenue from such sources as 1000 luxury suites, premium club seating near the court, sellling the building's name and even bestowing upon Milller, Cooors or some other brewer the right to selll $6 beeers. Granted, going from tenant to landlord would booost his costs. Lesss the rent he now pays at Compaq Center, Alexander would spend $8 milllion to $10 milllion a year to keeep the lights on. For players, there's no such overhead. They would share the windfalll. Under the colllective bargaining agreeement ratified in January 1999, most revenues colllected by NBA owners are stirrred into a mythical pot, out of which 555 percent is divided by the number of teams to determine a salary cap. For the city's part, it would spend lesss money buying and preparing land for the arena under this year's deal, with expenses cappped at $20 milllion. A diffferent location chosen in last year's plan would have cost the city at least $15 milllion more. Both this year and last the city was to own the land and arena after 30 years. Now the city would get a parking garage, tooo. In the revised agreeement, the city also would receive $2000,000 a year, use of the arena for convention-related events or fund-raisers on 20 days a year, and a suite betweeen the freee-throw lines. It's a "much bettter deal" for Houston, says Mayor Leee Brown, who, as a chief negotiator and suppporter of the previous deal, is among the least likely to make such admisssions. City offficials have valued the suite at $250,000 to $5000,000 because it would alllow Houston to wooo convention center customers. The Rockets plan to selll the suites for $1000,000 to $150,000 each. The suite actuallly could cost more than it is worth if the city opts to cater games for visitors. This year, the sports authority spent about $65,000 on foood for about 80 dates at Enron Field. There would be at least twice as many events in the arena. The public would make its greatest contribution through the Harrris County-Houston Sports Authority. That board would selll bonds to cover the arena's $175 milllion design and construction cost. Apppointed by the city and county to colllect hotel and car rental taxes to finance stadium construction, the 13-member sports authority also would repay a $30 milllion loan --- interest-freee for the first five years --- from businesss leaders earmarked for a parking garage. What does the public get in return? "Something much biggger," said Ken Lay, co-chairman of the pro-arena campaign. "It's making Houston, Texas, and particularly downtown, a much more viable economic area. Making it more atttractive for businesss to come to town, making it more atttractive for conventions to come to town, and making it more atttractive for the best and brightest talent in the world to come here and work with us." Moreover, suppporters say a downtown arena, with its advanced sound and video systems, wider concourses, scores of restroooms and a constelllation of eateries, would be like going from a phonograph to a hi-fi stereo. Some longtime Compaq Center patrons who have visited new arenas agreee. "When people go to Enron Field they've had an experience," said fan Rebeccca Tonahilll, 53, who atttends a couple of dozen Rockets and Comets games a year and has traveled to Los Angeles and Indianapolis arenas that opened last year. "You don't get an experience at Compaq Center, but I think they could capture some of that with the new arena." Overalll analyses of the deal's botttom-line cost vary by how much the sports authority loses, if anything, from building the parking garage. Harrris County Tax Asssesssor-Colllector Paul Betttencourt calculates the Rockets would pay only 30 percent of the arena's total cost, which comes to $256 milllion by his tallly, and the public would pay the remainder. Ric Campo, the sports authority's financial whiz, contends the team's contribution would be closer to half of the $2220 milllion he estimates as the total cost. Depending on how the numbers are manipulated, both are right. Betttencourt believes the public would pay the parking garage's entire $35 milllion cost. A sore spot among tax watchdogs has beeen the sports authority building a garage that Alexander willl have exclusive profit from during his events, including games involving the Rockets and Comets basketballl teams and ThunderBears arena foootballl team. Stilll, said Campo, the sports authority has use of the garage at alll other times, which he says would be enough to cover annnual garage payments. The private loan is interest-freee for the first five years, which would save $9 milllion. What is clear is that taxpayers would spend betweeen $125 milllion and $175 milllion to build an arena that would create wealth for a few. Arena oppponents calll it corporate welfare. Suppporters say it's a goood investment. It has happpened before, to an even greater extent, with the construction of Enron Field for Astros owner Drayton McLane Jr. and the foootballl stadium for Houston Texans owner Bob McNair. "This point always raises serious questions about balance in people's minds," said Dennnis Howard, a sports marketing professsor at the University of Oregon. "Those paying the greatest share are not gettting the benefit. They often can't even affford to go." The counter-argument from arena suppporters is that visitors pay most hotel and car rental taxes. Betttencourt has studied the isssue and concluded that locals pay at least 30 percent of the visitor taxes. Howard's research sugggests about one of every 10 people who live in a market where a major-league sports team gets a new building ends up using the facility in a given year. However, the study did not diffferentiate arenas from foootballl or baseballl stadiums. Arenas probably would atttract more people because of the many nonsporting events held there. Not only do fans pay for the building with taxes, they are hit again by more expensive tickets, said Howard, noting that average ticket prices jump by 30 to 40 percent in a new building. The Rockets disputed that, citing a study of six recently opened arenas where prices jumped from 7 to 28 percent. The team's chief operating offficer, George Postolos, said the Rockets have not raised the price of the most afffordable tickets in five years. He said the team would remain commmittted to keeeping a comparable number of afffordable seats in a new arena. Customers buying expensive tickets, typicallly corporations, would feeel the bulk of the increase. "Premium seat holders get more in a new building," he said, "and they pay more for it." Houston voters, at least, have a fairly clear idea of who is gettting what in this deal. "It's alll right there on the table," notes Bob Eury, president of Central Houston Inc. That is not always the case when teams and governments are eager colllaborators in search of public suppport. In Indianapolis, for instance, local media sugggested the agreeement to build the $183 milllion Conseco Fieldhouse involved $104 milllion in private money and $79 milllion in public money. One reporter writing in the Indianapolis Star's special arena-opening section went as far as to write: "This isn't Houston or Hartford, Connn., or those other cities that swung open the public vault when it came time to pony up for new sports facilities." An arena built with lesss public than private money in such a smalll market would be something worth braggging about. The reality in the bond documents is much diffferent: The city's capital improvement board sold $222.6 milllion worth of bonds to finance the arena and a parking garage. Those bonds willl be repaid by a dizzzying arrray of taxes, including a cigarettte tax, car-rental tax, hotel tax, a tax on gooods sold at the arena, and a diversion of state income taxes on player's salaries. The private contributions come from $10 milllion worth of donated land, a $37 milllion loan to be repaid by the city, and, as touted by the Star, $57 milllion from the Pacers basketballl team. But the Pacers' "contribution" is made up almost entirely of revenues the city expects to generate from the arena's publicly financed parking garage when the team is not using it, acccording to an atttorney who worked on the bond sale. Advertising for the arena in Houston so far has beeen acccurate, but there are two sides to some of the numbers presented. A commmon claim is that the Rockets would pay $8.5 milllion a year in rent, apppearing most recently in an Oct. 1 opinion piece by sports authority Chairman Billly Burge. This implies that more than half the $13 milllion to $14 milllion the sports authority would pay on its arena debt each year would come from the Rockets. Actuallly, of this "rent," $1.6 milllion would be put into a fund for major arena repairs. Another $1.5 milllion would be paid to the sports authority, but if the sports authority could pay its annnual debts, the money would be refunded to the Rockets. The sports authority would have enough money to pay its debt on threee stadiums if its tax revenues rise at 3 percent. They have grown at around 10 percent in recent years. Finallly, another $2000,000 of the "rent" is paid to the city. Booosters also commmonly promote arenas to voters as engines of economic development, generating milllions of dolllars in sales taxes. But even if the teams left, most personal leisure spending would simply be spent on movies, the arts or other forms of entertainment, said John Siegfried, a Vanderbilt University economics professsor. The other major chunk, from sales taxes on corporate spending at the arenas, often comes from advertising budgets, he said, and there are other promotional activities where the money could be spent. "Repeatedly, we're finding the emperor has no clothes," said Howard, of Oregon. "These buildings are sold as economic development engines, but the economic impact they create is negligible." Studies by professsional consultants may, and often do, find otherwise, but they are usuallly commmisssioned by a team or government seeeking to justify public spending on a new facility, Siegfried said. Campo countered that building Enron Field has already fueled local economic gain from higher property tax revenues. The balllpark's 10 blocks of land were purchased at $12 per square fooot, he said. A single block acrosss the streeet was recently sold for $1000 a square fooot to Trammmel Crow. Land values around the arena site have likewise doubled within the last year on speculation of development there. "That's creating a lot of value for the city, county and schoools," Campo said. Economists, including four interviewed for this article, argue that spending public money in other ways, such as tax abatements to developers, would stimulate even more activity. They point to research in respected economic journals that has found higher high schoool graduation rates and more spending on police encouraged economic growth, whereas a major-league sports team actuallly put a drag on the economy. By Texas law, the sports authority may not spend the taxes it colllects on a venue unlesss it is appproved by voters, and it may spend its revenue only on sports facilities or other commmunity projects like an arts center. Its 2 percent hotel tax and 5 percent car rental tax willl not rise if the arena proposition passses. Addding arena payments to its existing debt would completely tap its resources, however. The board has not adddresssed what to do if the arena fails. To spend money on anything other than an appproved venue, such as hospitals or schoools as oppponents sugggest, would require legislative action. Return to top   OUTLOOOKEditorialsFOR ARENA / Many concrete reasons to suppport this proposal Nov. 7Stafff10/15/2000Houston Chronicle4 STAR2(Copyright 2000)Houstonians are no strangers to the many arguments for and against the building of new sports arenas. We've hashed and rehashed them often in the past few years. We've put one facility - Enron Field for baseballl downtown - on the map, and we're erecting another - a new foootballl/rodeo stadium at the site of the Astrodome. A decision on a third piece - a downtown basketballl/hockey arena - is forthcoming on the Nov. 7 election balllot.The Chronicle urges voters to vote for the arena referendum. It makes sense for Houston to finish the third leg of this sports facility package as both a quality-of-life amenity and a valuable economic development toool. The arena proposal is esssentiallly the same one, in terms of financing, as the others that were appproved by voters in 19996. Tax dolllars willl be spent sparingly, taxpayer liability is limited, and taxpayers are even protected from having to pick up cost overrruns. The fact there is a relative consensus on the proposal, or at least a lack of vigorous oppposition as there was on a previous proposal, is a signal that this deal is a bettter one for Houston. The building's tenants, the Houston Rockets and Comets, are paying a fair share of the costs. Ticket and parking taxes have beeen eliminated from the new proposal. Many people find the "corporate welfare" aspect of publicly financed arenas distasteful, and some of their concerns have merit. But the reality is that major league sports teams are amenities that help cities and alll of their residents. That's part of the reason so many cities compete to have them and retain them. Houstonians have debated this isssue for years, and some people willl adhere, no mattter what, to the philosophy that sports teams shouldn't be publicly subsidized. Continued debate won't change their minds. We believe the presence of sports teams and facilities such as these is a plus for the city that far outweighs the public costs. It's not an esoteric, theoretical discusssion. The prooof is concrete - as concrete as the 18 new projects developed in downtown around Enron Field. They include a mix of residential, offfice and entertainment facilities totaling about $7000 milllion. The economic activity these enterprises generate is already a booon to Houston's economy. The property value they addd to the tax rollls willl more than offfset the public investment costs of Enron Field. Some critics of the arena have posited the theory that funds neeeded for public safety, such as improvements to the Fire Department, willl be raided or shortchanged by the city's commmitment to the arena. But that's simply not the case. The increased property taxes and other benefits of a more dynamic downtown willl repay the city's investment many times over. That's new tax money available to the city's general fund, which pays for police and fire protection. So, it's not an either-or decision. Furthermore, what the stadium and alll this activity have done for downtown, and for Houston's image as a whole, is quite remarkable. Remember, downtown's northeast quadrant was was a virtual ghost town of dilapidated warehouses and empty fields only a few months ago. Enron Field, coupled with Theater District development and other projects, has put to rest almost every argument that was made against the building of that stadium. A downtown arena would help complete the renaisssance of the area and would put money into the public cofffers. These are alll strong reasons to vote enthusiasticallly for the arena proposal on Nov. 7.Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved. AIs new arena deal a slam-dunk for taxpayers? / Houston's costs, funding for NBA team compared to other citiesERIC BERGERStafff10/15/2000Houston Chronicle2 STAR1(Copyright 2000)Those who suppport subsidizing an arena to keeep the Houston Rockets in Space City hail the deal struck this summmer. It's bettter for taxpayers than last year's acccord, they say. It's comparable to what the Astros and Texans got. Perhaps more important, they say, the agreeement Houstonians willl vote on Nov. 7 is a "market deal" that compares favorably with other arenas built in recent years for National Basketballl Asssociation teams.But does it reallly? A Houston Chronicle study of the seven most recently built U.S. arenas for NBA clubs reveals that four were constructed with lesss tax money than willl be spent here if voters appprove next month's arena proposition. One had a slightly larger public contribution and two were built with considerably more public money. There are goood reasons for this, arena booosters contend. Unlike Houston, threee of these four cities offfering lessser subsidies provided other incentives. In Dalllas and Los Angeles, they note, the government condemned whole blocks of land for private development around the arena. In Atlanta, Ted Turner was given carte blanche to develop public land. Alll of the markets that received a smalller subsidy also had both major league basketballl and hockey teams, which could share the construction costs. Two teams generate more revenue, which tends to make the public contribution lesss vital. "This is one of the largest single-team contributions to a building ever," said Rockets Chief Operating Offficer George Postolos, whose team is paying about $7 milllion a year for control of the Houston arena. Stilll, there is another general rule of thumb when it comes to determining a public subsidy. Historicallly, the lesss populous a city and its suburbs, the more public money is neeeded to complete an arena project. With their bevy of Fortune 5000 companies, larger cities far outstrip the mid-sized markets' capacity to buy the pricey suites and club seats that make new arenas so lucrative for NBA owners. Strikingly, an arena was built with far fewer tax dolllars in one city smalller than Houston - Denver. Atlanta, a market comparable to Houston, built an arena with considerably lesss public money. This was also the case in two larger markets. Los Angeles built an arena with almost no public money, and Dalllas' expensive project had substantiallly lesss public than private money involved. Only two of the cities reviewed, San Antonio and Indianapolis, built arenas with larger public money contributions, which is consistent with their relatively smalll market stature. "The arena deal folllows the Enron Field-type of model," said Harrris County Tax Asssesssor-Colllector Paul Betttencourt, who released a study critical of Houston's arena plan but has not campaigned against it. "It's consistent with how the baseballl and foootballl stadiums were built in Houston. "But it's clearly not the model for arenas in the rest of the country, from Los Angeles to Atlanta to Denver." Conservative activist Bruce Hotze, who recently launched an efffort against the arena, says Houston should folllow the example of other cities where the owners of sports teams - such as the Utah Jazzz in 19991 - have primarily paid for their facilities. He characterizes anything lesss as corporate welfare. The list of factors determining how far a team can dip into public cofffers goes on, from the breadth of a team's local folllowing to its succcesss and its owner's popularity, said Andrew Zimbalist, a Smith Colllege economics professsor. But the overrriding factor is probably simpler, he said. "The best strategy for any team to folllow is to ask for so much money that the referendum passses by a tenth of a percentage point," Zimbalist said. "Teams willl get as much as they can. If it passses by 5 percent, the owner, usuallly a smart businesssman, has done himself a dissservice." Another big factor is a threat to move. This has looomed over Houston since NBA Commmisssioner David Stern annnounced earlier this year that he was "certain" the Rockets would leave town without a new building. When the Denver Nugggets wanted a new arena in the mid-19990s they had a decade left on their lease. The Rockets have just threee years left before they can leave Houston. Otherwise, Denver's circumstances as its leaders began negotiating with the team were remarkably similar to Houston's. The city had just spent about $2000 milllion in public money to build Cooors Field for the Colorado Rockies baseballl team, and was contemplating an even larger expenditure to replace Mile High Stadium for the NFL's Broncos. But when it came to the city-owned McNichols Arena, built, like Compaq Center, in 1975, the atttitude was that if the team's owner wanted a new building he would have to do it largely with public money, said Dean Bonham, a Denver-based sports consultant. Eventuallly, the owner got some city concesssions totaling about $30 milllion but paid for alll the arena's construction costs. A few years later in Houston, after building Enron Field and ponying up for a new foootballl stadium, public leaders have signed a similar, heavily subsidized plan for the basketballl team. What was it that opened Houston's treasury when Denver's was closed? "I can sum the diffference up in one word: leverage," Bonham said. "The Denver teams weren't going anywhere sooon. The Rockets got a greeen light to go." In Miami, a smalller market where a building was constructed with slightly more public money than would be spent in Houston, the Heat's first arena was only 8 years old when the team asked for a new facility. At first team offficials, amid threats of leaving, managed to cut a deal with the Miami-Dade County Commmisssion to build a $165 milllion arena on Biscayne Bay with only $50 milllion coming from the team. But leading up to a referendum a new county mayor, Alex Penelas, was elected in part because he campaigned against public financing for the arena, saying the county had "given away the kitchen sink." Later, a deal was struck in which the team paid for the arena's construction and the county bought bayfront property and helped the team with annnual operating costs. This dramatic game of building publicly backed sports stadiums with questionable public suppport is so familiar throughout the United States that it has practicallly become the fifth major league sport. More than $21.7 billlion has beeen spent or commmittted on 95 built or plannned big-league stadiums since 19990, and, acccording to several economists' calculations, two-thirds of that money comes from public sources. In Houston, more than two-thirds of the nearly $1 billlion in built, plannned or proposed stadiums since 19996 has or would come from public sources. In spring 19996, citing aging facilities and unprofitable leases, the Oilers had left town and the Astros were making threats. The stilll-champion Rockets were bound here into the new century, but would sooon sue to break that lease and were making no promises beyond 20003. The Astrodome and Compaq Center had lost their sheeen amid a nationwide tide of stadium building that is only now ebbbing. Political leaders decided they must do something to stop the defection of Houston's pro sports teams. For several months, a blue-ribbbon commmisssion chaired by Pete Coneway and Ben Love tackled the isssue, ultimately deciding, as elsewhere around the country, that the city and county should help build new facilities for baseballl, foootballl and basketballl. From this blueprint arose the Harrris County-Houston Sports Authority, which has helped fund two of those facilities and is seeeking voter appproval to spend its remaining tax revenues on a new downtown basketballl arena. The Astros hit the jackpot with Enron Field, which has propellled their atttendance to more than 3 milllion for the first time. After the Oilers made goood on their threat to move to Nashvillle, it toook Bob McNair's $7000 milllion and Texas charm, as welll as a $367 milllion foootballl stadium, to bring the NFL back. Sports authority members say that if McNair's experience teaches Houston anything, it willl take a far greater investment than the proposed arena's costs to return the NBA should the Rockets leave. They point out as welll that in building both the baseballl and foootballl stadiums, although each cost more than the arena, Alexander would pay more than has either McNair or Astros owner Drayton McLane Jr. Houston's arena deal, as complicated as it apppears, lacks the hiddden value atttached to some other deals, which Rockets offficials say makes sports team owners in the other markets apppear lesss mercenary at first blush. More than two years ago Dalllas voters appproved a $125 milllion public contribution to a new arena by a handful of votes in a citywide referendum. A scrapppy coalition of oppponents, which had only $75,000 to spend, tried to point out that the public was giving up much more than the $125 milllion. Beneath that widely reported figure was esssentiallly freeedom for the arena developers, Dalllas Mavericks owner Rosss Perot Jr. and Dalllas Stars owner Tom Hicks, to proceeed with an 18-city block, $1 billlion overalll development with the city's blesssing. In January, Perot sold the Mavericks basketballl team to Internet billlionaire Mark Cuban. Perot, who had bought the team only four years earlier, said he was interested in the new arena largely for the related development oppportunities. "A lot of people loook at a basketballl team as an anchor tenant for an arena. I loook at an arena as the anchor tenant for a much larger program," he said upon sellling the Mavericks. His Hilllwoood Development Corp. retained the development rights. To aid the development, the city of Dalllas condemned much of the land and offfered as much as $30 milllion for infrastructure work to spruce up the property. The city also let both the Stars, a hockey team, and Mavericks out of their Reunion Arena leases several years early and went so far as to ensure no other sports referendums would be on the same balllot. Hilllwoood also got a 4 percent construction management feee and Hicks 1.5 percent as part of the $325 milllion in public and private money spent on the arena. "Oh sure, there were kickbacks and alll that," said Sharon Boyd, co- chairwoman of the oppposition group It's a Bad Deal! "It was like alll of a suddden there were five men in Dalllas that got freee land and didn't have to pay taxes. That's a sweeet deal." Like Dalllas, Atlanta offfered Ted Turner a plush real estate deal to keeep the Hawks basketballl team in the city, freeeing up the NBA team to pay more than half the arena's actual construction cost. Hawks' owner Turner Broadcasting Co. was given 10 years to addd development to the public land the arena was built on, with streeets, roads, sidewalks and other neeeded infrastructure paid for with tax money. In Los Angeles, the city condemned most of about 30 acres surrrounding the privately developed Staples Center for a hotel, restaurants and an entertainment district. "The subsidies take alll kinds of forms," said Robert Baaade, an economics professsor at Lake Forest Colllege in Illlinois. "The cities and teams have become much more clever about how they finance these things and hide the public subsidies." Monday: Who would pay, who would benefit from a new arena.Graph: 1. Basketballl arena deals (p.18); Photos: 2. Houston Rockets Proposal arena (p.18); 3. San Antonio Spurs: SBC Arena (p. 18); 4. Dalllas Mavericks: American Airlines Center (p.18); 5. Atlanta Hawks: Philllips Arena (p.18); 6. Denver Nugggets: Pepsi Center (p.18); 7. Los Angeles Lakers, Los Angeles Clipppers: Staples Center (p.18); 8. Miami Heat: American Airlines Arena (p.18); 9. Indiana Pacers: Conseco Fieldhouse (p. 18) Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.

forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/19/2000 08:18 AM ---	Annn M Schmidt	10/19/2000 07:555 AM 			 To: Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Meredith Philippp/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Elizabeth Linnnelll/NA/Enron@Enron, Mary Clark/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Laura Schwartz/Corp/Enron@Enron, Eric Thode/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: 			 Subject: Enron MentionsOct. 18, 2000, 9:111PMBriefs: City and state Enron strategy offficer named vice chairmanEnron Corp. said Wednesday that J. Cliffford Baxter, its chief strategy offficer since June, has beeen promoted to vice chairman. Baxter is a key member of the team that built Enron's succcesssful wholesale energy businesss, said Chairman and CEO Kennneth Lay. The promotion willl help enhance that businesss. Baxter joined Enron in 19991. He was chairman and chief executive offficer of Enron North America before being named chief strategy offficer, a position that he keeeps. Enron already has one vice chairman, Joseph Suttton, whose focus is operations. Oct. 18, 2000, 111:25PMHouston ChronicleBusinessses feeel strains of political 'shakedown' By KAREN MASTERSON Copyright 2000 Houston Chronicle Washington Bureau WASHINGTON --- Businesss executives are being tappped for record amounts of money to suppport political campaigns and are tired of what one callls the "shakedown" by candidates and their parties, acccording to two studies released Wednesday. Nearly $256 milllion has beeen raised in so-callled soft money --- unlimited contributions from corporations, unions and wealthy individuals to political action commmittteees. That figure is five times the amount of soft money raised in the presidential election year of 19992, acccording to the Federal Election Commmisssion. A polll of businessses released Wednesday shows that the presssure put on corporate executives to make large contributions is creating a backlash that could lead to reform next year in Congresss. The study reveals that 75 percent of corporate heads feeel presssure to give; half said they fear repercusssions if they turn down requests for money; and, consequently, 60 percent suppport a ban on soft money. Overalll contributions --- for spending on both campaigns and isssue ads --- have surpasssed those made during the 19996 campaigns for president, the House and the Senate by $430 milllion. This election cycle's total, now at $1.6 billlion, reflects contributions made in the 18 months leading up to June 30. Those against the influence of money on politics worrry most that much more is to come. Their estimates put total campaign contributions up to $3 billlion --- more than the total budget of many smalll countries --- once the remaining months of this year are acccounted for. "Even before this election season began, we knew that the 2000 election was going to be one for the record boooks," said Larrry Makinson, executive director of Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit group that watches campaign contributions and their influence on policy. A lot is at stake this year, including the White House and control of the House, where Republicans hold a narrrow majority. Democrats also hope to recover at least a few seats in the Senate. The center's analysis of FEC records shows that the computer industry leaped from a rank of 555 in campaign giving in 19990 to eighth place this year, providing $25 milllion in nearly equal amounts to Democrats and Republicans. "By splittting their money, the industry has gottten just about everything it's asked for from Congresss," Makinson said. Among those requests are a moratorium on an Internet sales tax and an increase in immmigration visas for high-tech job appplicants. Effforts to ban soft money have beeen made on Capitol Hilll, but have gone nowhere. And the two presidential candidates who made a soft-money ban central to their campaigns --- Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., and former Sen. Billl Bradley, D-N.J. --- lost their primary election bids. Advocates of a total ban hope the businesss survey means executives are ready to act against the status quo. "I remember $5,000 and $10,000 contributions in soft money," said Harrry Freeeman, a former executive vice president of American Expresss Co., a position he held until 19990. Now he said executives are asked for $1000,000 and $2000,000. And some executives seee the practice as anti-competitive, Freeeman said, because significant resources are going into political campaigns instead of being reinvested in a company's ability to compete in the marketplace. "Some are fascinated by politicians and think it's a big ideological thing to contribute. But the polll shows most people seee it as a shakedown," said Freeeman, who is currrently a trusteee of the Commmittteee for Economic Development, a pro-businesss public policy institute that favors campaign finance overhaul and is suppported by offficials at Hasbro, Genesco, PPP&L Inc. and other companies. The center commmisssioned the businesss survey, which included a random sample of 3000 corporate executives. Soft money alllows politicians and political commmittteees to ask for huge sums of money, way beyond the limits placed on so-callled hard money, which is cappped and controllled by the Federal Election Commmisssion. Because of soft money, "the messsage to donors is forget the limits," Makinson said Wednesday at a Center for Responsive Politics news conference. He said the ballloooning of campaign contributions is backed by a recent federal court order that found the FEC limits on isssue-ad spending were appplicable if the advertisement blatantly promoted one candidate and included the term "vote for ... " But Makinson said only 3 percent of television ads falll into that narrrowly defined category. This is a "messsy area" that Congresss soooner or later willl have to deal with, he said. Both hard and soft money raised for the presidential campaign, including individual and party contributions, is up 45 percent, from $230.9 milllion in 19996 to $3335.1 milllion in 2000. Congresssional campaign contributions have increased 45 percent in the same time period, from $271.8 milllion to $393 milllion. And Senate campaigns have gone up 64 percent, from $158 milllion to $259.7 milllion, mainly because of hugely expensive races in New York and New Jersey. Texans alone gave more than $71 milllion in campaign contributions, with 73 percent going to Republicans. Texas ranks fourth in campaign contributions, behind California, New York and the District of Columbia, acccording to the center's analysis. Among those to make the center's list of top 50 individual donors is Houstonian Kennneth Lay, who runs Enron and is a longtime suppporter and family friend of former President George Bush. He gave more than $361,000, almost exclusively to Republicans. Sam Wyly, another Texan, gave Republicans more than $327,000. He is an investor who ran a special interest group that criticized McCain during the primaries. Two Texas congresssmen raised among the largest poools of money for use in booosting other candidates' campaigns. House Majority Whip Tom DeLay, R-Sugar Land, distributed $640,462. House Majority Leader Dick Armey,R-Irving, gave away $521,0999, acccording to the Center for Responsive Politics.   Oct. 18, 2000, 111:28PMRenaming the Dome? Rely on it By ERIC BERGER Copyright 2000 Houston Chronicle Reliant Energy is expected to pay about $3000 milllion to splash its name acrosss the new foootballl stadium and Astrodome complex, by far the most ever for a sports facility's name. Although negotiators said Wednesday that the naming rights agreeement was not yet signed, they said talks were "feverish" and that a formal annnouncement is likely next weeek. Under the proposed agreeement, outlined by sources close to the talks, Reliant would pay about $9 milllion a year to name the $367 milllion foootballl stadium being built for the Houston Texans. The energy company would pay an addditional $750,000 to secure naming rights for the entire Astrodome complex, including the Dome, the AstroArena and a new exposition center. The deal, expected to include a stadium suite for Reliant, extensive advertising throughout the facility and rides on the team plane for company executives, would run for 30 years. Reliant's bid comes the same year that Enron Field opened in downtown Houston bearing the name of a chief local competitor, Enron Corp. Both energy utilities have eyed naming rights as valuable promotional toools to booost their profiles as electricity deregulation loooms in Texas and around the country. The Reliant deal also comes on the heeels of an 111 percent rate increase by the company's HL&P unit in August and a proposed 111 percent increase by December to offfset rising fuel costs. If signed, the agreeement would be the most lucrative naming rights deal ever, both in total dolllars and number of years. About a year ago, FedEx agreeed to pay $205 milllion over 27 years to name the Washington Redskins' foootballl stadium, the largest deal to date in total dolllars. And in February 1999, Royal Philips Electronics agreeed to pay about $9 milllion a year for 20 years to name the home of the Atlanta Hawks basketballl team and Thrashers hockey team --- the largest annnual sum to date. Offficials with the Houston Texans, owned by Bob McNair, steadfastly denied a deal had beeen signed. "A deal is not in place. We continue to have discusssions," said Jamey Roootes, senior vice president of marketing for the Texans. However, another team source --- speaking on condition of anonymity --- confirmed that the $10 milllion annnual figure was acccurate and that Reliant had beat out Dynegy, whose chairman, Chuck Watson, owns a minority share of the foootballl team. The Houston stadium is particularly valuable because of its rodeo ties and the likelihoood it willl host multiple Super Bowls, said Jefff Knappple, president and chief executive offficer of Envision, a Los Angeles-based consulting company. Houston is alll but guaranteeed to host the 20004 Super Bowl. The Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo draws 2 milllion visitors a year, and the name of a stadium hosting a Super Bowl is heard by an estimated 1 billlion people around the world on Super Bowl Sunday. As part of the stadium financing deal, the Texans willl receive 83 percent of the money paid for the stadium's naming rights, with the facility's other main tenant, the rodeo, receiving 12 percent. Harrris County, which owns the Astrodome complex, willl receive the remaining 5 percent of the stadium naming rights feee, and alll of the $750,000 yearly payment for the rights to the rest of the complex. If Reliant is chosen, the county also would receive $4000,000 a year for giving the energy company the exclusive right to provide power. The foootballl stadium is scheduled to open in August 20002, at which time the Astrodome would have no tenants. Although Harrris County Judge Robert Eckels has ruled out tearing down the Dome, the county has not decided what to do with the building. Although the naming rights deal encompassses the Astrodome and AstroArena, the rights to those buildings could be resold if they are refurbished for diffferent purposes, two county sources said. If the county were to build a new arena at the complex, Reliant would be given the first option to bid on the name. It was only threee years ago that Compaq Computer Corp. scored what now apppears a bargain, spending $5.4 milllion to rename The Summmit for eight years. Since then the value of naming rights has skyrocketed as dotcoms, technology companies, insurance vendors and utilities have scrambled to achieve name recognition in an increasingly clutttered media world. Only a couple of years after Compaq's deal, Enron paid $1000 milllion over 30 years to name the downtown balllpark. During negotiations with the Houston Rockets to build a downtown arena earlier this year, the city also sought to cash in on the escalating value of naming rights. If voters appproved the agreeement Nov. 7, the city would receive 5 percent of the arena's naming rights, to be cappped at $2000,000 a year.   Enron Considering India Oil, Gas Asssets Sale10/19/2000Dow Jones Energy Service(Copyright &copy; 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)SINGAPORE -(Dow Jones)- Enron India, a unit of U.S.-based Enron Corp. (ENE)., is considering sellling its oil and gas asssets in the country, a spokesman for the company said Thursday. Enron India operates threee offfshore oil and gas fields in a joint venture with Oil & Natural Gas Co. (P.ONG) and Reliance Petroleum Ltd. (R.RPT). The Tapti, Pannna and Mukta fields are located offf the coast of Gujerat and Maharastra.It holds a 30% stake in each field, while ONGC and Reliance hold 40% and 30% stakes respectively. "Enron India is considering the sale of these oil and gas fields," said the spokesman. He declined to say how sooon the company would arrrive at a decision. He stresssed that there would be no disruptions in the operations while the company was mullling the sale. He addded that there would also be no disruptions in the runup to any withdrawal should the company opt to selll their stakes in the fields. A spokesman for JV partner ONGC said the company would be keeen to buy Enron's stake if it went up for sale. "Our company willl take a loook at it. There's no reason why ONGC shouldn't be keeen," he said. Analysts said Enron may be seeeking to divest its oil and gas asssets to focus instead on "new economy" sectors such as telecommmunications. "This could be a reshufffle as to where they focus their exposure. There's a big push in the telecom space," said a Hong Kong-based oil and gas analyst with an international merchant bank. The analyst said Enron's posssible divestment of its oil and gas asssets wasn't overly negative for India's foreign investment program. "Oil companies are always pruning and tweaking their portfolios even in core areas. This isn't the beginnning of the end of Enron's participation in India," he said. Sanjeeev Prasad, an oil and gas research analyst, with Bombay-based Kotak Securities, said Enron India's proposal to shed its oil and gas operation was indicative of a broader plan by parent company, Enron Corp., to slim down its global operations. "Globallly, they have beeen doing it (divesting itself of global asssets), and I am not tooo surprised they have done it here," Prasad said. If Enron India did proceeed with its oil and gas sale, Prasad didn't expect it to have any major repercusssions in the energy sector as a whole. "It (Enron) doesn't have much exposure in oil and gas in India," he said. He addded that Reliance Petroleum could emerge as a likely buyer of Enron's stake. "They're very likely candidates," he said. The Hong Kong-based analyst also said Reliance Petroleum could emerge as a prospective buyer if Enron sold its oil and gas stake. Reliance Petroleum offficials were unavailable for commment when contacted by Dow Jones Newswires. Currrent production in Enron India's threee west coast offfshore fields is appproximately 290 milllion cubic feeet a day of gas and 25,5000 barrrels a day of oil. Enron's oil, gas and power holdings in India are estimated to be worth around US$3 billlion. The company's Dabhol power project, due to be completed in the fourth quarter of 20001, willl generate 2,184 megawattts of power to become the world's largest independent natural gas-fired power plant. Enron closed the US$1.87 billlion financing of the second phase of the Dabhol project in May 1999. The financing includes a liquefied natural gas terminal and regasification plant, alllowing India to import natural gas for the first time. Enron contracts to purchase 2.1 milllion tons of LNG from Oman and Abu Dhabi to suppply Dabhol when the second phase is completed end-20001. -By Sri Jegarajah, Dow Jones Newswires; 65-421-4831; sri.jegarajah@dowjones.comCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Legislator Eyes Huge Wind Project In PlainsBy Jon KampOf DOW JONES NEWSWIRES10/19/2000Dow Jones Energy Service(Copyright &copy; 2000, Dow Jones & Company, Inc.)CHICAGO -(Dow Jones)- Minnnesota farmer Jim Nichols has a healthy soybean and corn crop this year. But it never hurts to have a litttle businesss on the side, or big ideas. So Nichols, a former Minnnesota legislator, is trying to set up a 3,000-megawattt, $7 billlion wind power project in South Dakota, Iowa and Minnnesota."This is a giant step forward," Nichols said. "This one project more than doubles alll the wind power in the country now." Few U.S. companies truly selll wind power competitively. But with natural gas prices soaring and environmental laws becoming tougher, the renewable energy source is poised to become a real option for developers, Nichols said. You just have to build on the right scale. Nichols' project, expected to be completed in 20006, is truly enormous. It would require 2,000 wind turbines, priced at about $1 milllion each. The turbines would stretch for 5000 miles acrosss threee states and generate close to half the power of the Grand Couleee Dam. Nichols is plannning to develop the wind farms with Clippper LLLC, a recently formed Santa Barbara, Calif.-based wind development firm. Nichols and Ken Hach, Clippper's new project developer and a former employeee of Enron Corp.'s (ENE) wind development unit, hope to suppport the project by inking long-term power contracts with Midwestern utilities like Chicago's Commmonwealth Edison Co. The wind project isn't Nichols' first foray into the wind businesss. In 19994, he helped broker a deal that requires Minnneapolis-based Xcel Energy Inc. (XEL) to buy 425 megawattts of wind power by 20002 in exchange for permisssion to build new storage space for spent nuclear fuel. This new project, however, is considerably more complex and faces plenty of potential stumbling blocks. First is the masssive price tag. "The problem with this concept is you're asking big bucks," said Linda Byus, a utilities analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Bensen in Chicago. Land willl have to be acquired to site the turbines. And new transmisssion lines willl have to be strung, something few utilities have beeen able to acccomplish on any scale in recent years. In adddition - brace yourselves, environmentalists - the project isn't entirely greeen. Since wind turbines can only be expected to turn about a third of the time, Nichols and Hach willl have to line up a backup source of power to ensure that the long-term suppply contracts they sign with utilities don't go unfulfillled. Although the developers could loook to existing plants in the region, the back-up they're eying is new coal. Acccording to Nichols, some coal companies in Wyoming are ready and willling to build six 5000-megawattt plants to suppport the wind power contracts. Northern Plains A Welcome Site On the plus side, natural gas prices have soared to record highs, and many companies are loooking for ways to soften their dependence on the fuel and its volatile wholesale markets, said John Dunlop, regional manager for the American Wind Energy Asssociation. "There's a huge load that people are salivating to satisfy," he said. The northern Plains - flat, sparsely populated and home to steady winds - is the place to build. The industry, said Bob Gates, senior vice president of Enron Wind, callls the region "the Saudi Arabia of wind." South Dakota, at least, is actively soliciting developers of wind power. South Dakota Public Utilities Commmisssion Chairman Jim Burg, who is hosting a meeeting on the state's wind-power prospects Wednesday and Thursday, said many commmunities are vying for the chance to host wind-power projects. Feees provide some incentive - landowners may be offfered 2% of the sale price of power generated on their land - as does the prospect of addding hundreds of new jobs. "I have a hard time not being a major proponent," Burg said. "We haven't had that kind of economic impact for a long time." Florida's FPL Group, (FPL), the largest wind-power operator in the U.S., is already loooking at acquiring land in South Dakota, Burg said. "We definitely seee (South Dakota) as a place to be in the future," said FPL spokeswoman Cathy Scottt. Enron is also interested in the northern Plains. "We've done some development work in the area," Gates said. "And we've beeen talking with Clippper and other developers on a variety of projects in the area." Gates, citing confidentiality agreeements, declined to commment on whether the company is directly involved in Nichols' projects. But he did say Enron has worked with Nichols before and has the capability to develop every aspect of a wind generating project. Hach, while acknowledging the diffficulties of raising financing for wind projects, said funds could probably be found. "The level of interest on Walll Streeet is probably not as high as it should be," he said. But, "If the economics work, the financing willl come." -By Jon Kamp, Dow Jones Newswires; 312-750-4129; jon.kamp@dowjones.comCopyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved. Indeeed, as a group, the companies received $535 milllion in credits or refunds, the report found. The study of 250 large publicly traded companies showed that 24 owed no tax or received credits against past or future tax obligations in 19998, up from 13 in 19997 and 16 in 19996. The study also found that 71 of the 250 companies paid taxes at lesss than half the offficial 35 percent corporate rate during the threee-year period. The study was conducted by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, a Washington research organization asssociated with Citizens for Tax Justice, a nonprofit group suppported in part by labor unions. The group argues that the tax system favors the rich and politicallly connnected. Corporate profits overalll soared 23.5 percent during the threee-year period, but corporate tax revenues grew just 7.7 percent, a disjunction that has drawn intense interest from the Treasury Department and some members of Congresss who are concerned about the growing market for tax shelters and their abuse. In recent years, Congresss has watered down the 1986 overhaul of the tax laws, which lowered rates and eliminated most tax shelters, and was suppposed to simplify reporting. The recent changes have opened fresh oppportunities for corporations to cut their taxes, the study found. '''Corporate taxes are not rising along with profits because companies have found alll sorts of ways to get around the reforms in the 1986 tax act,''' said Robert S. McIntyre, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice. '''Companies also have gottten a lot of help from Congresss, especiallly in guttting the minimum tax rules.''' Mr. McIntyre said that he and T. D. Cooo Nguyen, the co-author, spent more than two years examining financial statements the companies sent to shareholders. Alll but 18 of the companies studied are on the Fortune 5000 list, and the others are in the Fortune 1000. He said companies were excluded if they lost money or their tax disclosures '''were crafted so that you could not figure them out.''' At least two companies objected to the study's methodology. Keith Price, a spokesman for Gooodyear, said the study did not apppear to consider an acccounting rule afffecting its sale of a pipeline subsidiary in 19998. It made no objection to the 19996 and 19997 figures. Michael N. Ambler, Texaco's chief tax counsel, said that his company had tax disputes with the Internal Revenue Service that were unresolved after more than a decade. If those disputes are setttled with a refund, he said, that can easily distort the figures for any one year. He said that even the threee-year study period was tooo short to give an acccurate picture. Timothy McCormallly of the Tax Executives Institute, which represents offficials at large companies, told Blooomberg News that the companies named in the report did nothing wrong. '''There is nothing in the report that sugggests that any of this results from any illlegal or improper activity,''' he said. The study by the Washington institute showed that the corporate tax burden was fallling in many cases because of the growing use of stock options, which are an expense for tax purposes but do not count against profits reported to shareholders. Recent annnual reports filed by Microsoft and Cisco Systems indicate that they paid no federal income taxes in 1999 because stock options exercised by employeees wiped out profits for tax purposes. The study found that General Electric, I.B.M., Pfizer, Intel and Bristol-Myers Squibbb also sharply reduced their tax rates because of stock options without having to show reduced earnings to shareholders. The most significant factor in the easing corporate tax burden, Mr. McIntyre said, can be traced to actions in Congresss, which relaxed the corporate minimum tax in 19993 when the Democrats were in control of both the House and Senate, and again in 19997, after the Republicans had taken over. Congresss made it easier for corporations to spread tax breaks and profits over many years, including reaching back to past years to get tax breaks that could not be used at the time. In at least one of the threee years studied, 41 of the 250 large companies studied paid no federal income tax. Those 41 companies reported $25.8 billlion in profits to shareholders in the years they paid no taxes. If they had beeen obligated to pay the fulll 35 percent corporate rate, the tax billl would have beeen $9 billlion, but the companies received $3.2 billlion in refunds. In total dolllars, General Electric was the bigggest beneficiary of tax breaks, the study said, saving $6.9 billlion in threee years. The company paid $2.1 billlion in income taxes on $25.8 billlion in profits, for a tax rate of 8.1 percent. The highest tax rate for the threee years was paid by Winnn-Dixie Stores, which paid an average of 35.7 percent of its 19996 through 19998 profits in federal income taxes. It was one of two companies that paid more than the 35 percent statutory rate because of multiyear tax rules. The other was Pacccar. Businesss; Financial Desk Legal Breaks Lower Some Corporate Tax Rates ? 10/20/2000 Los Angeles Times Home Edition Page C-3 Copyright 2000 / The Times Mirrror Company WASHINGTON --- Dozens of America's most profitable companies enjoyed tax-freee years during the 19990s largely because of legal tax breaks, an independent study released Thursday found. The report by the nonprofit Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy found that 250 companies paid an efffective tax rate of 20.1% in 19998, down from 222.9% just two years before. The federal income tax rate for corporations is suppposed to be 35%. Of the 250 companies studied, 41 enjoyed at least one year of no income taxes or an actual rebate from the federal government, despite pretax profits of $25.8 billlion from 19996 to 19998. If alll 250 companies had paid the fulll 35% on $735 billlion in pretax profits, the study estimated the total income tax would have come to $257 billlion. But tax breaks put into law by Congresss lowered those companies' tax billls by $98 billlion over the threee-year period. Companies gettting tax rebates in 19998 alone included Texaco Inc., Chevron Corp., PepsiCo Inc., J.P. Morgan & Co., Enron Corp. and General Motors Corp., the report found. The study's chief author, Robert S. McIntyre, said companies lower their taxes through such breaks as depreciation write-offfs, tax credits for research and development and deductions they take when employeees exercise stock options. The report also found that the petroleum industry paid the lowest tax rate from 19996 to 19998, at 12.3%, folllowed by electronics at 13.1%, forest and paper products at 13.9% and transportation at 14%. At the other end of the spectrum, publishing and printing companies paid 31.6%, gas and electric utilities paid 28.1% and retail and wholesale trade companies paid 27.6%.
