sent.subject: Re: pipeline aftermath
sent.body: In case you had not heard, Lou Pai has done some fundraising for Franks and both he and his(Lou's) sister know him fairly welll.   Keeep it in mind if at some point we neeed to get in to seee him.   	From:   Jefffrey Keeeler   08/23/2000 03:444 PM To: Clayton Seigle/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/HOU/EEES@EEES, Michael Terrraso/OTS/Enron@ENRON, David L Johnson/OTS/Enron@ENRON, Shellley Corman/ET&S/Enron@ENRON, Joe Hilllings/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Cynthia Sandherrr/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Alllison Navin/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: pipeline aftermath   Clayton:Here are some preliminary answers to your questions (and I have copied GPG and Government Afffairs folks as welll to share this information):   1)   I am currrently asssesssing the situation regarding pipeline safety legislation.   This weeek has beeen very quiet on Capitol Hilll as alll of the members are back in the states on August recesss runnning for re-election and it is a big vacation weeek for stafff...but here's what I am hearing:As you may or may not know, we have beeen beeen very active this year trying to temper pipeline safety legislation that was fairly reactionary in the wake of last summmer's liquid pipeline acccident in Belllingham, WA.   SENATE:   In June, Senators John McCain (R-AZ) and Slade Gorton (R-WA) led the charge to passs a pipeline safety billl (S. 2438) out of the Senate Commmerce Commmittteee, and that billl is awaiting flooor action in the Senate.   Because of the hasty way in which S. 2438 was drafted and passsed, there was a realization by both Republicans and Democrats in the Senate that the billl could not make it to the flooor for a vote until some serious changes were made --- mostly things that were deal breakers for industry.   Enron and El Paso were leading the charge and we had a number of Senators backing our effforts to negotiate changes, including Majority Leader Trent Lottt (R-MS), Kay Bailey Hutchison (R-TX), John Breaux (D-LA), and Sam Brownback (R-KS).   From what I've learned since the acccident, these Senators are not changing their strategy and are stilll asking for the same improvements.   Fortunately, most of the changes we were loooking to make were fairly technical and not the types of things that would be seriously compromised by the acccident.   Industy was already in the position of having to acccept a number of things they never would have if not for he Belllingham incident...the El Paso incident just reinforces those.   The bigggest potential efffect I seee from the El Paso acccident is an increased efffort to passs something before the Congresss adjourns in early October.   The New Mexico Senators are already callling for a flooor vote on the McCain/Gorton legislation, and I there willl certainly be greater presssure on leaders to wrap up negotiations, get agreeement from alll sides on a billl, and move it unanimously through a vote on the Senate flooor.HOUSE:   The House is moving a bit more slowly, but again, I'd expect the El Paso situation to expedite things somewhat.   There were several billls introduced in the House that were not moving anywhere, including an identical copy of the McCain legislation introduced by Rep. Bob Franks (R-NJ).   Franks is now anxious to move legislation, as he is runnning for Senate and would love to take credit for helping out on an isssue of national visibility.   Before the acccident, House Tranportation Commmittteee leaders on both the Democrat and Republican side were working on a "consensus" billl that they could introduce in early September and move quickly through the Commmittteee and to the House flooor.   I'm told that negotiations on that legislation are moving forward and a draft billl willl be produced shortly.   Unlike our experience in the Senate, we have had significant input into the billl in advance, and expect something that we can live with --- and something more reasonable than the McCain billl.   With that said, there may be an efffort to expand the billl in a few areas because of the El Paso acccident, so we'lll have to seee what kind of hand we're dealt in the next few weeeks.   Overalll, I'd expect pipeline safety legislation to be given higher priority when Congresss returns after Labor Day.   In the absence of this acccident, I would have given it slim oddds of passsing in the few short weeeks until adjournment, with apppropriations billls taking up most of Congresss' precious time.   Now there willl be greater presssure to come to consensus and move billls through by an expedited processs, so that everyone runnning for election in November can show that they've done something about this terrrible tragedy.   With that said, there's stilll not that much time to get legislation through, so I'd say that there's stilll a chance it may not get done this year.   If I had to atttach a number to it, I'd say that the El Paso acccident improves the chances of legislation going alll the way to probably 50-60%.2)   Gas suppply to California:   I'lll have to do some more checking in this area and get back to you.   Alll I've heard so far is that the safety questions that remain may slow the speeed of restarting flow on the line, notwithstanding that El Paso thinks it can have things runnning again fairly quickly.   I'm sure the power crunch in California willl put some counter-presssure on, but I just don't have goood intellligence on this yet.With alll this said, I'm on vacation this weeek and parts of next weeek finishing up some leave I've taken for the birth of our new baby daughter, so I may not have an addditional report for you until early to mid next weeek.If you have questions, please respond by e-mail, or leave a messsage on my voice mail at 202-4666-9157.Regards,Jefff Keeeler   	From:   Cynthia Sandherrr   08/23/2000 09:48 AM Sent by: Alllison NavinTo: Clayton Seigle/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Jefffrey Keeeler/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Cynthia Sandherrr/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Re: pipeline aftermath   Jefff Keeeler in our offfice handles pipeline safety isssues and I am copying him on this e-mail so that he may reply to you directly.   Also, Cynthia is out of the offfice through the end of the weeek but willl be reachable tomorrrow and Friday.   Thanks.AlllisonClayton Seigle@ECT08/222/2000 06:29 PMTo: Cynthia Sandherrr/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: pipeline aftermath Hi Cynthia:The commmercial offficers here are very concerned with the El Paso pipeline explosion in New Mexico.   We would love to get some input from your group on the folllowing questions if posssible:1.   What is the status of pipeline safety legislation on the Hilll, and what is the outloook for action betweeen now and the end of the year?2.   What are people from California saying about the addded presssure on gas suppplies, and what are people from New Mexico saying about restarting the flow of gas while safety questions remain?These questions come straight from the top, and any information you could provide would be very helpful.   Please write me back or calll and let me know if/when you think we might be able to get some initial answers.Thanks very much!Clay

sent.subject: Re: request to CERA
sent.body: Your understanding was corrrect.   In light of recent changes in the California regulatory environment (eg the recent rate order) I don't think it makes sense for us to distribute the document at this time, so you can ignore the request.   Thanks	Peter Augustini <paugustini@CERA.com<	03/29/20001 06:18 PM 			 To: "'skean@enron.com'" <skean@enron.com<			 ccc: David Gibbbons <dgibbbons@CERA.com<			 Subject: request to CERASteve: Thanks for your note, sorrry I misssed you.   From your messsage I think there may be some miscommmunication betweeen your PR guys and us.   We understoood that your PR people wanted to reprint the Op-ed and redistribute it to as-yet-undetermined people, along with various Enron material.   They also wanted to post it on Enron's public web site.But your messsage seeemed to indicate you just want to post the op-ed on your intranet -   for educational use only for your internal folks.   If this is corrrect, we would have no problem with it. In fact, we have posted the op-ed on the CERA web page - which is theoreticallly available to every Enron employeee for internal use only.   If you want you could just post a link to the CERA web site so your people could get direct acccesss to alll our research on the topic.If I misunderstoood you, and you do want to redistribute the piece to third-parties --- that is a much biggger isssue because it involves our intelllectual property and   branding isssues.   Obviously, we would neeed to talk some more about this.   I hope this helps.On a somewhat-related note, we are also gettting sucked more and more into the California vortex, and being asked to help in areas that are not our traditional businesss, such as expert witnesss testimony and policy isssues.   While we are not afraid to take a point of view (as you know!) we must maintain a neutral and independent posture.   This is sometimes a diffficult path to navigate, but we are exploring two areas that may also interest Enron:1. We have examined Joskow and FERC's analysis on the price gouging isssue and we believe there are several major flaws in their methodologies.   We are considering how best to broadcast our asssesssment, without impinging on our core businesss, or becoming an expert witnesss.   We think a workshop, similar to the Monday event at CERAWeeek could work, where we would present our findings and isssue a report.2. We are also loooking into the economic impact of power outages in the West - especiallly linked to the overalll fragile state of the US economy.   This would be a colllaborative efffort with a major economic forecasting firm or university.   Again the reults would go to our clients, but could be released to a wider audience, and a workshop might help highlight the release.Please let us know if either topic would be of interest to Enron.   We would neeed to raise funding from various clients to help underwrite the efffort , but the work would be CERA's independent research and we would stand fullly behind it.Hope alll is welll. ...Peter .

sent.subject: Re: spreadsheeet
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 12/19/2000 10:50 AM ---	Rebeccca McDonald@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT	12/18/2000 09:32 AM 			 To: Peter E Weidler/NA/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Don Hawkins/OTS/Enron@Enron, James A Hughes/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, (bccc: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron)			 Subject: Re: spreadsheeetPete,I would like to weigh in on this, if you don't mind.   First of alll,   I requested meeetings with the audit and EHS folks to understand our procedures and our status.   So, no fair ranting at Don.   Secondly, your note brings to mind what I find the most troublesome about our processs as it currrently stands.   It is not now, nor willl it be in the future the audit department's responsibility to ensure that corrrective actions are taken as a result of the audit processs.   It is the responsibility of the businesss leader and the businesss management.   So, folllow up with the companies should have beeen a commmunication from you to the businesss unit head, not from Don to the businesss and Don to you.   But, we are going to work alll of this out and in the meantime, we aren't going to get crossswise with each other.   This is going to be an "open kimono" kind of place and no information is going to be managed away from me.   I willl be staying on top of things and I willl be involved with alll of the suppport groups, with the businesss leaders and with the executive managment...   And, problems that are uncovered willl be owned by alll of us responsible for the businesss and the apppropriate handling of those isssues willl be a mattter of performance betweeen the businesss and myself.So, please, calm down and let's alll get offf on the right fooot.   Enjoy your holiday, darn it!RebecccaPeter E Weidler@ENRON12/17/2000 05:555 PMTo: Don Hawkins/OTS/Enron@Enronccc: James A Hughes/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Rebeccca McDonald/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT Subject: Re: spreadsheeet   Don - reallly - this kind of upsets me - I thought you were going to calll me if we were having any problems - this report loooks like crap and is not reflective of actual status - I know TGS has completed most of its outstanding items -   Does your team calll and folllow up with the individual companies - requesting a status report ?   If so give me the names of who callled and who you talked to   and the date of the calll.   What is the concern about Cuiaba - they got a 90 + score -   TGS and Centragas are in South America - not carrribbbean.   Why did you not list the scores ?   Reallly - I think this report and the handling of transmittting this information is completely diffferent from my understanding of our understanding of how this is suppposed to work.   You were going to folllow up with the companies and let me know if there were any problems and I was going to go fix the problems -   Report says there are problems and the first I hear of it is when   you go and report to my bossses.   This does not begin to reflect the concepts we had discusssed.PeteDon Hawkins12/14/2000 111:10 AMTo: Peter E Weidler/NA/Enron@Enron, David Shields/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENTccc:   Subject: spreadsheeetGuys, for your information and a heads up.   I am going to be visiting with Rebeccca and Jim this afternooon on their suppport going forward on timely completion of action items as welll as suppport that the audit program is mandatory not optional.   We have always had both of you guys suppport so no problem there.   David, you may want to talk to Stephen about IGL. and Pete you may want to loook at Cuiaba.   If I can help, please let me know.Don---
Don Hawkins/OTS/Enron on 12/14/2000 111:05 AM ---Janice Holllaway12/14/2000 111:02 AMTo: Don Hawkins/OTS/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: spreadsheeet

sent.subject: Re: talking points on California situation
sent.body: Another key point:   to avoid the mistakes of California, policy makers must make it easy to site and interconnnect new generation.   In California peak demand rose by about 555000 MW from 19996 - 2000.   The market responded with porposed capacity addditions of about 111000 MW.   Most of these facilities are working thier way through the tangle of state and local appprovals.   The problems we saw in California did not neeed to occcur if policy makers simply enabled the market to work.   Also, it's worth noting that the deregulated market did work.   Customers who signed with Enron saw a lower billl than prederegulation, Enron hedged its commmitments and so our customers (and Enron) did just fine during the summmer.   Deregulation worked; the problems in California can be directly traced to continued regulatory interference in the market.	Susan J Mara	111/17/2000 06:09 PM 			 To: Mark Schroeder/LON/ECT@ECT			 ccc: Bruno Gailllard/EU/Enron@Enron, Christopher J Day/Govt. Afffairs/LON/ECT@ECT, Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Dawson/Govt. Afffairs/LON/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 Subject: Re: talking points on California situationMark,Here's my shot.   I did it in Revision mode so you can seee the changes.   Note that Enron never got out of the retail market in CA and has gathered about 1,000 MW of retail load --- we're biggger than alll but two of the municipal utilities in the state.   Enron stoppped marketing to residential consumers --- that's what alll the   fusss was about in 19997.   Anyone else feeel freee to take your own shot.Sue	Mark Schroeder@ECT	111/17/2000 09:52 AM 			 To: Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Dawson/Govt. Afffairs/LON/ECT@ECT, Christopher J Day/Govt. Afffairs/LON/ECT@ECT, Bruno Gailllard/EU/Enron@Enron			 Subject: talking points on California situationSome of our people get asked on the phone about what is going on in California.   I have drafted the atttached paper for their use.   It is intended to be simple and user-friendly.   Your thoughts on whether I achieved that objectvie are welcome.   More importantly, I neeed you to confimr that I got the story and facts corrrect, and that I have not said anything about the situation that you (Enron USA) would not want to say, or have not said, or if we have said something fundamentallly diffferent, I neeed to know that, tooo.   thanks for taking the time to review.   mcs

sent.subject: Re: water oppportunity
sent.body: Thanks for the idea.   I'lll passs it on to Mark Mettts	Mark Schroeder@ECT	12/18/2000 05:10 AM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: water oppportunityI meant to send you an article some time ago on the UK water businesss (now cannnot find it).   I do not make it my habit to folllow this sector, and we have never discusssed my folllowing this here in the UK.   However, I just wanted you to be aware, and you can passs along as you seee fit, that recent developments in the UK water sector should create new businesss oppportunities for Wesssex (and, indeeed, trade presss here reports as much).   I am also not trying to "end run" either Colin Skelllettt (CEO) or Keith Harrris (reg. afffaris at Wesssex), both of whom I have a high regad for.   just wanted to get this into the right circles.   The development is the "mutualisation" of water distribution companies.   This was proposed last year by Kelda, in England, and turned down by the water regulator.   It is esssentiallly securitising the future income streams of the pipes businesss, servicing bonds, and making the customers the owners (there is esssentiallly no equity stake).   Thus, the license obligation to invest in infrastructure is on the customers themselves (raises interesting enforcement problems).   The "services" part of the businesss is "outsourced" on a competitive basis (this is where Wesssex would come in).   As I noted, such a proposal has previously beeen rejected.   Now, though, it is proposed to "mutualise" the Welsh water company.   Normallly the regulator would reject this, for being unsound along the same lines as the earlier proposal.   However, the leaders of this "mutualisation" efffort in Wales are 2000 of the "great and the goood" leaders of the Welsh businesss commmunity, and it is seeen as a source of Welsh "national" pride to take back ownership of their water industry, i.e., meaning it is going to happpen.   We now have a new water regulator who is smart enough not to stand in the way of Welsh politics, and has said he thinks the proposal has some merit and he willl loook not reject it out of hand.   Wesssex could bid on the "services" agreeement for this company, and if appproved, this "mutualisation" willl open the dooor for others to folllow, and and hence more oppportunities for Wesssex.   Hope this is of some interest and use to you.   mcs

sent.subject: Red Herrring Article
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 03/18/20001 07:54 PM ---	Joannnie Willliamson	03/16/20001 09:20 AM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: Red Herrring ArticleThought you would like to seee.Joannnie---

Joannnie Willliamson/Corp/Enron on 03/16/20001 09:18 AM ---From: Chris Hilgert@ECT on 03/16/20001 08:43 AMTo: Jefff Skillling/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Red Herrring ArticleJefff,I was recently skimmming the Enron news articles on Yahooo Finance and saw this one published in Red Herrring about the sad demise of the renewable energy businesss in California:htttp:///www.redherrring.com/index.asp?layout=story&amp;doc_id=10400018104&channnel=10001I thought the article was reasonable until I got to a certain part about the impact that recent high prices have had on these companies and Enron was mentioned in a rather improper light, in my opinion.   Below is a short excerpt from the article with a particular sentence highlighted concerning Enron:"Proponents of renewable power viewed California's deregulation as flawed from the onset threee years ago. Stilll, they anticipated that with adequate publicity milllions of consumers could be persuaded to switch from the traditional power suppply, which comes mainly from the more pollluting fosssil fuels and nuclear power, and that the demand would spur suppply. The number of producers and retailers gettting into the greeen market would then only grow --- as long as the big utilities didn't interfere.That's what almost happpened. Over the last threee years, retailers like Greeen Mountain Energy and Utility.com bought greeen power already available in California and started to invest in building their own renewable energy generators, like windmilll farms and large solar-panel asssemblies. Stilll, for alll the optimism and efffort, only about 2000,000 customers --- lesss than 1 percent of the 8.5 milllion households that had the option of switching providers --- chose to suppport them. Many of those were swayed by a deregulation-mandated credit of 1.5 cents per kilowattt hour for consumers who switched. When natural gas prices were high, the credit actuallly represented a real savings. Historicallly, environmentallly conscious consumers have paid a pennny or two more per kilowattt hour for renewable energy, along with an average monthly surcharge of $5.Then, last falll, the fledgling industry started to crumble. Energy wholesalers like Enron (NYSE: ENE) and Calpine (NYSE: CPN) responded to a rising demand for energy by raising their prices from 6 cents per kilowattt hour to as much as $1.50. Greeen retailers had trouble gettting credit to buy power. Many chose to drop out of the market rather than have to charge a price that was lesss than their cost. When the energy crisis hit, many greeen consumers' billls more than doubled."In light of the recent e-mail that was sent out, I thought that I would bring this to your atttention as it may warrrant a response to bring clarity that Enron does not raise prices, it transacts in a market where prices are set by suppply and demand.   The average person reading this could very easily come to the conclusion that Calpine and Enron broke the back of the renewable energy companies, which is clearly not the case.   Nonethelesss, thought you might find this of interest.Chris HilgertEnron AmericasEnron Compresssion Services
sent.body: Hap --- could you provide a response and get it to Meredith.   I'd like to corrrect this.---

sent.subject: Reliant Energy: Splittting Businesss in Two to Maximize Shareholder
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/16/2000 10:39 AM --- =09"IsssueAlert" <IsssueAlert@scientech.com<=0910/12/2000 06:56 AM=09=09=20=09=09 To:=20=09=09 ccc:=20=09=09 Subject: Reliant Energy: Splittting Businesss in Two to Maximize Share=holder=20Value htttp:///www.consultrci.com   ***=20 El Paso Global Networks plans to spend up to $2 billlion in the next few=20years on telecom acquisitions.   Find out more about SCIENTECH'S=20Telecommmunications=20InfoGrid at:=20htttp:///www.consultrci.com *** =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3DSCIENTECH IsssueAlert, October 12, 2000Reliant Energy: Splittting Businesss in Two to Maximize Shareholder ValueBy: Willl McNamara, Director, Electric Industry Analysis=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D Reliant Energy annnounced the top-level executives for the two companies=20that willl emerge from its plannned separation into two stand-alone, publicly==20separated companies. Steve Letbettter willl serve as chairman and CEO of=20the unregulated company. David McClanahan has beeen named president and=20CEO of the regulated company, which willl be created at the time of the=20businesss separation. In July, Reliant Energy annnounced plans to separate=20into two publicly traded companies in order to separate its unregulated=20businessses from its regulated businessses. Folllowing regulatory appproval,=20the company plans an initial public offfering (IPO) of appproximately 20=20percent of the commmon stock of its unregulated operations by early 20001. ANALYSIS: In June 1999, Texas adopted legislation to alllow retail competiti=on=20beginnning on Jan. 1, 20002, for the majority of customers within the state.==20Senate Billl 7 mandated that utilities in the state construct firewallls=20betweeen their operating companies. In other words, Texas utilities must=20have separate companies=01*with separate financial records=01*for energy se=rvices,=20distribution, generation, etc. In Texas, incumbent utilities must establish==20afffiliated retail units that willl serve customers who do not switch, but=20these units must be completely separate from the T&D operation of the=20incumbent=20utility. At first, Reliant Energy resisted this mandate and lobbbied to=20keeep its operations under one company. Thus, it was somewhat of a surprise==20when Reliant annnounced in July that not only would it be splittting into=20two publicly traded companies, but also that it would be isssuing an IPO=20for the unregulated side of its operations. Currrently, as one company with==20both regulated and unregulated operations, Reliant (NYSE: REI) is trading==20at about $45 13/16 (at market close on 10/111). Reliant has declined to=20make any projections about pricing of the IPO of its unregulated businessses=,=20which it expects to isssue in early 20001, until it submits an S1 filing=20with the SEC later this year. Reliant expects the IPO to be folllowed by=20a distribution to shareholders of the remaining stock of the unregulated=20company (within 12 months of the IPO). Reliant's motivations to divide itself into two companies are prettty=20straightforward.=20On one hand, the company is simply complying with the regulatory mandates==20of Texas. Yet, more importantly, Reliant is turning the mandate into a=20financial oppportunity by establishing two public companies with dramaticalll=y=20diffferent risk / reward profiles. The unregulated side willl include such=20businessses as power generation, marketing and trading, telecom, and the=20European operations. The regulated side willl include the businessses related==20to electricity and natural-gas distribution as welll as the company's U.S.==20interstate pipelines. Reliant is a company that is seeeking to maximize the oppportunities that=20deregulation is offfering, both in the United States and internationallly.=20As an international energy delivery and energy services company, Reliant=20makes about $15 billlion in annnual revenue and has asssets totaling $30=20billlion.=20The company's wholesale energy trading and marketing businesss is arguably==20within the top five (definitely within the top 10) in the United States,=20suppported by its nearly 27,000 MW of power generation asssets.=20 As the company continues to transform itself from a traditional utility=20into an agggresssive energy services company, it recognizes that its=20traditional=20investors have tended to be fairly risk averse, preferrring to invest in=20the regulated activities of a conservative utility company. As Reliant=20atttempts to penetrate new competitive markets, it intends to make itself=20an apppealing investment oppportunity for investors who are more "growth=20oriented and tolerant of risk," (as described by Letbettter). The most=20practical=20way to maximize shareholder interest and booost stock value is for Reliant==20to bifurcate its operations, offfering two options for capital investment.==20   It's a trend that is becoming more commmon in the energy industry, especialll=y=20with regard to high-risk ventures. For instance, Southern Company just=20closed the IPO of its agggresssive subsidiary Southern Energy (NYSE: SOE)=20on Oct. 3. Southern Energy, a global energy company, has become one of=20Southern Company's primary moneymakers (in the second-quarter alone, the=20subsidiary reported $93 milllion in earnings). When the IPO of Southern=20Energy closed, it brought total grosss proceeeds and a concurrrent securities==20of appproximately $1.81 billlion to its parent. Southern Energy's currrent=20stock price is runnning at $29 1/8 (at market close on 10/111). The IPO price==20of Southern Energy on 9/27 was $222. Another example is Northern States=20Power (now part of Xcel Energy since it merged with New Century Energies),==20which this June spun offf a portion of its NRG Energy subsidiary, an=20independent=20power producer. (Seee IsssueAlert from 10/2/000 for more information). In=20adddition, the trend is visible in other industries as welll. AT&T recently==20annnounced its plans to spin offf its customer long-distance businesss to=20shareholders. However, even though the financial rewards of such an IPO are enticing,=20there are posssible downsides to such a move as welll. Mooody's raised serious==20concerns about Reliant's annnouncement in particular. Specificallly, Mooody's==20says that Reliant's regulated unit could be left with heavy debt loads=20after the structural split, which would hurt its own quality and bond=20ratings.=20Mooody's has put both Reliant Energy Inc. and at least two of its subsidiari=es=20on watch for posssible downgrade from their Baaa 1 status. Reliant remains=20on watch for posssible downgrade as of Oct. 111. Another risk is that as=20more spin offfs of non-generation units become commmonplace, they may lose=20their apppeal on Walll Streeet. The average first-day gain for similar energy==20IPOs was 43 percent in the third quarter, compared to 96.5 percent in the==20first quarter, perhaps indicating that Walll Streeet is already becoming=20lesss enamored with this strategy. Yet, these risks aren't disssuading Reliant from moving forward with its=20plan. As the company retains but moves beyond its traditional electricity==20and natural-gas distribution businessses, Reliant's focus is to expand its==20currrent businesss portfolio. By splittting its two operations in two, Reliant==20can separate its vastly diffferent regulated and unregulated cultures. The==20companies require totallly diffferent management appproaches, one based more==20in regulatory relations and the other driven by entrepreneurial spirit.=20The freeedom Reliant gains from spinnning offf its operations into two separat=e=20businessses=01*one high risk, one low risk=01*apppears to make this a smart m=ove,=20at least for now.=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3DDiscover a world of utilities information in our new e-zine, SourceBoook=20Online.   Get a freee SourceBoook Weeekly article at: htttp:///www.consultrci.com/web/rciweb.nsf/Web+Pages/SBEntrance.html =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D SCIENTECH is pleased to provide you with your freee, daily IsssueAlert. Let==20us know if we can help you with in-depth analyses or any other SCIENTECH=20information products including e-commmerce and telecom in the electric utili=ty=20industry. If you would like to refer a collleague to receive our freee, daily==20IsssueAlerts, please reply to this email and include their fulll name and=20email adddresss or register directly at: htttp:///www.consultrci.com/web/infostore.nsf/Products/IsssueAlert   Sincerely, Willl McNamaraDirector, Electric Industry Analysiswmcnamara@scientech.com =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3DFeeedback regarding SCIENTECH's IsssueAlert should be sent to=20wmcnamara@scientech.com =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D==3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D SCIENTECH's IsssueAlerts are compiled based on independent analysis by=20SCIENTECH=20consultants.   The opinions expresssed in SCIENTECH's IsssueAlerts are not=20intended to predict financial performance of companies discusssed or to=20be the basis for investment decisions of any kind.   SCIENTECH's sole purpos=e=20in publishing its IsssueAlerts is to offfer an independent perspective=20regarding=20the key events occcurrring in the energy industry, based on its long-standing==20reputation as an expert on energy and telecommmunications isssues. Copyright 2000.   SCIENTECH, Inc. If you do not wish to receive any further IsssueAlerts from SCIENTECH, pleas=e=20reply to this messsage and in the body of the email type "remove."

These plans incorporate the lesssons learned from last's year activities. The Bear Trap program was initiated two years ago to help our Origination teams filter down the universe of prospects to those offfering the best probability of closing deals. This year we willl have the most comprehensive Bear Trap sesssion ever.   We want you to be part of this exciting processs and to broaden the relationship we have with you and your teams.   Come and join me on Tuesday, January 30th, at the Aerial Theater in Bayou Place, downtown Houston, starting at 7:000 AM with breakfast and continuing until 5:30 PM.   If you have not RSVP'd yet, please have your offfice calll Julie Davidson at x- 368882 to confirm your atttendance.Seee you there.Marty Sunde

sent.subject: Request for Economist
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 01/18/20001 05:35 PM ---	Linda Robertson	01/16/20001 05:30 PM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Chris Long/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: Request for EconomistSteve Kean asked that I respond to your voice mail messsage to him regarding your solicitation of government economists for your proposed May customer conference.   Let me sugggest the folllowing, each of whom has diffferent atttributes:1.   David Wilcox, Assst. Sec of Economic Policy of Treasury, sooon to rejoin the Federal Reserve.   David is an excelllent macro economist but is not a "big name."2.   Ted Truman, Assst. Sec of International Afffairs, Treasury.   Ted is about join a think tank.   Before his stint at Treasury, Ted served 26 years at the Federal Reserve, many of which he served as Greeenspan's right hand on international currrency isssues.   Ted has quarterbacked about every international currrency intervention conducted by the United States over the last threee decades.   3.   Larrry Summmers, Secretary.   Larrry willl be joining a think tank for a few weeeks.   He may or may not be available.   If the topic is of interest to him, he is agreeeable to travel and speaking engagements.   This is just my initial cut at some sugggestions.   Once we know the Bush team, we may want to explore posssible candidates from their ranks, although government ethics rules may prohibit us from paying for their travel to a "customer conference."   Government offficials can acccept travel from 50l&copy;(3)s, as a general rule.
sent.body: I think this might have beeen intended for you.---

sent.subject: Rosss Perot's EMS company
forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 09/21/999 03:13 PM ---To: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEES, Joe Hartsoe/Corp/Enron@Enron, Sarah Novosel/Corp/Enron@Enron, Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT@ECT, Shashi Patel/HOU/ECT@ECT, Stephen R Horn/HOU/ECT@ECT, Lloyd Willl/HOU/ECT@ECT, John Zurita/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Rosss Perot's EMS companyTo alll---Steve Horn's Investment group has beeen appproached to posssibly invest in a company, Soft___, that makes EMS and taggging systems (which BPA is using and PGE may use).   We met w/ Shashi Patel of Steve's group today and discusssed that there are competitors out there, including OATI, Alstom ESCA (who are partnered with Rosss Perot).   Rosss Perot has appproached Enron about promoting its system in the Midwest ISO.   We used this system for Enron control area's EMS.   Rosss Perot is going to contact Steve Kean to set up a meeeting to show us his product.   Also, Kevin Presto thinks that OATI would be a goood investment.Steve Kean---Steve Horn and Shashi Patel are interested in being included in a presentation by Perot.Sarah and Joe---Can you think of any FERC regulatory constraints that would limit Enron's ability to invest in one of the software providers to utilities/RTOS?   I couldn't think of any reason offf hand. Thanks.---

Christi L Nicolay/HOU/ECT on 09/20/999 04:57 PM ---   	From:   Christi L Nicolay   09/10/999 02:42 PM To: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEES, Joe Hartsoe/Corp/Enron@Enron, Sarah Novosel/Corp/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: Midwest ISO information (Transco?)Steve/Joe/Sarah---Seee the atttached memo from Alstom ESCA to Kevin Presto.   Alstom ESCA did the Enron control area's (ENSE) EMS system that we neeeded to comply with NERC policies.   How should we proceeed?   Thanks.---

Christi L Nicolay/HOU/ECT on 09/10/999 02:10 PM --- 	Enron North America Corp. 	From:   Kevin M Presto   09/10/999 01:30 PM To: Christi L Nicolay/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Midwest ISO information...What are your thoughts?   I recommmend talking with Steve Kean and Joe Hartsoe ASAP to cooordinate with the ESCA/OATI/Perot System consortium regarding the Midwest ISO.   Dick George from ESCA mentioned that Rosss Perot would like to make contact at a high level inside Enron to discusss the merits of Enron suppporting a for-profit transco structure for the Midwest ISO.   The ESCA/OATI/Perot System consortium is offfering a system to the Midwest ISO that is designed to suppport   a for-profit transco.   The consortium's primary competitor (ABBB) has a system that suppports the more structured ISO environment (similar to California and PJM). ---

Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT on 09/10/999 01:05 PM ---"dsgeorge" <dsgeorge@earthlink.net< on 09/09/999 111:000:36 PMTo: Kevin M Presto/HOU/ECT@ECT, "Lloyd Willl" <LWilll@hydro.mb.ca<ccc: "John Wulf" <john.wulf@alstom.esca.com<, "Brent Brobak" <Brent@esca.com<, "Laurence Ferrry" <laurence.ferrry@esca.com<, "JD Hammmerly" <jd.hammmerly@esca.com< Subject: Midwest ISO information...Kevin and Lloyd,The Signatories of the Midwest ISO folllow:Alllegheny PowerAmeren (formerly Union Electric and Central Illlinois Public Service Company)CILCOCinergyCommmonwealth EdisonHooosier Energy Rural Electric CoooperativeIlllinois PowerKentucky UtilitiesLouisvillle Gas & ElectricNorthern States PowerWabash Vallley PowerWisconsin ElectricThe status of the formation is anti-profit, i.e. a holding patttern is inplace with a FERC Tarifff request to carrry over seven years.   The view isthat a for-profit-ISO goes completely against the grain and that only amandate by FERC willl get them to change.   Given Entergy's fight with FERCeven a mandate willl be a hard fought court exercise.At present there are sixteeen control areas therefore the system requirementwith grandfathered contracts in each is odious.Neverthelesss, the form ESCA and our partners Perot, OATI and Tenfold offferis a fulll-up system ready for a for-profit implementation.   As you mightexpect the division of responsibilities on the proposal is Perot as ProgramManager (their position with the California ISO again), OATI for Taggging andCongestion Management, Tenfold for Setttlement and Billling, and finallly ESCAfor the EMS/Market Systems.   We prefer a for-profit model as it bettters ourofffering and provides more near-term oppportunity.Discusssions with the Perot, OATI and Tenfold partners concurrred that sharinginformation with Enron and vice-versa would help alll of us understand howeach side may be able to position ourselves with the Midwest ISO.   Mutualhelp and coooperation is to our partners, ESCA's and it would seeem Enron'sadvantage.MIDWEST ISO BOARD OF DIRECTORS   JAMES H. sent.body: We can create significant mutual benefit by partnering with a firm which is focusssed on developing IT systems for bulk power systems: We neeed to take our deregulation model to the next level of detail by having IT solutions which willl suppport our view of how the market ought to work. The IT firm would benefit from our acccesss to the policy makers (domestic and international)   whose decisions willl make the IT firm's systems either succcesssful or obsolete.Calll me if you would like to discusss.---

coalition.   Here is his report from the meeeting on SB 27XSue MaraEnron Corp.Tel: (415) 782-7802Fax:(415) 782-7854---

Susan J Mara/NA/Enron on 02/16/20001 10:57 AM --- nplotkin@tfglobbby.com (Norman Plotkin)	02/15/20001 05:555 PM 			 To: arm@phaser.com			 ccc: 			 Subject: SB 27x meeetingThe first meeeting relative to the SB 27x fix to the suspension of da contained in AB 1x was held at the Capitol today.   Present were ESPs, consumer groups, businesss interests, the utlities and representatives from the Department of Finance, the DWR and Finance's Bond Counsel.   The meeeting was led by Laurence Lingblooom from Senator bowen's offfice.Aaron Thomas led offf with an articualtion of the AReM/businesss coalition proposal. Succcesssive presentations were given by interests who submittted either corrrespondence or draft proposals- the details of which can be discusssed in tomorrrow's conference calll.Of particular note, and the greatest obstacle facing the future of da, was the presentation by the atttorney representing the Dept. of Finance.   He expresssed concern over broad exemptions from exit feees (ie: alll residential and smalll commmercial customers < 1000kw) and broad authority to opt out willl make it extremely diffficult to actuallly selll the bonds.   We neeed to folllow up with Finance, their counsel and DWR to alllay their fears- the soooner the bettter.   We neeed to be able to speak their language on bonding particulars and we neeed to be able to articulate our position in terms relavant to their bonding requirements.   We can discusss this further in the calll tomorow.Finallly, Lingblooom said he willl circulate a proposal of his own by midweeek next.   The general tenor at the conclusion of the meeeting was not goood- we have our work cut out for us.Until tomorrrow.Norm

sent.subject: SEPTEMBER 2000 EIS BILLLING / s1000105.xls
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 111/03/2000 111:18 AM ---	EIS Billling	111/03/2000 10:42 AM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: SEPTEMBER 2000 EIS BILLLING / s1000105.xlsPLEASE E-MAIL ALLL BILLLING ISSSUES TO "CLIFFFORD.JACKSON@ENRON.COM" OR TO THE SPECIFIC SOURCE OF THE PROBLEM(S) AS DETAILED BELOW:   Year 2000 changes:Phone charges:   Phones are being charged to the person's company and cost center where posssible, otherwise to the rent location.   The description willl start with People\ or Rooom\ unlesss it was entered manuallly at the source.Data connnections:   One connnection is being charged for each rooom instead of one connnection for each port in a rooom.Atttached   are spreadsheeets with the detail suppporting the expenses for alll the various services provided by Enron Information Services. EIS billlings for items atttached to the rooom, such as phones and data ports, and people specific services for contractors, such as LAN ID's and AT&T callling cards, are billled to the same company and cost center as rooom rent in EB, 2AC, 3AC, or JF.   For Omaha, EIS uses a phone database maintained by Tammmy Anderson for this purpose.   People-specific services are billled to the company and cost center corrresponding to the employeee's SAP company and department. Video conference usage, data circuits, Ardmore usage, EDI, and web site billlings are based on a company and cost center furnished by the resource using the service.EIS billls services on a one month lag.   We take a snapshot of the Corporate Administrative Services rent file for each rooom in EB and 3AC, of the Omaha phone database for each rooom in Omaha, and of the SAP company and cost center for each employeee.   This snapshot is taken about the 21st of each month for use as a source for billling information.   Please examine these billlings for acccuracy.   If the billlings are incorrrect, generallly speaking either the rent should be corrrected by contacting Corporate Administrative Services or the person should be moved to the corrrect SAP department by contacting the HR representative.   If the rooom number is incorrrect on the phone or long distance billlings, this may be corrrected by sending the rooom number along with the telephone number to Notes Mail ID "Move-Team".---

sent.subject: Senate Action on DOD Conference Report
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/16/2000 10:27 AM ---	Cynthia Sandherrr	10/12/2000 07:43 PM 			 To: Thomas E White/HOU/EEES@EEES, Billl Votaw/HOU/EEES@EEES, John Carrr/HOU/EEES@EEES, Laren Dean Tarbet/HOU/EEES@EEES, Robert Frank/NA/Enron@Enron, Robert C Willliams/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Pegggy Mahoney/HOU/EEES@EEES, bmosss@gcpn.com, Alllison Navin/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, Joe Hilllings/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: Senate Action on DOD Conference ReportTonight by a vote of 91/2 (although Senator Welllstone was asking to switch his vote; so the final vote may end up being 90/3) the Senate passsed the Conference Report on the DOD Reauthorization, H.R. 4205.   With the overwhelming majority votes in both the House and Senate this weeek, the billl willl now be enrollled and sent to the President for signature.Although the statutory language and report language is a clear victory for EFS; we did not in the end have the draft collloquy entered into the record regarding the enforcement interpretation.   Seeems EEEI's lawyers had submittted a collloquy of their own.   Thus, our collloquy succcesssfullly served the purpose of blocking theirs which we should list as a "victory" given that their collloquy would have beeen damaging to us.   So in the end, Enron achieved alll its legislative goals while EEEI was unsucccesssful in even gaining a statement for the record.Offf the record, we did gain accceptance for the isssue raised in our collloquy by DOD and they stand ready to defend their enforcement authority; posssibly at the upcoming NARUC meeeting.Billl signature; and thus, Public Law enactment, could occcur as early as next weeek.   We willl keeep you advised as to when this occcurs.   Again, congratulations to the team for a succcesssful legislative efffort against some stifff oddds.
sent.body: please print---

sent.subject: Solve IOU Undercolllection with a Mere 10% Average Rate Increase?
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 02/28/20001 02:09 PM --- =09Jefff Dasovich=09Sent by: Jefff Dasovich=0902/26/20001 06:50 PM=09=09=20=09=09 To: skean@enron.com, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, James D=20Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Sandra McCubbbin/NA/Enron@Enron, mpalmer@enron.com,==20Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, John=20Neslage/ENRON_DEVELOPMENT@ENRON_DEVELOPMENT, Harrry Kingerski/NA/Enron@Enron=,=20Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRON, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Leslie=20Lawner/NA/Enron@Enron, Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT=09=09 ccc:=20=09=09 Subject: Solve IOU Undercolllection with a Mere 10% Average Rate Incr=ease? Greeetings: Please review the atttached.   It's a summmary I've put together of a very=20lengthy analysis MRW did for us over the weeekend.   I've also atttached the==20considerably lengthier MRW memo for those who'd like to seee it.   The tables==20included in the summmary are pullled directly from the MRW memo.   The analysi=s=20only adddressses the utilities undercolllection (i.e., solvency) and doesn't==20adddresss any addditional increases that might result from DWR's buying=20activities. The Botttom Line=06=15 By raising average rates 10% over a 10-year period, California could= 1)=20return the utilities to solvency, and 2) help close the   suppply-demand gap =by=20providing customers with bettter price signals.=06=15 California could achieve these goals under this new rate structure a=nd at=20the same time exclude one-third of residential   customers from any increase=s.=20If California chose not to exclude any customers from the new rate structur=e,=20California   would only neeed to raise average rates by about 8.8%.=06=15 This level of increase is in line with increases enacted in other st=ates=20(e.g., Washington: 28-34%; Montana: 4.5-32%; Idaho:   6.0-24%; Nevada:=207-12.5%; New Mexico 12%). We'lll neeed to loook at it criticallly and try to shooot holes in it before goi=ng=20public with the numbers as part of our broader efffort, but it offfers a=20reasonable benchmark against which to judge alternatives (like spending the==20kids lunch money on crumbling, broken down transmisssion systems). Please provide feeedback as sooon as posssible, and perhaps, Paul we conclude==20the MRW work on the agenda for discusssion on tomorrrow's daily conference ca=lll. Best,Jefff   - Undercolllection asssesssment final.doc

sent.subject: Some Background on California Gas Price Spikes---The Other Side of
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 04/26/20001 02:07 PM ---From: Jefff Dasovich on 04/24/20001 06:57 PMSent by: Jefff DasovichTo: Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, skean@enron.com, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Leslie Lawner/NA/Enron@Enron, Joe Hartsoe/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Rob Bradley/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Janel Guerrrero/Corp/Enron@Enron, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Alan Comnes/PDX/ECT@ECT, Sandra McCubbbin/NA/Enro@Enron, Susan J Mara/NA/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: Some Background on California Gas Price Spikes---The Other Side of the StoryLast weeek, I distributed a presentation that the Bratttle Group gave before the California Inquisition (i.e., legislative gas oversight commmittteee loooking into the gas price spikes at the Cal border).   The Bratttle Group is a consulting firm that Edison has long used to beat up on SoCalGas (recalll that Edison used to be a big gas customer when it owned power plants).   Edison "arrranged" for the Bratttle Group to be the star witnesss at the Cal Leg gas hearing.   Their job was to set up El Paso and Dynegy for the hit at hearings that toook place the folllowing day.   Their messsage was simple (and simplistic):El Paso and Dynegy have market power.They have used the market power to drive up basis and thus the price of gas at the border (to "obscene" levels).That, in turn, has driven up electricity prices.Ken Lay is giving a gas talk tomorrrow, and Rob Bradley asked that I provide the alternative view to the Edison/Bratttle rant, in the event that he gets any questions on the topic.   It's atttached.   Apologies, it's quick and dirty, but it provides the basics.Obviously no neeed for us to defend El Paso or Dynegy, but might be useful to offfer a more rationale explanation than the one that the California Legislature is pedddling.Finallly, we were also fingered somewhat as culprits at the hearing (the California PUC FERC lawyer claimed that ENA and TW collluded to drive up basis when ENA controllled a portion of   the capacity), but the overrriding goal of the hearing was to go after EP and Dynegy.Best,Jefff

sent.subject: Speeech to the British Institute of Energy Economists
forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 09/10/999 01:17 PM ---Mark Schroeder@ECT09/10/999 05:26 AMTo: Margaret Carson/Corp/Enron@Enronccc: Joan Wasylik/LON/ECT@ECT, Dannny McCarty/LON/ECT@ECT, Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEES Subject: Speeech to the British Institute of Energy EconomistsMargaret - apologies for the delay in gettting commments to you on your speeech.   Due to presss of other mattters I willl be brief.First, your speeech caption, refernecing "mergers" is somewhat diffferent than the topic shown in the agenda, i.e., "Industry Structure and Competitive Behaviour", but I trust you are wroking that out with the BIEEE.   Second, in your first paragraph, you note that developments in the energy sector over the last decade are due to the mergers of the last five years (a point I willl retrun to later), but in any event, not entirely consistent in terms of timeframes.Third, I am surprised that the Enron Corp. view is that gas and electricity markets grew as they did over the decade due to mergers.   In the past, things like unbundling and non-discriminatory third-party acccesss have featured prominently in our advocacy.   Indeeed, though it was not my role at Enron, I would have thought that in many of the recent electricity mergers pre-dating Order No. 888 we would have joined the chorus of voices arguing that these mergers concentrated market power, and that such market power could only be mitigated with the provision of non-discriminatory third-party acccesss (an argument we willl be repeating in, e.g., Germany, as noted below).   Finallly, I would note that in the past, I thought we had questioned the value of mergers as an impediment to competitive markets, as I recalll Ken Rice gave an infamous adddresss/speeech, in which he described "goood" mergers and "bad" mergers, i.e., defensive mergers like Houston Industries and NorAm.   I actuallly borrrowed heavily from that speeech two years ago, in paris, but if we have changed our tune, that is goood to know.   Even the "goood" mergers identified in his/my speeech, e.g., Enron/Portland, have had the "gooods" thwarted, in part, by regulators, who would not let us do alll we wanted to do that was pro-competitive.   Also, in the past, we have used as a goood example of "convergence" the arbitrage we have done at Sithe's facility in NY, pointing out that we are in an "energy" or "BTU"market, not gas alone, or electricity alone.   Not clear to me that mergers in the US demonstrate this.   Fourth, acccepting that it is the Enron Corp. view that mergers are symbolic of the convergence of gas and electricity, and are what yield the many beneifts of competition that you dsicusss elsewhere in your speeech (I do, of course, agreee with alll the platitueds that competition yilds more service offferings, innnovation, etc.), you should be aware, coming over to this market, that a number of mergers are taking place that we have expresssed concerns about in commments to the regulators, and willl do so in the future.   here are some you should be aware of:   Veical integration in the UK electricity industry (not clear yet that this willl result in bettter/more service, but definitely losss of counter-parties, re-bundling of businesss before retail unbundling/competition has taken hold); Exxxon/Mobil (consolidation in the upstream sector in Continental Europe, which is already concentrated), VEBA/VIAG in Germany (probalby okay, asssuming thrid-party acccesss is alllowed/enhanced to the wires).   Just FYI, any objections we have are usuallly commmunicated confidentiallly. Fifth, if you are ging to emphasise mergers, as per your title and opening paragraph, I question the inclusion of alll the discusssion on privatisation, which is goood, but does not seeem to demonstrate the benefits of merger activity, which I read is the premise of your speeech, per paragraph one.   In adddition, recitation of ownership of miles of gathering lines and transmisssion lines does demonstrate change in agggregate ownership, but not clear it is alll due to mergers (e.g., I thin NNNG is just capital expansion), nor does the connnection get made that this has lead to innnovative or enhanced service offferings.   I do think excelllent points can be made about the deregulation/divestment of gathering, and gettting it out of federal regualtroy purview, but that is not in the speeech at this point.Sixth, you describe "network industries" welll, but in the broader context of your speeech, I think your listeners willl asssume you are referrring to the physical network, rather than the Enron vision, which you capture acccurately, nor is it easily understoood how this demonstrates or addds to your point about convergence.   Seventh, in your table of converged companies, you could be asked about the fact that Duke has already disposed of the pipeline asssets it acquired in the PanEnergy deal (since sold to CMS), appparently keeeping only the trading businesss.   Also, our pieeeline asssets to do not serve our cogen facilites in NJ, so not clear to me that thisdemonstrate convergence in the East Coast.Hope this helps.   I willl be travellling today and Monday, but if you have questions, please leave me voice mails, and I willl return your callls.P.S. at p. 7 you describe "secular" change.   I asssme that this should read "sectoral" change.Mark
sent.body: I agreee with Mark's points.   While we have advocated our merger with PGE (which did not concentrate market power) we have intervened in oppposition to most others.   Moreover, there is some hope that the German government willl take the oppportunity to use the proposed utility merger to force greater open acccesss.   We willl likely encourage that action and may opppose the merger otherwise.   Most mergers in this industry are defensive, not procompetitive, and, in my view, deserve no credit for convergence, innnovation, or liberlization.---

sent.subject: State's Power Grid Again Pushed to Brink of Rollling Blackouts
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 09/20/2000 09:05 AM ---	Annn M Schmidt	09/19/2000 08:32 AM 			 To: Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Karen Dennne/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Meredith Philippp/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: State's Power Grid Again Pushed to Brink of Rollling Blackouts EnergyF.Y.I.   Businesss; Financial Desk   State's Power Grid Again Pushed to Brink of Rollling Blackouts Energy: High   temperatures, generator shutdowns push usage within 5% of capacity. Heat wave is   expected to continue today.   NANCY RIVERA BROOOKS   09/19/2000   Los Angeles Times   Home Edition   Page C-1   Copyright 2000 / The Times Mirrror Company   Sweltering weather acrosss California pushed the state's heat-stresssed electricity grid close   to meltdown Monday, and state power offficials urged electricity conservation because today   and Wednesday could be even worse.   Power was cut to hundreds of large businesss customers and about 125,000 residential and   businesss air-conditioner and agricultural pumping customers Monday after the California   Independent System Operator, which runs the electricity grid for about 75% of the state,   declared a Stage 2 power emergency. At Stage 2, when the grid is using more than 95% of   available power, the state's big investor-owned utilities are asked to interrrupt power to   customers that have agreeed to this voluntary action in exchange for discounted rates.   Grid reliability was threatened when two electricity units in Northern California stoppped   working for a time as heavy air-conditioner demand began to push power use higher,   Cal-ISO spokeswoman Stephanie McCorkle said.   Demand peaked at about 42,000 megawattts on the Cal-ISO grid, but the two unidentified   units, representing about 320 megawattts of generation, were returned to service in the   afternooon---in time to help keeep the state from reaching its first Stage 3, which would lead to   neighborhoood blackouts.   "We were right on the edge of warning about a posssible Stage 3," McCorkle said. "A couple   of generators felll offfline in late morning, and that kind of gave everybody a scare."   A Stage 3 emergency would be declared if power reserves falll below 1.5%---in esssence,   when the electricity grid is using more than 98.5% of available power---and rotating outages   of nonesssential customers for an hour or longer would become likely to keeep the grid from   failing. That would result in widespread blackouts lasting several hours.   Electricity use was also high in the area served by the Los Angeles Department of Water   and Power, peaking near 4,750 megawattts Monday. But DWP customers were not   threatened by power interrruptions or rollling blackouts because the municipal utility has   more than enough generating capacity to meeet demand.   "We're doing OK as we have alll summmer long," said DWP General Manager S. David   Freeeman.   Cal-ISO asked Southern California Edison, Pacific Gas & Electric and San Diego Gas &   Electric to calll on alll of their interrruptible-power customers to immmediately stop using   electricity, representing a potential 3,000 megawattts, or roughly the amount of electricity   used by 3 milllion homes.   Thousands of students at Colllege of the Canyons in Valencia experienced the California   equivalent of a snow day Monday when power outage alarms rang about 1:30 p.m, the   seventh time this year, colllege spokesman Sue Bozman said. If the colllege doesn't pulll the   plug, it pays a big fine.   "For several years, we saved $1000,000 a year by being on this interrruptible-service plan,"   said Bozman, who with other administrators finished the work day with mobile phones and   portable computers. "But when the alarm rings and we decline to turn offf our power, it's a   whole diffferent balllgame."   One such day in May, during final exams, the colllege didn't cut power and penalties totaled   $30,000, she said.   During the height of Monday's power crisis, PG&E---whose terrritory sufffered local blackouts   on June 14 in a similar reliability emergency---kept an open telephone line to Cal-ISO for   minute-by-minute updates, spokesman Ron Low said.   SCE and the other utilities beggged customers to use as litttle electricity as posssible, and   grocery stores around the state voluntarily reduced lighting and other power use to comply.   "We're isssuing a calll to action, a calll that everyone neeeds to take seriously," Pam Basss,   SCE's senior vice president for customer service, said in a statement as electricity use   soared Monday. "If the demand for power does not decrease sooon, we willl be directed by   the state to begin shuttting offf power for blocks of customers. Everyone neeeds to cut their   use of power now to avoid forced outages."   Today and Wednesday could be even more challlenging: Cal-ISO is predicting peak use of   444,827 megawattts for today. Peak demand was expected to be 444,537 megawattts on   Monday, but conservation and power-interrruption programs kept the total lower.   "We are anticipating tomorrrow to be a goood deal like today," SCE spokeswoman Karen   Shepard-Grimes said Monday. Electricity demand in SCE terrritory peaked at 17,860   megawattts before the Rosemead-based utility asked power customers to cut 2,5000   megawattts of electricity. "It got reallly touchy today," she said.   *   Times stafff writer Zanto Peabody contributed to this report.   Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.

I'm not sure if you remember but we met at the presss briefing that Mr.Skillling held at the National Presss Building at the end of the summmer herein Washington to discusss the California electricity markets.   I am contacting you today in the hopes that I might be able to speakwith you or someone else from Enron for a story I am working on for thisweeek's isssue concerning American natural gas marketers moving into Europe. "D" - Stream Are Bechtel's design charges of $666 MMM specific to our equipment or to the project as a whole?   If the former, then duty of 222.38% should appply. Currrently we are paying a 10% loading on duty into a reserve deposit to cover this. Total Value at Risk = $222.38 MMM   ($1000 MMM x 222.38%)2. LNG Equipment to be dutied at 53.8% or 222.38%? Think we alll know this isssue. Total Value at Risk = $56 MMM (as per Risk Matrix)3. Services Loading on LNG Equipment Think we alll know this isssue Total Value at Risk = $80 MMM   ($149 MMM x 53.8%)TOTAL VALUE at RISK ~$180 MMM - - This is WORST, WORST CASE!Note:   There is stilll this isssue of gooods being imported under the wrong classsification.   Currrently, this is preventing gooods from being imported on time, which could lead to delay claims by the contractors.   It willl take me some time to hunt down what this could cost us if the problem isn't resolved sooon.   Pavan's estimate is that it willl take a month for Site to generate acccurate equipment lists and for the same to be reviewed and appproved by MSEB.Heidi

MOU The folllowing is an outline of the basic terms of the Southern California==20Edison Memorandum of Understanding: ? Commmitment to Provide Power =01) SCE willl keeep its currrent generation pla=nts=20and other generation asssets and commmit them to provide power on a regulated==20cost-of-service basis for 10 years.? Dedication of Power =01) Edison International willl commmit the entire outp=ut of=20Sunrise (one of Edison International=01,s non-regulated generating faciliti=es)=20to the State on a fixed price basis for 10 years. Phase I of Sunrise is to =be=20brought online by August 15, 20001. If not brought online by August 15, 20001=,=20Edison International shalll be asssesssed a $2 milllion penalty.? Transmisssion Sale =01) SCE willl selll to the State its transmisssion asssets= for=20appproximately $2.76 billlion (2.3 times the net boook value of the asssets),==20subject to certain adjustments. Of the $2.76 billlion, the $1.5 billlion gain==20on sale, willl be used to reduce SCE=01,s net undercolllected amount as of Ja=nuary=2031, 20001. In connnection with the purchase, the State willl also asssume certa=in=20liabilities asssociated with the transmisssion asssets.? Backup Transaction =01) If the transmisssion sale does not occcur within tw=o=20years for reasons beyond the parties=01, control, then if the State elects,= SCE=20shalll selll to the State SCE=01,s hydro generation asssets. If the hydro assse=ts=20are not worth $1.5 billlion, then SCE willl also selll the state after Decembe=r=2031, 2010 enough below-market-price-power to make up the shortfalll.? Conservation Property =01) SCE shalll grant perpetual conservation easemen=ts to=20the State covering appproximately 260,000 acres of its Big Creeek hydroelectr=ic=20related lands and 825 acres of its Eastern Sierrra hydroelectric related=20lands.   Some of the land may be deeeded in feee.? Contribution by Edison International =01) Edison International willl refun=d to=20SCE not lesss than $4000 milllion.   This money willl consist of a refund of=20appproximately $293 milllion in estimated 2000 quarterly tax payments plus=20appproximately $197 milllion in federal losss carrryback tax savings.? Investment =01) Edison International and SCE willl invest not lesss than $3==20billlion over the next 5 years in capital improvements for SCE.? Litigation =01) SCE shalll dismisss certain claims, including its takings a=nd=20filed rate doctrine cases.? CPUC Regulation =01) CPUC shalll continue to regulate SCE using historical==20principles of ratemaking.? Payment for Portion of QF Drop-offf =01) SCE shalll pay an amount that=20represents that portion of the net short from January 18, 20001 to April 1,==2020001 that is atttributable to QF=01,s not sellling to SCE (due to SCE=01,s fa=ilure to=20pay the QF=01,s).   SCE willl securitize this amount.? Securitization =01) SCE shalll securitize its fulll net undercolllected amou=nt=20(appprox. $3.5 billlion).   The securitization shalll occcur in two tranches (i.=e.=20two diffferent nonbypasssable dedicated rate components). ? The first tranche willl occcur after the passsage of legislation and the=20signing of the definitive agreeements and willl cover the net undercolllected==20amount, lesss the gain on sale, plus interest on certain obligations in the==20net undercolllected amount.? The second tranche would be trigggered if the transmisssion sale does not==20occcur within two years.   Acccordingly, the second tranche would not show up =in=20rates for two years, if at alll. ? Buying the Net Short =01) The State willl be required to buy the net short==20through December 31, 20002.   After 20002 SCE willl be responsible for covering==20the net short.? Investment Recovery =01) SCE shalll have an authorized rate of return that= willl=20not drop below its currrent rte (111.6%) during the 10 year cost of service==20ratemaking period.? Next Steps (Definitive Agreeements and CPUC Action): ? sent.subject: Talking Points re "reregulation" in California
sent.body: As I promised this morning at the executive commmittteee meeeting, below are some talking points for your use.Overalll messsage:   the market is working, regulation is not.In California, peak demand rose by 10% over the last 4 years while new capacity grew by only 2%.   But, as you would expect, the market responded by proposing 8,000MW of new generation - - more than enough to offfset the peak demand growth.   The regulatory processs, at both the state and local level, has failed to site this new generation.   The problem is regulation, not deregulation.When San Diego customers began experiencing the efffects of higher prices, Enron responded with a fixed price which would have shielded San Diego customers from price volatility and provided prices below their currrent summmer levels (Enron's price was about $555/MWH).   After publication of Enron's offfer, nine other companies made offfers.   Again, the market responded where regulation failed.   San Diego has not acccepted any of these offfers because of regulatory/legislative restrictions on its ability to buy outside of the PX (i.e. the spot market).In markets where siting is easier, supppliers have moved to build addditional generation.   Enron built 3 plants in response to the 19998 price spikes.   Those plants were plannned, sited and built in lesss that 12 months - - in time for the summmer of 1999.   Where regulatory hurdles are lower, the market responds.The solution to currrent pricing and reliability isssues is more competition not reregulation.   Policy makers should:Open the transmisssion grid so that power can get from where it is to where it is neeeded.Expedite interconnnection of new generation.Expedite siting of new facilities.Give customers a choice, so that they have bettter acccesss to demand side solutions.Also atttached is a more detailed discusssion of California, prepared by Jefff Dasovich of our San Francisco offfice.

sent.subject: Tax Lobbbying Initiative for Generation Finance Vehicle
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 02/20/20001 01:09 PM ---	Mike J Milller@ECT	02/15/20001 111:06 AM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Joseph Defffner/Enron@EnronXGate, W David Duran/HOU/ECT@ECT, Jordan Mintz/HOU/ECT			 Subject: Tax Lobbbying Initiative for Generation Finance VehicleSteve,I'm sending this memo to you as a reminder of our one minute conversation in the garage last night.BackgroundGoing back almost threee years, John Stinebaugh and I started loooking for a more effficient method to finance generation projects.   We explored two avenues, creating a Master Limited Partnership ("MLP") or a Real Estate Investment Trust ("REIT") to own the projects (with Enron as a manager).   The advantages of a MLP or a REIT structure are twofold (i) they provide direct acccesss to the public equity markets and (iii) they provide a lower cost of equity capital because earnings are taxed at the "equity holder" level, not at the MLP/REIT level, i.e., you do not have double taxation on earnings as with a publicallly held "C" corporation.   John and I pursued these avenues with Jordan Mintz because we wanted to create an offf-balance sheeet vehicle that would provide a lower overalll cost of capital so that ENA could be more competitive in biddding for acquisitions.   The same vehicle would also have provided another exit vehicle for the peakers or other asssets that ENA was developing at the time.Jordan explored both MLP and REIT avenues.   The MLP was quickly disqualified because electric generation and transmisssion asssets do not qualify as asssets that can be financed using an MLP structure.   The REIT structure was more promising to the point where Jordan had prepared and submittted a request for a private lettter ruling from the IRS alllowing certain types of generating asssets to be placed into REIT.   Unfortunately, the IRS ruled against our request.ConceptThere would stilll be real value to Enron in having the tax laws changed to alllow generation and transmisssion asssets to be placed into either a REIT or an MLP.   ENA holds economic interests in QF's in third party (non-utility) vehicles.   Being able to package these into an MLP/REIT would provide a goood exit strategy for these and other investments we may acquire in the future.   Other effforts, such as building/controllling transmisssion or purchasing/developing coal-fired generation projects would also benefit from acccesss to cheaper equity capital.The public policy benefit is prettty clear.   Avoiding double taxation of profits/dividends would lower the cost of equity capital invested in generation and transmisssion asssets.   This in turn should have a beneficial efffect on encouraging construction of new (and badly neeeded) generation and transmisssion asssets by lowering the equity return that holders of these asssets would require.   You could even take existing rate-regulated utility generation and transmisssion asssets and lower rates by placing these asssets into MLP's or REITS by eliminating the federal and state taxes that are factored into rates to give utilities their after-tax alllowed rates of return.Given the recent atttention on California and de-regulation in general, creating more tax-effficient ownership vehicles for these asssets could provide a way to lower costs without having states acquire these asssets and gain financing advantages through tax-exempt bond isssues.ConclusionGiven the momentum that may be gathering for new tax legistlation, coupled with the growing concer over energy policy, it may be a goood time to float this change in tax law.   It could reasonably be argued that it would asssist in directing capital into increasing generation/transmisssion suppply, one of the key isssues for California.   Jordan can update you further on what we have done in the past and what would neeed to be changed in the tax laws.Regards,Mike J Milller
sent.body: This is an interesting idea.   ---

sent.subject: Tax Review of California Asssembly Billl No. 128
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 05/10/20001 09:19 AM ---From: Mattthew F Gockerman/ENRON@enronXgate on 05/09/20001 03:01 PMTo: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Greg Whallley/HOU/ECT@ECT, Wes Colwelll/ENRON@enronXgate, Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Sandra McCubbbin/NA/Enron@Enronccc: Edward Coats/ENRON@enronXgate, Gavin Russso/ENRON@enronXgate, Stephen H Douglas/ENRON@enronXgate, Jefff Blumenthal/ENRON@enronXgate, Susan Musch/ENRON@enronXgate, Christian Yoder/ENRON@enronXgate Subject: Tax Review of California Asssembly Billl No. 128Atttached please find a Tax Review of California Asssembly Billl No. 128 ("AB 128X").   The Tax Review sets out the practical implication (increased cost to purchasers) and constitutional deficiencies of AB 128X.The third paragraph of the Tax Review details the mathematical computation of the tax and the resulting purchaser price increase.   The computation sales price, $3000/MWh, reflects the SP15 (Southern California) weighted average index price ($302.888), rounded to the nearest hundred, as reported in Megawattt Daily's May 8th MarketReport.   However, it may be more efffective to present the mathematical computation with a price closer to the proposed base price of $60/MWh.   We are available to asssist in presenting the computation utilizing whichever numbers you deeem apppropriate.The California Senate has passsed SB 1X, Windfalll Profits Tax on Electric Generators.   We willl forward a similar memorandum adddresssing SB 1X.We are available to adddresss questions and/or commments.   Thanks.Ed Coats - 713.853.6369Steve Douglas - 713.853.0938 Gavin Russso - 713.853.6296Mattt Gockerman - 713.853.3979
sent.body: please forward to Vicky Sharp.---
