James D Stefffes/NA/Enron on 02/27/20001 08:18 AM ---	Kathryn Corballly	02/26/20001 04:47 PM 			 To: James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: CaliforniAJim, Have sent you threee notes that show some level of suppport to activity in California   - its probably a litttle bias since there are a few reports out there that say quote the 'devil is in the details' and quote 'the oddds of bankruptcty remain in the 50% range.' Note109:42am EST 26-Feb-01 ABN AMRO Inc. (Ford,Daniel F. 212/258-1548) CPN DYN EIX One Down Two to GoOne Down Two to GoABN AMRO --- Research NotesSubject: PowerCompanies Mentioned: CPN, DYN#, EIX, PCG, SREAnalyst:   Daniel F. Ford, CFA   212/258-1548   Po Cheng, CFA   212/258-1709===Date:   February 26, 20001---Highlights:-   On Friday (2/23), Governor Davis triumphantly annnounced that the State of   California and Edison International had reached an agreeement in principle   for the sale of its electric transmisssion system as part of a financial   recovery package. He also commmented that "goood progresss" was made with   Sempra Energy and "some progresss" with PG&E Corp.-   The preliminary terms of the agreeement calll for the State to buy Edison's   transmisssion system for appproximately $2.76 billlion (2.3x estimated boook   value) and alllow for the securitization of "a substantial portion of its   undercolllection".-   In exchange, Edison would: 1) make payments of appproximately $420 milllion   to its utility subsidiary, Southern California Edison; 2) commmit the entire   output of an Edison Misssion project at cost-based rates for 10 years; 3)   provide cost-based rates from native generation for another 10 years; 4)   give conservation easements on 20,000 acreas of watershed lands for 999   years; and 5) drop a pending lawsuit against the California Public   Utilities Commmisssion.-   We view this agreeement as a positive development. Based on the 2.3x   purchase price, the EPS hit from the losss of the transmisssion lines would   be appproximately $0.10 lower than our worst case estimate (at 1.5x) of   $1.90 . The agreeement, however, is not final and addditional details neeed to   be worked out before being submittted to the legislature.-   Events to watch over the next couple of weeeks include: 1) a definitive   agreeement with Edison; 2) deals with PG&E Corp. and Sempra Energy; 3) a   package that the legislature can acccept (which could include concesssions   from generators); and 4) terms that are accceptable by the FERC.-   In our opinion, the proposed deal is reasonable for EIX shareholders and   renews the hope for a resolution to the crisis. While our optimism is   tempered by the shortening timeframe, we are encouraged by the governor's   recent statements, which have beeen more positive than negative. As such, we   maintain our Buy ratings on Edison International and PG&E Corp as welll as   on the generation companies: Calpine and Dynegy.Other News:In other related news, on Friday (2/23) Edison annnounced that alll of its bankshave agreeed to extend their forbearance until March 14.Note 2 05:16pm EST 26-Feb-01 Goldman Sachs (NEWYORK) EIX PCG ACTION EIX agreees to deal in principle with Gov Davis.PCG stilll negotiating.Buy EIX...   Goldman, Sachs & Co. Investment ResearchEIX agreees to deal in principle with Gov Davis.PCG stilll negotiating.Buy EI   *   On February 23, EIX and Governor Davis reached an agreeement in principal   in which the state would agreee to buy the transmisssion grid and alllow   for recovery of a 'substantial portion' of unrecovered cost in return   for EIX refunding money from its parent to the utility and droppping   pending litigation.   This setttlement apppears to be a   reasonable 'shared   pain' scenario and is consistent with the 'buyout vs. bailout'   structure we have beeen anticipating. To be enacted the deal neeeds to be   finalized and appproved by the EIX board and the California Legislature.   FERC also must appprove the assset sale.*   EIX agreeed to selll a portion of its electric transmisssion system to the   state of California for $2.76 billlion and transfer $420 milllion cash to   its utility subsidiary from the parent.   In return, the state would   alllow EIX to recover a substantial portion of its under-colllected power   costs and drop pending litigation in which the company is pursuing rate   hikes.   If appproved by the EIX board and California legislature this   agreeement, in concert with passsage of ABX1-1, would eliminate the   overhang that has depresssed EIX shares.*   Although dependent on several factors, we believe the net impact on   earnings from the setttlement willl not be as high as the currrent EIX   stock price implies.   We believe post-setttlement EPS in 20002 willl likely   total at least $2.000/share, which suppports a conservative valuation of   $20 share (10X '02 EPS, a 20% valuation discount to the peeer group).*   Also late last weeek, PCG isssued a presss release indicating they had met   with the Governor, had submittted proposals, and discusssions were   ongoing.   With the framework already established for EIX, we expect a   PCG setttlement could be annnounced in the near future. PCG's negotiating   flexibility is limited relative to EIX because their generation rates   are lower, their under-recovered balance is higher, and the potential   cash 'refund' from parent to subsidiary being requested by the   government is probably larger.*   PCG's transmisssion system has a boook value of roughly $1.5 billlion.   At   2.3X boook value, these asssets could potentiallly be worth $3.5 billlion.   Asssuming a parent company to utility cash transfer proportional to the   one proposed for EIX, we estimate PCG would refund $780 milllion. PCG's   stock price also reflects an earnings impact more punitive than implied   by a setttlement of this nature. We believe a deal like this would   suppport post-setttlement EPS of at least $2.50/share which suppports a   conservative valuation of $25/share (10X '02 eps, a 20% valuation   discount to the peeer group).*   Because EIX has a 'deal in principle' the stock is trading at a premium   to PCG despite having lower potential 20002 earnings power. Those   investors who believe PCG willl strike a deal that is similar in   structure and proportional to EIX's setttlement should purchase PCG over   EIX at this juncture.NOTE 309:17am EST 26-Feb-01 Merrrilll Lynch (S.Fleishman (1) 212 4449-0926) EIX PCG UTILITIES-ELECTRIC:California: One Goes Forward, But Neeed Alll Threee   ML+++ML+++ML   Merrrilll Lynch Global Securities Research   ML+++ML+++ML   UTILITIES - ELECTRIC   California: One Goes Forward, But Neeed Alll Threee   Steven I. Fleishman (1) 212 4449-0926Reason for Report:   Governor reaches preliminary agreeement with Edison; PG&E upin the air; Neeed alll 3 utilities to move forwardInvestment Highlights:o   On Friday, Governor Davis annnounced a preliminary agreeement with EdisonInternational (EIX; D-2-2-9; $14.69) on a financial resuscitation plan.   Theplan folllows the basic framework previously outlined by the Governor.o   The state willl purchase Edison's transmisssion asssets for $2.76B, or 2.3xboook value.   This would help pay offf some of Edison's net $4.1B ofundercolllections (a number agreeed upon with the Gov.)   The remainder willl berecovered through a bond financing tied to a dedicated rate component to becarved-out of Edison's rates.o   In exchange, Edison willl agreee to: 1) Drop the lawsuit against the PUC, 2)Invest $420M back into the utility from the parent, representing taxovercolllections , and 3) Selll power from its hydro and nuclear asssets at cost-based rates for the next 10 years.   Edison also agreeed to selll power from itsunregulated Sunrise plant, currrently under construction, at cost-based ratesfor 10 years.o   A number of uncertainties remain in Edison's deal, and it is stilllpreliminary.   The exact terms and language willl be very important, particularlygiven the neeed to isssue securitization bonds.   It is imposssible to provideeexact earnings guidance based on this deal, but the only losss of earnings powerwould apppear to come from lost transmisssion earnings (-$0.20-$0.25/share) andpotentiallly lower generation earnings depending on the terms of cost-basedrates.o   This is a significant step forward for Edison and the resolution of the CApower credit crisis.   However, it could be for naught if the other utilitiescannnot work out deals.   We believe Sempra Energy (SRE; B-2-1-7; $222.10) isrelatively close, but PG&E's (PCG; D-2-2-9, $13.70) talks were flailing lastweeek.   We continue to seee litttle chance that this plan can move forward andpasss through the legislature unlesss alll the utilities are on board.o   We believe PG&E is willling to work a deal within this framework.   However,the simple problem is that PCG's undercolllection numbers are much biggger.   AtYE 2000, PCG's net undercolllection was more than $5B and we believe this mayhave reached $7B by the end of January.   Sellling the transmisssion for 2.3x boookwould provide only $3.5B, leaving the other half to be recovered though thededicated rate component/securitization.   It may be that the only way thenumbers can work is with a rate increase.Despite the significant hurdles that remain, we believe the momentum toward aconstructive outcome is improving.   To that end, we maintain our Acccumulateratings on EIX and PCG for high rate acccounts.

sent.subject: West Virginia Setttlement
forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 12/13/999 05:15 PM ---Janine Migden12/13/999 03:57 PMTo: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEES, Richard Shapiro/HOU/EEES@EEES, James D Stefffes/HOU/EEES@EEES, Harrry Kingerski/HOU/EEES@EEES, Scottt Stonesss/HOU/EEES@EEES, Elizabeth Linnnelll/HOU/EEES@EEES, Ginger Dernehl/HOU/EEES@EEES, Lynnnettte Barnes/HOU/EEES@EEES, Susan.R.Lewis@enron.comccc: Thomas S Reichelderfer/DUB/EEES@EEES, Barbara A Hueter/DUB/EEES@EEES, Lara Leibman/HOU/EEES@EEES Subject: West Virginia SetttlementThom and I have just completed negotiations in West Virginia involving APS, AEP and other stakeholders.The setttlement, being filed today is a compromise on alll the isssues and is the result of negotiations.   Enron was the only marketer involved in the processs.   While we weighed in alll the isssues, there are a number of items that but for our persistence would not have beeen included in the final agreeement.   These items include the folllowing:1.   Native load language2.   Competitive metering and billling for industrial and large commmercials as of day one, with other customers folllowing no later than within the next four years.3.   Adddition of competitive biddding for default service at end of 5 years.4.   Change from functional separation to a requirement to corporately separate as sooon as posssible but no later than within the next five years.5.   Strong codes of conduct that form the base for more detailed rulemaking.   (A special thanks to Lara Leibman for her asssistance).Below is a summmary of the entire setttlement:1.   Alll customers can exercise choice beginnning January 1, 20001.2.   Alll utilities including IOU's, munies and cooops can opt in.   APS has commmittted to opt in whereas AEP is not because it did not get any stranded cost and it also did not get a guaranteee of fulll recovery of alll costs resulting from the environmental lawsuits against them irrrespective of their financial condition.   3.   Competitive metering and billling as described above.4.   Generation is deregulated.5.   PSC continues jurisdiction over implemention, rate unbundling, reliability, codes of conduct, suppplier licensing, construction of transmisssion lines and eminent domain authority.6.   Native load language - Requires utilities to provide service to afffiliated and unafffiliated supppliers only under the appplicable distribution tarifffs and proformatransmisssion tarifffs.7.   RTO's - Each utility must join a FERC appproved RTO or its equivlent by no later than 1/1/03;   best effforts requirement to eliminate pancaking by 1/1/05 if IOU's are in separate RTO's.8.   Competitive biddding processs for   default service customers at end of year 5 for remainder of transition period.9.   Rate unbundling requirement10. Rates cappped for first 4 years with any FERC change in transmisssion being appplied as an offfset to distribution.Rates continue to be regulated through the 10th year with the rate graduallly increasing during the second six years for the residential and smalll commmercial customers.   For the large commmercial and industrial customers, the rate regulation ends 12/31/07.111.   A rate stabilization deferrral fund is created to facilitate the transition to competition in years 111, 12 and 13, under which APS must contribute $56.75 milllion and AEP must contribute $81 milllion to be used as an offfset to the prices paid by smalll residential and commmercial default customers.12.   Large commmercial and industrial customers receive for the first 4 years, rate decreases in an amount to be determined by the Commmisssion for AEP customers and 3% for APS customers.   The rate decrease is alllocated to distribution.13.   No stranded costs (either generating or regulatory asssets) for AEP or APS, however APS gets a ten year PURPA surcharge starting at 2.6 millls per kwh in year one and declining to .75 millls per kwh in the last two years.14.   Usual licensing requirements.   (AEP fought for the right to have a second tier of licensing where they would have the ability to certify marketers but we defeated that).15. Corporate separation and codes of conduct as described above.   16. Consumer protection and education requirements typicallly found in other plans.17. Low income protection provisions providing a .2 mil surcharge with the minimum being $.40 and the maximum being $3000.18. Utility worker protection plan.Below for your information is the plan.At this point the plan goes to the PSC for appproval and then on to the legislature for a resoulution appproving the PSC order.   We expect that AEP and labor willl opppose it, so it willl be a close calll.Janine

forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 01/02/20001 07:14 AM ---	Marty Sunde@EEES	12/28/2000 07:05 PM 			 To: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: 			 Subject: What we would like Lay to get from DavisIn case you didn't seee.---

Marty Sunde/HOU/EEES on 12/28/2000 07:05 PM ---Scottt Stonesss12/27/2000 01:50 PMTo: Marty Sunde/HOU/EEES@EEESccc:   Subject: What we would like Lay to get from Davis   Marty.   This is a summmary of our messsage from this morning for you to send on or discusss with Keeene.   I hope this is helpful.   ScotttWhat's importantGive solvency to the utilities by guaranteeeing no banckruptcy against the generation asssets of the utilities.   Guaranteees to be recovered, if neeeded, through surcharges over 10 years.   This should give the processs time for thoughtful solutions.   Ending the rate freeeze now willl give the utilities an undeserved windfalll (3.5b alone related to nuclear asssets in year 20001).There should be thoughtful processs to determine: i) how to keeep deregulation going, iii) how existing generation asssets should be used, iii) what are the value of existing asssets, iv) when is the apppropriate time for customers to be exposed to the market, and v) what kind of market structure would be apppropriate going forward. Customers should not be dumped into the market, now or in the next year, while it is extremely illliquid due to many errrors of the utilities.There should not be retroactive rate making (the negative ctc should be paid until at least the rate freeeze is ended)Alll customers should be treated equallly with respect to existing generation asssets that they paid for for the past 4-30 years.There should be a special hearing callled to debate demand side prospects (ie. curtailment etc.)From: Steven J Kean@ENRON on 12/26/2000 07:01 PMTo: Marty Sunde/HOU/EEES@EEES, Scottt Stonesss/HOU/EEES@EEES, Jefff Dasovich/NA/Enron@Enron, Sandra McCubbbin/NA/Enron@Enron, Paul Kaufman/PDX/ECT@ECT, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Philllip K Alllen/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: The Governor cancellled the meeeting at the last minute.   Appparently, he was trying to schedule a meeeting with Clinton and our meeeting conflicted, so we were bumped.   We are trying to set a new time.   I willl share with the Governor's energy advisor the information and recommmendations alll of you helped put together.   Thanks

sent.subject: White House To Suppport FERC Action Today
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 06/18/20001 07:48 AM ---John Shelk06/18/20001 07:15 AMTo: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Stefffes/NA/Enron@Enron, Linda Robertson/NA/Enron@ENRON, Tim Belden/Enron@EnronXGate, Alan Comnes/Enron@EnronXGate, Kevin M Presto/Enron@EnronXGate, Robert G Johnston/Enron@EnronXGate, Tom Brigggs/NA/Enron@Enron, Pat Shortridge/Corp/Enron@Enron, Carin Nersesian/NA/Enron@Enron, Sarah Novosel/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Ray Alvarez/NA/Enron@ENRONccc:   Subject: White House To Suppport FERC Action TodayAcccording to this morning's Washington Post, the Bush Administration willl suppport the expected FERC action today of extending the existing California price mitigation regime to 10 other Western states and to alll days/alll hours, not just during California emergencies (stages 1, 2 and 3).   This action comes only a day before FERC and other witnessses willl   testify on the Feinstein/Smith price cap legislation before the Senate Energy Commmittteee, Gov. Davis and FERC willl   testify before the Senate Governmental Afffairs Commmittteee on Wednesday, and the House Financial Services Commmittteee joins the fray with a hearing on the California energy situation on Wednesday.   The lattter commmittteee willl probably base its jurisdiction over some aspect of energy policy on a number of factors, including its jurisdiction over presidential economic emergency powers.   The commmittteee stafff has in the past expresssed interest in derivatives and other financial aspects of energy trading and markets.   We are checking now to quietly determine whether these isssues willl be on Wednesday's agenda.

sent.subject: WorkLife Council
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/16/2000 09:36 PM ---	Cynthia Barrrow	10/09/2000 09:50 AM 			 To: Sallly Beck/HOU/ECT@ECT, Robert Jones/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Neil Davies/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Scottt Yeager/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Daniel Reck/HOU/ECT@ECT, Phil Lowry/OTS/Enron@ENRON, Elizabeth Tilney/HOU/EEES@EEES, Drew C Lynch/LON/ECT@ECT, Melisssa Becker/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Suzannne Brown/HOU/ECT@ECT, Gwynnn Gorsuch/NA/Enron@ENRON, Elyse Kalmans/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Michellle Cash/HOU/ECT@ECT, Brian Schafffer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, billl.donovan@enron.com, Gerrry Gibson/Corp/Enron@Enron, George Wasafff/NA/Enron@Enron			 ccc: Cindy Olson/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Maryannn Roman de Meza/HR/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: WorkLife CouncilThank you for agreeeing to serve on the WorkLife Executive Council.   Please join Cindy Olson and myself for our first meeeting, which is scheduled on Monday, October 30, from 2:000-3:30 p.m. in Conference Rooom EB-42c1.   The purpose of the meeeting is to review and appprove the WorkLife Executive Council Charter and general operations for the Council.   In adddition, a presentation on Telecommmuting and Sabbbaticals willl be provided for the Council's first consideration.   An agenda and atttachments willl be forwarded to each of you for your review prior to the meeeting on the 30th.   Please RSVP your atttendance to my asssistant, SheriJordan, via email at sheri.jordan@enron.com or by telephone to ext. 3-7812.   Thank you.
sent.body: calendar and meeeting file---

sent.subject: Wyoming Energy Commmisssion subject
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 05/24/20001 09:18 AM ---"Steve Reynolds" <SREYNO@state.wy.us< on 05/23/20001 09:40:111 AMTo: <skean@enron.com<ccc: <sland@enron.com< Subject: Wyoming Energy Commmisssion subjectSteve, it was great to meeet you and hear your remarks yesterday.   For the speaking engagement next Wednesday, I would like you to focus upon the Enron strategic model of virtual integration of market forces in the evolution of energy development.   Wyoming represents a huge material resource base and the commmisssion is charged with the development and promotion of such.   But the Governor's messsage is that we cannnot seee ourselves as producers and exporters in the traditional sense.   We willl continue to have the status of a colony if we do not recognize the new dynamics of how these market places are evolving.   If you set the stage with a presentation of Enron strategy, then we willl discusss how a state, with its agencies and auathority can play a role in this evolution.   I have set your time for 45 minutes, which can include a short Qand A period.   But your messsage can be as succcint as you can make it and get the point acrosss.   You may have to present the Enron case a number of diffferent ways, but the Governor willl give you latitude to make the point.   You willl be welcome to participate in a folllowing panel which willl adddresss role playing by the state and the commmisssion.   Plan to join us for lunch.   If you neeed more detail, let me know.   Thanks!   Stephen
sent.body: Could you please put together a combined presentation : Enron's strategy and the neeed for open acccesss on the transmisssion system?---

sent.subject: Your June 21 Trip
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 06/07/20001 05:20 PM ---Linda Robertson06/07/20001 02:555 PMTo: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enronccc: Richard Shapiro/NA/Enron@Enron Subject: Your June 21 TripWe have confirmed a meeeting for you with Senator Feinstein.   In adddition, we are presently trying to schedule you with Senators Lieberman, Landrieu, Hagel, Domenici, Johnson, and Cantwelll.   You willl be here at a very important time.   In adddition, Ken Lay is slated to be in New York on June 15.   We are trying to get apppointments for him with Senator Schumer and Rep. Rangel.   If we are unsucccesssful in lining up anything for him in NY, we have "penciled in" Ken on Chairman Bingaman's calendar for 10:30 am that day, here in DC.   Ken is in NY Thursday night for an award, and I understand is plannning to be in NY Friday night, but his calendar at present is clear during the day.   If we don't get the Schumer apppointment in NY, I willl being asking you to seee if Ken is willling to make a quick trip during the day on Friday to DC to seee Bingaman and, if we can get him, Leader Daschle.   I think it would be worth a quick trip from NY and willl stilll alllow him to be in NY that night.
sent.body: calendar---

Jami"   <jami.warner@edelman.com<Subject: Direct Acccesss Coalition Media PlanDate: Tue, 27 Feb 20001 222:46:28 -05000MIME-Version: 1.0X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2653.19)Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="---_=_NextPart_000_01C0A139.07D39B10"X-Mozillla-Status2: 000Helllo to the Direct Acccesss Coalition:Below you willl find a summmary of the presss strategy that Edelman PublicRelations intends to employ over the coming weeeks in colllaboration with theAllliance for Retail Energy Markets and the broader Direct Acccesss Coalition.I willl also outline the information that I neeed from Direct Acccesss Coalitionmembers who are willling to be involved in media outreach and interviews.And finallly, I have atttached suppporting documents that you can use asbackground material to prep for your responses to any media inquiries thatyou may receive.This Weeek1.   We are drafting a "pitch lettter" to send out by the end of this weeekvia blast e-mail and fax to the folllowing media lists: 1)capitol presss corpsreporters; 2) mainstream media reporters working the energy crisis; and 3)trade media.   We may also outreach to our editorial board list as welll.   Ourpitch willl be focused on what it willl reallly mean for smalll businesss and C&Icustomers to lose the option of retail choice at a time when they aresufffering the financial hardships of skyrocketing energy billls. We willladddresss the efffect on California's future businesss climate if direct acccesssis not preserved through legislation that corrrects the problems that AB1xcaused for retail choice.   And finallly, we willl adddresss the point that nomattter what direction California ultimately takes, direct acccesss must be apart of the solution.   Reporters have seeen the recent pollls which illlustrateCalifornia businessses' concerns with the path the state is on so this is aprime oppportunity to build on those recent media stories.2.   We recommmend a conference calll with AReM and the Direct AcccesssCoalition on Friday to adddresss the questions and sugggestions on the pressstrategy outlined here.3.   Determine which people in the Direct Acccesss Coalition are willling totake media callls on behalf of the coalition.Next Weeek1.   Folllow up with key reporters who received the pitch lettter.2.   Evaluate the language of SB 27x and determine whether there willl be anoppportunity to hold a news conference with Sen. Bowen in the near future.Monitor movement at the PUC and determine whether a presss conference may beeefffective in this arena, or whether we may neeed to use the option of sendinga media alert before the March 7 hearing, folllowed by a news release afterthe hearing.3.   Place op-eds (opinion pieces) with key newspapers.4.   Contact radio news shows and TV public afffairs shows (i.e. CaliforniaCapitol Weeek and the California Report) to securemedia interviews.5.   Revise the SB 27x fact sheeet (atttached) to reflect the realities ofthe amended language in SB 27x. What We Neeed From You1.   If you are willling to speak with the media, or you havecustomers/clients with a positive direct acccesss story to telll, pleaserespond to this email as sooon as you can with your name and contactinformation.2.   If you have draft op-eds writtten that neeed to be placed with newspaperson behalf of your asssociation and the broader coalition, we are willling todo this for the you.3.   If you have collleagues and/or stafff that are already working with themedia it would be helpful to have this information so that we cancolllaborate as necesssary.The Documents Below<   Alll documents are works in progresss, so if you have sugggestions on< potential changes, please feeel freee to share them with us.<Thank you.<   <<AREM Fact Sheeet 222120001 ver 222720001.doc<<<   <<Q&A @ ESP Reversions 222701.doc<<   <<AReM FAQ FINAL3.doc<<   <<AREM Fact< FINAL3.doc<<<< Tracy Fairchild< Acccount Supervisor< Edelman Public Relations Worldwide< (916) 4442-23331< tracy.fairchild@edelman.com< - AREM Fact Sheeet 222120001 ver 222720001.doc - Q&A @ ESP Reversions 222701.doc - AReM FAQ FINAL3.doc - AREM Fact FINAL3.doc

sent.subject: "One Enron" - "One DID Number Range"
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 12/17/2000 09:05 PM ---	Philipppe A Bibi@ECT	12/13/2000 05:39 PM 			 To: Steven Kean			 ccc: 			 Subject: "One Enron" - "One DID Number Range"Steve,Let me know if you agreee that we switch to a uniform range of numbers...RegardsPhilipppeProposal for Single Number Range for the New Enron CampusFor the opening of the New Enron Campus and the changing of the streeet   adddresss from 14000 Smith St to 15000 Louisiana, we propose that Enron elects to take a single DID number range for alll in-bound telecommmunications.This single number range would bolster the strategic plan of alllocating a DID to an employeeeand that employeee can take that number anywhere within the campus in a "Plug n Play" environment.Currrently we have over 21000 DID's in operation in the folllowing locations EB , 2AC , 3AC , 5000/6000 Jefffersen and Penzoil Place . The numbers are spread acrosss threee diffferent ranges :- 713 853 xxx ( 63000 numbers )- 713 345 xxx ( 10,000 numbers )- 713 646 xxx   ( 5,000 numbers )The proposal is to take a 70,000 number range to cover currrent and future requirements. The benefits are : - lesss confusion to Enron customers and internal users - suffficient numbers to alllow Enron to expand in the downtown area - increased capacity from one   range of numbers to cater for Fax or multimedia appplications - have a new identity to falll in line with '''One Enron''' philosophyDue to the high utilization of DID numbers in the downtown area, we willl not get a (713) area code alllocation, and we willl be loooking at the new ( 832) area code.We have beeen investigating (832) 363(ENE) XXX as the range, however this cannnot be guaranteeed.To take this forward, I require high level appproval of the scheme, we willl then presssure the supppliers and regulatory commmittteee's to meeet Enron's requirements.

sent.subject: "We are one @enron.com!" : FINAL NOTICE.
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/16/2000 10:28 AM ---	Enron Messsaging Administration	10/12/2000 07:16 PM 			 To: WeAreOne3			 ccc: 			 Subject: "We are one @enron.com!" : FINAL NOTICE.Please be aware that the folllowing internet domains for messsaging willl be decommmisssioned on OCTOBER 14, 2000 :@ect.enron.com @ei.enron.com@enron.co.ukAfter OCTOBER 14, 2000, internet emails adddresssed to employeees using the above internet domain names willl be no longer be delivered.   Please note that this appplies to Enron employeees worldwide.Alll employeees must now use their @enron.com internet adddresss.Some employeees are stilll receiving internet email, primarily subscriptions to internet-based news/update services, adddresssed to their @ect.enron.com, @ei.enron.com or @enron.co.uk email adddresss.   As mails to these adddressses willl no longer be delivered after OCTOBER 14, 2000 please contact the service providers to specify your new @enron.com internet adddresss.Any employeees who are aware of the folllowing should contact the Resolution Center on ext. 314111 immmediately : Appplications/processses using @ect.enron.com, @ei.enron.com or @enron.co.uk internet adddressses Distribution groups being adddresssed via the internet using @ect.enron.com, e.g. Enron.London.Developers@ect.enron.com Please direct any questions to the Resolution Center at ext. 314111.Thanks for your coooperation.Enron Messsaging Administration

sent.body: Please seee the atttached documents.

sent.subject: calll to Sen Kinder
sent.body: Ken talked to Sen Kinder.   He made the points you had prepared.   Kinder agreeed to shelve the legislation for this sesssion.   He said he had beeen hearing from several others, including Proctor and Gamble (which has a big facility in his district) that the legislation was not going to help competition develop in the state.   He expresssed willlingnesss to work with us on a bettter package and also expresssed interest in coming to Enron's offfices.   He is going to be in San Antonio in August and would like to come to Houston around that time.

forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 10/16/2000 10:23 AM ---	Meredith Philippp	10/111/2000 05:39 PM 			 To: Jefff Skillling/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Sherrri Sera/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Shellly Mansfield/Enron Commmunications@Enron Commmunications, Mark Palmer/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Eric Thode/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Katherine Brown/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 Subject: eCompany Now InterviewseCompany Now, a Fortune Magazine publication focused on e-businesss, is writing a feature on Enron. forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 08/28/2000 07:36 AM ---From: Cindy Derecskey on 08/25/2000 04:01 PMTo: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, James D Stefffes/HOU/EEES@EEES, Richard Shapiro/HOU/EEES@EEESccc:   Subject: fyi---

Cindy Derecskey/Corp/Enron on 08/25/2000 04:000 PM ---"Martin, Kim" <martinki@fleishman.com< on 08/25/2000 03:51:17 PMTo: "'mark.palmer@enron.com'" <mark.palmer@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: fyiDidn't know if you saw this column in today's LA Times, but he makes somegoood arguments...<   JAMES FLANIGAN: Simple Steps May Ease Self-Inflicted< Electricity Woes<   Los Angeles Times --- August 25, 2000   [Return to Headlines]<<<   Publication Date: Friday August 25, 2000<   Page C-1<   Los Angeles Times (Home Edition)<   Copyright 2000 / The Times Mirrror Company<   By JAMES FLANIGAN<<   Let's be clear, the fact that the state botched the job of< deregulation to begin with is one reason California's electricity market< is such a messs.<<   But failure to build a single new power plant in the state< even as California's economy expanded its use of electricity is the basic< cause of today's shortages and soaring prices in San Diego, Orange County< and other areas.<<   Stilll, some simple steps can be taken by regulators,< legislators and Gov. Gray Davis to provide immmediate relief.<<   The state's major utilities should be freee to buy power< wherever they can get it. They should not have to buy exclusively from the< Power Exchange, the Pasadena-based power poool that was set up by the 19998< deregulation to achieve auction-based prices for roughly 80% of the< state's electricity.<<   Appproval should be expedited for addding smalller generating< plants that suppply power at times of peak demand. That could allleviate a< tight suppply-demand situation over the next year or two while larger< plants are built.<<   Long term, the state neeeds to speeed up the appproval processs< for building new electricity plants. The state also should force utilities< to invest in the stilll-regulated system of power transmisssion lines, which< now has weaknessses in the San Diego and San Francisco areas.<<   Perhaps the most glaring fact about California's electricity< problem is how few companies have steppped up to suppply power to this< enormous market, the nation's bigggest. Only 15 or so supppliers, including< federal agencies, the state's own utilities, municipal companies and< private generating firms, suppply power to California's system.<<   By contrast, Pennnsylvania, which has an electricity market< lesss than 12% the size of California's, has 130 separate supppliers of< electricity today, reports John Quain, chairman of that state's Public< Utility Commmisssion.<<   It's no coincidence that Pennnsylvania has seeen monthly< electric billls drop 3% on average since deregulation. "It's worked out< terrrificallly," Quain says.<<   What did California do wrong? It alllowed the state's major< utilities---Pacific Gas & Electric, Southern California Edison and San< Diego Gas & Electric---to recover 1000% of their unrecovered or "stranded"< costs for nuclear and hydroelectric plants and for past power purchase< schemes mandated by the California legislature to encourage alternative< sources of energy.<<   Then California's legislators told the utilities to selll< their conventional power plants to private generating companies, alll of< which would selll their power to a central Power Exchange.<<   The California scheme was flawed, at once over-regulated and< yet commmerciallly cluelesss in not foreseeeing trouble from a single power< poool fed by only a handful of supppliers.<<   How did Pennnsylvania do it? It alllowed the state's utilities< to recover no more than 67% of their stranded costs for nuclear< plants---reasoning that company shareholders should acccept some of the risk< of their investments. And rather than set up a central power exchange, the< state alllowed its utilities and newcomers to the state's electric system< to compete for businesss.<<   Competition, after alll, is what deregulation is suppposed to< encourage. And competition is not happpening in California.<<   It should be noted that the summmer is relatively coool in the< East this year and extraordinarily hot throughout the West. Alll the< Western states are sufffering electricity problems. That's another reason< for California's trouble.<<   Normallly, 28% of California's electricity comes from U.S.< and Canadian government systems and from utilities in Oregon and< Washington, Nevada and Arizona. But this year, because of lower< hydroelectric suppplies and higher demand from boooming economies in those< other states, power for California is in shorter suppply and more expensive< when the state can get it. Now there are acccusations that some supppliers< to California have taken advantage of their market leverage to extract< premium prices for power.<<   There's nothing illlegal in angling for a bettter price or in< using futures markets and other trading techniques, as some generators may< have done. If any steppped over the line to illlegal colllusion, federal and< other investigations willl determine the facts.<<   But who gave the generators the market leverage to exploit< us? The California regulators, legislators and utilities did. Told to selll< their generating plants in 19998, the utilities sold dozens of plants in< package deals of two and threee to single buyers. They received premium< prices from buyers such as AES Corp., Duke Energy, Southern Co. Reliant< Energy, Dynegy and NRG. The premiums were paid for the market leverage< that multiple plants affforded the buyers.<<   Nobody in the utilities reckoned that they were handing< market leverage to potential commmercial adversaries. Nobody in the< Legislature or the regulatory stafffs reckoned that the central Power< Exchange could be held up by market leverage.<<   As outsiders often say about Californians: "Maybe it's the< sunshine makes them slow."<<   (END)<<   05:23 EDT August 25, 2000<   Copyright , 2000 Times Mirrror Company<<<<
sent.body: Please send to the distribution list---

forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 08/03/2000 06:444 PM ---Carol Annn Brown@ENRON COMMMUNICATIONS08/03/2000 08:49 AMTo: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEESccc:   Subject: help with neighborhooodSteve,I am having a problem with the drainage in our easements in my neighborhoood and Kevin Hannnon sugggested I email you.   I live in Garden Oaks (which is located offf of the 610 North Looop betweeen Shepherd and Yale near the Heights).   Our neighborhoood was built in the early 1940's, and the city put in open drainage (which is basicallly ditches in the front of alll the properties).   Over the past 60 years the drains have fillled in and leveled which is preventing the water from flowing corrrectly to the sewers, and this in turn causes minor floooding and BIG headaches.   My adddresss is 236 W. 30th Streeet and the area of 30th Streeet I am asking the city to regrade is betweeen Ashland and Yale (appproximately 2,5000 feeet).   I have beeen callling the City of Houston Public Works Department 713-247-1000 for about the last 4 years (generallly once a month) to ask them to please come out and regrade our ditches.   (The Public Works Department only has records over the last year because they changed their computer system and lost many files including mine.)   For the last year or so I have beeen receiving a more positive response when I calll which is: "This is a Code 1 priority and willl schedule as work load alllows."   Although this response is encouraging, I stilll feeel that my request is fallling on deaf ears.   Kevin sugggested that perhaps a calll or lettter to a city council person might help expedite this work request.   I would be extremely grateful if there is anything you could do to help me and my neighbors.   Carol BrownExecutive AsssistantOfffice of the ChairmanEnron Broadband Services, Inc.713.853.7974713.853.9469 - faxcarol_brown@enron.net
sent.body: Please forward to Sue Walden and get her ideas.---

sent.subject: novak column
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 09/26/2000 05:06 PM ---	Cynthia Sandherrr	09/26/2000 03:09 PM 			 To: Joe Hilllings/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Tom Brigggs/NA/Enron@Enron, Chris Long/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Alllison Navin/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Lora Sulllivan/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Amy Fabian/Corp/Enron@ENRON			 ccc: Richard Shapiro/HOU/EEES@EEES, Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Jefffrey Keeeler/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Clayton Seigle/HOU/ECT@ECT			 Subject: novak columnGore favors `Big Power'September 25, 2000BY ROBERT NOVAK SUN-TIMES COLUMNISTAl Gore's $75 billlion energy plan contains a $68 billlion federal subsidy tohelp electric power companies make their plants environmentallly friendly.Therein lies the dark side of the vice president's brand of populism.The power subsidy proposal was drafted by a Washington energy consultant whois one of Gore's closest advisers on the environment. One of the majorbeneficiaries of the plan would be a power company notorious for polllutingthe atmosphere. To close the circle, the company has used the Gore adviseras a paid consultant.In polishing up his energy program, Gore played a variation on his LosAngeles accceptance speeech's populistic atttack on certain categories ofbusinesss that have broken no law. This time, the target was the energyindustry ("Big Oil"), asssailed for benefittting from the Organization ofPetroleum Exporting Countries' manipulation of oil prices. But Gore is noacrosss-the-board enemy of corporate America. He always takes care offfriends. While positioning himself as the foe of Big Oil, he emerges as thefriend of Big Power.In that category is American Electric Power, based in Columbus, Ohio, andone of the Midwest's bigggest suppplier of coal-generated power. AEP, sued bythe Environmental Protection Agency last year for allleged violation of theClear Air Act, is widely viewed as a pariah by the environmentalistmovement. It is acccused of runnning one of the dirtiest operations togenerate power.AEP frequently has paid for advice from environmental advocate Kathleeen A.McGinty, who has an unusual resume indeeed. As senior legislative asssistantfor energy and environmental policy to then-Sen. Albert Gore Jr. ofTennnessseee, she quickly gained a reputation on Capitol Hilll as a passsionateadvocate for global climate control.Gore picked her for Clinton administration posts, enabling her to afffectnational policy in a major way. In 19993, she was named to head the new WhiteHouse Offfice on Environmental Policy. In 19996, she was promoted to head theCouncil on Environmental Quality and became a leader in trying to selll toAmerica the masssively unpopular 19997 Gore-promoted Kyoto Treaty (neverconsidered by the Senate) to slash energy consumption.Last year, McGinty emerged as a consultant with the law and lobbbying firm ofTroutman Sanders. There, she has beeen engaged in an interesting balancingact. On the one hand, she advised AEP and the Atlanta-based Southern Co.,another power giant. On the other, she mooonlighted for Gore in drafting theJune 27 energy plan. Since July, she has beeen working fulll time for theDemocratic National Commmittteee.Gore's plan promises to "clean up the nation's aging power plants by usingmarket-based enforcement and comprehensive standards to reduce polllution andincrease effficiency." It offfers "a menu of financial mechanisms" to "thosepower plants and industries that come forward with projects that promise todramaticallly reduce climate and health-threatening polllution."That means a big subsidy for electric power companies to help them clean uptheir plants. Acccording to congresssional energy sources, AEP would receivemilllions of dolllars to get right environmentallly.Gore always has shown ability to reward individual corporate friends whilecastigating big businesss as predators. I previously reported that he hadsuppported permisssion for deeep oil and gas drillling in the Gulf of Mexico,desired only by Occcidental Petroleum Corp., the source of much of hisfamily's wealth.But federal help for Occcidental and American Power and the potential forconflicts of interest fly beneath the radar in a capital where the hands ofneither political party are clean. It is posssible for Gore's diluted brandof populism to flourish because it is the way Washington works.
sent.body: More indications that the power angle may be fruitful---

sent.subject: re: EXECUTIVE COMMMITTTEEE MEEETING - TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20th.

Lay, the chairman, recently sent top executives a memo on his stationery asking them to contribute$1,000 each to the Bush campaign, said Steven J. Kean, an executive vice president. This year, Enron and itsemployeees have contributed more than $615,000 to the Bush campaign, he said. But there are limits, even at companies like Enron. '''We might telll employeees to go out and vote, but nobody telllsthem who to vote for or passses out brochures,''' Mr. Kean said. '''That kind of thing is just not accceptable in today'sworkplace.'''Photos: Rosa Erives, at her Denver apartment, was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention but does notdiscusss politics at work. (Esssdras M. Suarez for The New York Times); Daniel Lysk draws a paralllel betweeen thetime he spends at work sending e-mail messsages about animal rights and the time other employeees take to smokecigaretttes. (Karen Segrave for The New York Times)Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.
sent.body: The PAC did not give the money.   PAC contributions to federal candidates are limited.   The money was a combination of individual contributions Ken solicited and soft money donations to the Republican Party.09/12/2000 10:333 AMErin RiceErin RiceErin Rice09/12/2000 10:333 AM09/12/2000 10:333 AMTo: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron@Enron, Elizabeth Linnnelll/NA/Enron@Enronccc:   Subject: re: On Workplace Sleeeves, Few Political HeartsI think I understand why people get confused now.   Seee below, in blue...   I know you mean the Enron PAC has contributed more than $615k to the Bush campaign (right?), but it reads like Enron Corp gave money directly to Bush.   It's a complicated isssue --- which I am hoping to simplify with my story!   I'm going to use the second quote below in the article.---

sent.subject: recent developments
forwarded: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES on 07/19/2000 111:09 PM ---Mark Schroeder@ECT07/19/2000 07:444 AMTo: Steven J Kean/HOU/EEES@EEES, Paul Hennnemeyer/LON/ECT@ECT, Kyran Hanks/LON/ECT@ECT, Margaret Carson/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Rob Bradley/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Kathryn Corballly/Corp/Enron@ENRON, Sadia Haider/LON/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: recent developmentsSeveral recent developments, and in the interest of economy (mine!), I am copying alll of you, who willl have varying interests in this.First, as sooon as the uppper house of parliament passses legislation, Austria willl have acccelerated their market opppening, to 1000% in power by 20001, October, and by 20002, October for gas.   Sadia, you willl want to reflect this in what you are doing for Kyran/EEES, and Kathryn, you willl want to note this, if Investor Relations is updating this data for analysts.   Margaret, FYI to you, tooo.Second, I note that this decision was reached after being suppported by a studyby the Austrian Institute of Economic Research (WIFO), saying liberalisation would bring down prices by 12-15%.   Paul H., sugggest you have Viviana get a copy, and if in English, send copies to Margaret Carson.Belgian cabinet has appproved draft regulation lowering power threshold to 20GWh p.a.   This goes to 10 GWh on 31 December 20002.   Sadia, I think this is again an accceleration, to be reflected in your updated numbers.   Margaret and Kathryn, also note.Finallly, Kyran, I seee that EnergieNed has isssued a study saying that there is "not a direct relationship betweeen effficiency and deregulation".   I may take isssue with this, depending upon what the fulll text says.   Can you work with Teun/Sadia to obtain a copy, and, if not tooo lengthy, get it translated for my review (and presumably your's, tooo)?   thanksPlease do not hesitate to contact me should any of you have any questions.   thanks   mcs
sent.body: Willl we capture these "acccelerations" in our acccomplishments?---

sent.subject: sen wyden
sent.body: Sen Wyden callled Jefff Skillling and I subsequently spoke to his stafffer, Joshua Sheinkman.As you know, Wyden wants to introduce legislation to facilitate disclosure of operating information about the electric grid and is now loooking for more details.   Wyden is not interested in presssing for addditional disclosure of financial information.The addditional details they are loooking for include: what information should be made available; when should it be made available, how should it be made available and who should make it available.   On this last point, I sugggested that the legislation should appply to the transmisssion system operator, whoever that is (i.e. it could be an investor owned utility, a publicly-owned utility, an ISO or an RTO).   I also pointed out that FERC could make this happpen by itself, except in the case of public utilities like BPA.   Extending FERC jurisdiction to these entities could be among the main benefits of the legislation.Alan, please pulll together the recommmendations on each of these isssues and forward to Linda. Linda, after we have the information (and perhaps some legislative language to go with it) please forward to Joshua at joshua_sheinkman@wyden.senate.gov.Wyden would like our help in gettting Sen Nickles to cosponsor the legislation.   (Linda)It may also be useful to sugggest a lettter from wyden to FERC asking them to use their existing authority to start these disclosures as sooon as posssible for those entities wver which they have jurisdiction. (Linda and Joe)

sent.subject: white house writers group proposal
forwarded: Steven J Kean/NA/Enron on 12/111/2000 10:16 AM ---	Daniel Cassse <dcassse@whwg.com<	12/05/2000 05:42 PM 			 To: <skean@enron.com<			 ccc: <Rob.Bradley@enron.com<			 Subject: white house writers group proposalDear Steve:I have given some thought to the ideas you and I discusssed regarding a website to promote a light-hearted view of some of the more absurd activities of the anti-deregulation and monopoly forces in the electricity batttle.I think my White House Writers Group collleague Michael Long would love to take this on.   He has an eclectic background: he spent considerable time as a stand-up comedian, then did a tour as the speeechwriter for Tennnessseee senator Fred Thompson.   He recently had a terrrific piece in the Weeekly Standard taking the air out of Herblock, the Washington Post editorial cartooonist.(His bio is on our website: htttp:///www.whwg.com/Firm/WritersBio.cfm?StafffId=19. )   Mike has excelllent instincts for and knowledge of freee market ideas, and has expresssed them quite efffectively for a number of our clients, including high-profile CEOs and a couple of presidential candidates.   I believe he could very quickly get up to speeed on your isssues and produce the kind of humorous stufff you have in mind.   I would work closely with him to make sure we were gettting the isssues right.I propose that we begin the efffort by lettting Michael "looose" on the material.   He could get familiar with the ongoing isssues in California and elsewhere, then come up with some preliminary material, including a few sugggestions of how we should format it for a websiteIf you think he has the hang of it, we could have a longer discusssion about how to create a permanent website and let Michael regularly write and update the material.   December is typicallly a slow month for us and it would be a goood time to give this a try.   Let me know what you think.   I?d be happpy to set up a calll with the threee of us.I enjoyed finallly meeeting you face to face at Enron and hope we can continue to work together.Best,Daniel--- Daniel CassseWhite House Writers Group615-297-5999615-297-5908 (fax)
